Are you kidding me? Best picture of the year? Now it's in the category with "12 Years a Slave" "On the Waterfront" "An American in Paris" et al? Wow. I found this slow, violent, gross, and awful. It did not present any social commentary whatsoever. The poor characters were more disgusting than the rich and were hideously violent. And being poor doesn't give you license to kill someone who says you smell bad. Calling this film and expose on social justice is an insult to films that effectively examine social class and its impact on lives. I could not relate to nor empathize with even one character in the film. They were hollow. The film carried no true emotional depth. And if it was meant to be a comedic effort, I think I laughed twice, at most. It wasn't funny, it's wasn't thrilling, it wasn't dramatic, it was... dumb? And, as mentioned, violent. The storyline, itself, had potential. It could have gone really interesting places. It did not. And the ending? The kid is going to somehow become rich and buy probably the most expensive home in South Korea to free his father from the basement of the house. Sure. I will say, acting was good, cinematography was good, basic plot premise, interesting. The film? Not good at all. Not good at all.

Decent movie, nothing really special.

The first time I have watched a movie in theaters several times, this movie was worth it. It was just as entertaining the second time, even knowing where the plot was gonna go, which I think is a testament to how well this movie is cast, paced and just overall constructed.
An incredibly unsual film, full of twists and turns, putting the audience constantly envolved in it's plot twists and simbolism. One of the best of 2019.
Intense but perfect storyline. Can’t think of a way to make it better

It’s is a Tarantino style Korean movie with great characters and a beautifully orchestrated tragically strong ending. I’ve watched subtitles movies before so I thought I’d give it a chance given the fact that it won a ton of awards.Great plot that twists until the end.
I love this movie! I've seen it twice now, and every time I see something a bit different that makes me want to watch it again.
95%. Just a phenomenal movie. Fun seeing the different social classes represented in the Korean culture. Funny build up and intense and dramatic scenes at its peak. So well done.

The least life-affirming film I've seen in some time. It makes Quentin Tarantino's worst on-screen moments feel like feel-good Frank Capra moments like when George Bailey finds it's snowing again! It begins well, but it's descent into evil is complete and unrelenting. I didn't watch the last 12 or so minutes, and I never will. Jojo Rabbit---bleak subject matter and all, but with a shred of dignity, a last gasp of hope, to my mind, that's the film that deserved the Oscar (and I've seen them all now).
About as perfect a movie as a film can be: great sets, acting, screenplay.  Thrilling, horrifying, funny, and at the same time heavy on message.
I saw it last night on our TV with my husband, daughter and son-in-law.  We all agreed it was as fascinating and hypnotic as all the reviews.  Thought-provoking to say the least!
Great film! Beautifully done. Thoroughly enjoyed it
horrible and disgusting

A great moment for Korean cinema and an extremely thought provoking film. Very much a film of two half's, moving from comedy to something darker. An exploration of the class system and the power of money to block out the smell of life.
Perfect film, all social criticism is profound and extremely valid today.

Worst movie I have ever seen in my life. Also, screw them for promoting pedophilia and abuse against girls.  People are drawing messages out of it that were not remotely shown. It's about the rich exploiting the poor? Then show the rich exploiting the poor. No sympathy for the Kim family.  Much more sympathy for the Park family. So many breadcrumbs that didn't pay off. Could have been a great movie, but instead it seemed like someone got ahold of it and changed the last third of it for the worse.
Smart, honest, and allegorical. Well-crafted. But best picture...? It sure doesn't paint the lower class very well.

I don't get why people love this movie so much. It's about a terrible family who do terrible things and probably don't get enough of what they deserve. The most redeeming part of this movie is when the credits roll. There are FANTASTIC Korean movies that deserve more attention then they're getting, but this is not one of them. The acting is pretty good, but the story is garbage, so does is matter? No one is likable, except maybe the dogs. Anyways, don't waste your time.
Hot garbage. The story played out like some strange anime. Time I wasted on this movie will be lost forever.

An outstanding flick - hard to figure which box to fit it in but worth watching.
I do not think it deserved best picture but it is a great movie

Well put-together film providing a window into a foreign culture, with universal themes. You wonder who the "parasite" really is, and I guess that's the point -either of the families depicted can be the parasite in their own ways.

I personally did not like the movie, and I was constantly questioning HOW this movie won an oscar. Some of the qualities I didn't like included: 1) the movie was horribly long, 2) slow development of the plot, 3) the idiocy and obliviousness of the Park family,and lastly, 4) the lack of morals of the Kim family. I understand the point of the movie and how it was contrasting the gap of wealth in South Korea: the desperateness of the poverty-stricken Kim family vs. the comfortable lifestyle of Park family. However, this film was a long, drawn-out, and ineffective way to express this message.
This movie will go down in cinema history and deserved every award/nomination it got and then some.

Great story, amazing surprises and extremely lovable cast. I did not like some of the turns towards the end, and the needless stretching of the climax, but directors have to be commended for avoiding the obvious story arc there too.
The movie is completely over hyped.  The plot did not have any unique ideas nor did it deliver the brain teaser people claimed.  The twist ending was no surprise, making it more disappointing.
A multi-layered masterpiece that deserves the accolades.
Every aspect of filmmaking is really remarkable in this piece of utopic art. A movie that you can't fit to any genre. Because it's beyond that.
everthing was so in place. the setting/story was just a side note. everything inside the setting was completely aligned.
We'll never know who the good ones were...

I’m fine with the subtitles, I have no problems with the movie, but for best picture, this doesn’t come close to some of the other options this year. Maybe my expectations were too high. The ratings this movie has received from critics and audience makes me think it’s more about the time it was released instead of the actual content of this movie. Cinematography is superb, I will admit.

An engrossing movie from start to finish. I especially liked the first half, as the poor family slowly becomes part of the rich family's life. How they pulled that off was very impressive. Then the movie takes a turn, and has scenes that are quite thrilling. It does get a bit violent at the end. This is the kind of movie that will stick with you and have you asking questions afterward. It's a great one to see then talk about with friends.

Boong Joon Ho directs this Oscar winning movie about the disreputable behaviour of a Korean family who infiltrate the home and lives of a wealthy couple by gradually taking over the roles of domestic helpers. It has some funny moments like many of his films but it turns very dark and menacing. Though I really did enjoy the film, I personally, didn't think this deserved the Oscar win for best movie as although a strong and powerful tale, for me, there were better films in the preceding year. I also do not think this is the best of  Boong Joon Ho's movies. However, the fact that it did win is to be applauded as a massive step forward in the recognition that there are movies made outside Hollywood.
I feel like it delivered in the acting, but the story didn't entice me or give me any positive emotions.
One of the best thrillers ever made

Parasite was such an incredible movie. It’s one of the best movies of 2019 I’ve seen since “Joker” and “Once Upon a Time in Hollywood”. Parasite is a must see movie that you don’t want to miss out on.
The ending was very bleak, along with the rest of the film.

I mean, this is an unpopular opinion, but I didn't really care for it. I did like the bunker twist it had (sorry for the spoiler alert), but other than that, it really didn't live up to the hype I was expecting.
It's good. ‏‏‎ ‎‏‏‎ ‎

The stunning visuals and compelling story are unlike any other. Creating a masterpiece that breaks the language barrier is hard enough, specifically with the English audience. I can't wait to see future movies from the director; his style creates a uniform and unifying feel that certainly works extremely well in this film. Loved it; kept it at the edge of my seat.

Unforgettable experience!
It is authentic,it's brilliant....it shows you how a large portion of the people around the world live and how they deceive and trick other people due to their circumstances...which is not an excuse surely....it makes you struggle with the family and think how to solve their problems....and the great thing was that they always had hope!....that was so astonishing....In spite of all the troubles they were immersed into....someone of them always had hope
It wasn't boring which was surprising....as if the introduction of the movie describing the conditions of the family was extended a bit...it would've had some boredom....I anticipated some boredom but there was none!
The father by Kang-Ho Song and the rich lady by Cho Yeo-jeong are the best roles in my opinion....both caught my attention especially the father
I felt the hatred growing inside him against the the rich man every single shot....it was peaceful acting and yet powerful.....and sometimes I loved his carelessness....he was great.
And there's a scene with mesmerising cinematography!
Literally a masterpiece!

This is where the class dystopia begins, we see a story that looks as if it is false or to good to be true but it is! This movie seems to take on so many things and balance them all with perfection and grace. hats off to Boon Joon Ho for is fantastic wrtting and revolutionary direction.
Filmed expensive, but that's pretty much it

This is such a good movie. After hearing so much buzz about this film at the Oscars, somehow I still had no idea what the movie was about going into it. Boy was it a wild ride. The actors were great, the plot was super strong, and I can't say enough good things about how beautiful this film is just to look at. II had to watch this film with subtitles as I do not speak a word other than English, and boy do I wish I did just so I could understand this film in all its glory. One thing to note (that did not impact my rating at all) is that it is long film and reading subtitles for that long can, for me at least, get tiring. Just go into it with the mindset of being ready to really, really focus on the film and I think anyone would enjoy it.
This movie is the best of the movies 2019, i like this film for the history of the characters, and the south korea film wins an Oscar of the best picture, i want the movie again
What a great film. This is exactly the kind of creativity the film industry needs.
I don't usually watch movies with subtitles.  They usually disappoint me.  This one was a huge surprise.  Excellent film that runs the gamut of emotions from comedy to tragedy and all in between.
I went expecting a great movie and it was just ok. I guess not my cup of tea. No need to watch again.
The biggest plot twist I could have ever imagined!

I absolutely loved this! The first hour of the movie it was more of a comedy but after that everything changed. The whole ambiance changed, and I was literally shook all the time after that happened. This was beautiful acted and so well done, I haven't seen a movie as good as this was in a long time. I have no points of improvement, everything was so well thought. This was a movie which took a while to get out of my head, cause everything was so intense. I would really recommend this to anyone!!
Brilliant filmmaking.
great overall movie starts off slow but ties together at the end

Ingenious and heartwarming! 
A real movie that unifies families and embraces family teamwork.
Comedy that takes a sharp turn into commentary. Interesting film that I understand why everyone was going gaga about.
It was a good con thriller.  It gave me an appreciation for Korean culture too.  I'd like to visit.  Rented this on Verizon.  Best picture winner.

One of its kind. Every character of this film did their damm good performance. Outstanding story with outstanding screenplay. A must watch of 2020.
Unique with an original story and topic, it's not your everyday movie . A must see!!

The plot, cinematography, score,screenplay were all flawless

Masterpiece.
I hate everything of this movie

Apparently, I am no stranger to the work of Bong Joon-ho, realizing he directed Snowpiercer starring Chris Evans in 2013 which I really enjoyed and recommend. Parasite is a movie that surprised many during award season but after finally watching this movie I now see why it won an Academy Award for Best Picture.

This was the first time in a long time that I did not have my phone in my vicinity while watching a movie at home. Because this movie has subtitles and was praised to be so great, I decided it needed my undivided attention and I succeeded in doing so. Sitting at 2 hours and 12 minutes I was completely sucked in. You could say this movie is a comedy that turns dark that is filled with laughs, thrills, and suspense while delivering a message about class discrimination. Many great movies can also be predictable but I found myself on a roller coaster ride full of twists and turns, and plenty of uncertainty. With great acting all around and amazing cinematography, you are in for a film-going experience.

I give Parasite a 9.5/10 and recommend you give it a watch on digital during our time of social distancing.

Well the Oscar itself describes what you're gonna be watching/have watched. The direction is just too beautiful to be understood by many. The metaphors that this movie hints on is quite intricately hidden but easy to find and feel onto. The sound effects from the doors to the grass in the lawn is brought up pretty well. .5 is up for the ending. Not saying an alternaitve would do the job but a little bit more chilli makes the taco more tastier. Overall- Oscar deserving!
Excellent movie. Many meaningful details to pay attention to. An interesting commentary on how the wealthy class is oblivious to the struggles of the non-wealthy.
Masterpiece!! The movie was so many different things built into one. Funny, intense, sad, and overall, just so well written!

"Ki-woo, you know what kind of plan never fails? No plan at all. You know why? If you make a plan, life never works out that way."

This quote from Kim Ki-taek talking to his son perfectly explains the movie as a whole: When the audience expects something, the plot never works that way - it never ceases to be unpredictable.
That is a good movie
Perhaps one of the best films of the century

everything about this film was beautiful, the direction, the story, the character. Now i see what the hype was about!

Parasite does shine during it's second half though and it does get to the point in which you can't wait to see how it ends. A pretty good movie that does take some bold risks but ultimately, I found it overrated.
Fantastically orchestrated, beautifully filmed and a finely crafted picture that's genuinely gripping. Bringing as a dark comedy, segueing into tragedy. It's truly a story of two halves.

My favorite movie of the year (2019). As far as I can tell, the thing this movie does hasn't really been done before. And the way it's filmed is so mesmerizing. It's a very nice-looking movie. But the performances are also great. It can be kind of hard to tell since it's a different language, though. And the music is an excellent compliment to every scene

Utterly unlikable characters, oafish, gross and crude.  Lack of humor.  Poorly conceived plot.  Basically it is a movie about a degenerate family whose degeneration comes as no surprise.  Lack luster dialogue. Acting was fine, but the script was garbage.  The setting was garbage as well, supposedly the house was some sort of artistic home, but it seemed like it was simply a concrete box.  The score was lackluster however the boxing of the movie was quite well done, the sounds of the doors opening and shutting sounded real and authentic. It reminded me of a cheap knock off Cohen Brothers film, without charm, dialogue, and interesting characters.  Perhaps the one redeeming quality of the film, in a meta sense, is that it was named parasite, as in parasite of my time and of anyone else's time who bothers watching it.  Worst movie I have ever seen in my life.

I loved the upstairs, half basement, and hidden basement element of class identity and mobility here. And the central conceit, of all the people in the film, who was more of a parasite? Visually rich.
Loved the screenplay
Nothing extraordinary and slow paced
Great idea, great performance, I like this sort of drama, I loved it.

Oh my god, this is a gore festival. A horror movie like Texas chainsaw massacre! After it had received received several academy awards i never expected this, i felt nauseated. the first 45 minutes were quite entertaining, but the movie as a whole is only for hardcore blood/horror lovers. i truly regret having gone to the cinema for this disaster!!!!

Parasite is an instant all time classic. Like "Breaking Bad" it is pretty much perfect in every way...script, casting, lighting, locations, makeup and hair, music. Will be all all time great lists for years to come. Most important, a movie like this helps the world get over itself as far as fear of subtitles is concerned. Think of the GREAT movies that will be opened up for the great American movie-loving public once they learn to tolerate subs! Perfect movie-making, it's a rare treat...enjoy!

Funny , real , and shocking. This is an edge of your seat drama rooted in the cold realities of poverty and the pride of those in the elite classes. A great depiction of foreign film since it covered so many genres in one sitting, even got to walk away with a moral and a new perspective on the dangers of good planning. If only this had a dub to it and if the theatre I saw it in did not lose power halfway through. Parasite was so good that I finished it at home online rather than abandon such phenomenal storytelling.

Kiddin' me? An oscar for this?
Reminded me of earlier HK movies. Lose ends, probably plot changes while filming..(fyi this was common with hk movies, changing plots overnight while filming).
First 30 to 40 minutes was completely predictable, boring (getting the driver and maid fired). I actually checked my phone while my wife was considering to leave. Then the shock/surprise in the basement. Really? We thought, okay this is it, oscar material coming up....
But the enthusiasm lasted for 32 seconds.
The old maid surely would be able to get in at midnight and get her husband out but she went through the front door expecting not to be caught by the new maid? Seriously????? Come'on!  
Then the whole social class bullshit. Really? This was a have vs have-nots? The scammers are incredibly well skilled, whether cooking or driving or arts class.
. 
Then the lose ends; the CCTV camera was pointed at the garage so Mr Kim the driver returning into the house after the killing should have been caught. Why was this ignored? Gonna get a sequel? 
Second lose end; how was the old maid killed? Kind of a big deal. Yep she fell on her head and then rambled on, but died? 
Third lose end; kid while camping sees the blinking light and deciphers the morse-code message. But nothing is done with it.
And then the biggest let-down. The underdog, the victim of social injustice, Mr Kim the driver, kills the loving father out of rage because he is told he smells badly? Looked down upon? Made fun of? Come'on. 
How are we, the public, supposed to buy that.
As to the final part of the movie. What a crap. Go in hiding for months (maybe even years is suggested)? No building plans of the cellar while the house is sold to ignorant Germans? Using a light Morse code to reach his son after months/years instead of going out at night while raiding the fridge getting the news out? 
.
I speculate the 90% score public approval score is related to the kind of viewers (most people won't go see, pay for, this kind of movie). 
If one would show this to a random batch of 100 people approval would be below 15% sure. 
BTW the wife is hot... wow!
On the edge of you seat, you will never look at a blinking light the same.
7/10 quirky and interesting

Parasite clings you from start to finish with not only a genius plot, but also incredible directing. Set up perfectly, the Kim family is able to convince not only the Park family, but also the audience as they deceivingly trick each and every one of them into a job. The movie's true accomplishment isn't the class driven acting, twisting plot, or metaphorical cinematography, but Joon Ho's effective cohesion of everything all while being able to communicate it across a foreign film.

The best movie of 2019 and one of the best of the decade. Despite an unoriginal premise, it excels on its execution, with bitting satire and social commentary, unexpected plot twists, impressive production design, and superb direction from Bong Joon-Ho. It serves as the perfect introduction to South Korean cinema.
Great portraying of the parasite that is infecting humanity - that is FEAR, the symptoms are - anger, greed, hate, jealousy and separation.
Good movie, I love it. This movie is really, really reality. Wonderfully acted and a great story. I really loved this movie for some reason...

A very nice example of ultra black humour blended with thriller elements and even social commentary. It's engaging, tight, suspenseful and very entertaining, from the very first till the last minute; with strong cast, many important and well developed supporting roles.
Super big plot twist. Almost an entirely different movie in the second half of the movie. Amazing !

BEST Movie 2019! I love how everything changes in this film. I won't spoil anything from parasites because everyone has to see it. The way the poor family infiltrates the big but still vulnerable family is fantastic. The spectacle is great and the plot twist in the middle and at the end is just one word to describe WOW
Very moody & dark. Good plot & ending. A disturbing glimpse into the cast system.
Didn't enjoy it for the same reason I don't enjoy Cohen Bro. movies.  Violence that stems from people's worst inclinations sickens me.
Great movie with a surprising ending.

I was suppose to see this back last year, but when I knew it wasn't in English, I really didn't want to go. After hearing about how good it was as a foreign film, I finally got the guts to see it in theaters in March. The whole movie is subtitled and you have to pay VERY close attention to what happens. If you miss a scene, then you can't follow up what comes next. This goes really in depth with the characters and what the Korean family is trying to do. Later on, it becomes suspenseful as the families encounter more trouble within the mansion. It was really well done and a pretty good drama. I still don't really get why some parts happen, I probably need to watch it again. I still think there should be an English Dub for this. Once they do that, I'll see it again. Reading for 2 hours really hurts my eyes. If you get a chance, give this a watch if you are in the mood for a foreign film.
A masterpiece! Everyone should see this movie!
Filled with amazing characters, beautiful cinematography, frightening moments, dark humor, and a timeless social message, Parasite succeeds on all counts.
A waste of time !  I have to ask myself ~ what were these High Ratings based upon ?  Apparently we all saw the same Movie ?  What I saw was a waste of time ! ! !

Its triumph at the Oscars didn't surprise me that much: this movie is simply amazing! You have to watch it at different times in order to get all its cryptic messages. Plot, storytelling, screenplay, shots, and dialogues need to be deeply studied. A flawless masterpiece from South Korea! Highly recommended!

My rating: 10/10

Expertly crafted, brilliantly acted, and inspiringly original, Parasite brings Bong joon-ho, Korean class disparity(which can be a little heavy handed sometimes), and international film to the mainstage. Every setup, every edit, is perfectly edited to establish a whirlwind of internal emotion. Hilarious, terrifying, thought provoking, this film is one of the must sees of the 21st century.

Great movie. It was fun! entertaining. Good plot and acting. A lot of drama and mystery. Funny at times. Although It exposes some social issues like inequality, it is not realistic but it is okay, it's just a movie. I think it is already a classic.

Oh boy... here we go again. A case of overhype blowing things WAY out of proportion. I mean, it's Bong Joon Ho, so it is pretty brilliant, as usual. But I wouldn't call it the revelation that people are making it out to be. That said, it's a highly entertaining little... mystery? comedy? It's a mishmash of different genres, handled really cleverly. I think the best thing is the heist movie hidden early on in the narrative.
Quite possibly the best movie I've seen to date.

This movie was the Oscar winner for the entire 2019 year?  First, it's subtitled (strike 1) 2nd, there are parts of them movie that bring to mind an old "I Love Lucy" episode!  3rd, there's a guy LIVING in your home you don't know about??  Come on, this plot is just too nutty.  This movie starts out good, but the plot becomes impossible to believe in.  Reading the text, gets old, and difficult to do, and still watch them movie.  NOT the best movie I saw in 2019!

Definitely a movie you cannot judge by just watching it once. During my first watch, I went "this is an enjoyable movie" but then--once I got to watch it the next time, I came to see all the metaphorical/visual symbols that Bong Joon Ho ever so masterfully put in the production of the movie. As a Korean speaker, I did not need the subtitles but if you do need them, watching the movie twice (or thrice lol) will help you understand the movie better, because during your first watch, you can focus on the subtitles and during your second, you can pay more attention to all the visual details of the movie. Superb movie indeed.

Yes, another five-star review, what's the surprise? This movie is better than I expected even I already have an extremely high expectation. Given my 50/50 chance to fall asleep during a movie, I didn't even blink as I was so immersed in the story and was anxious to see how things develop.
Everyone should watch this movie, at least once; I am planning to watch it the second time.
 
First of all, I love socioeconomic contrasting between the extremely rich and the extremely poor, every step of the way - their beliefs, day-to-day life, living environment, outfit, and how they treat others. For this low-income family, they even have to go to this very spot in their tiny restroom to get the free Wifi from an unknown neighbor, but they can be so happy for fighting this kind of thing. However, this wealthy family has so much that they even need a basement to store all of their kimchi. As a person who has lived in both Taiwan and the U.S., I feel like this dynamic is universal, not just applicable not just to South Korea. Given the worsening wealth gaps growing across the globe, the movie portraits something so real that it didn't feel like a comedy.
 
The acting is brilliant. All the actors are well-rounded, with great character developments progress as the story evolves. Especially for the son, his evolution was fascinating, from an insecure left-behind young man to feeling getting to something, then felt responsible for killing the maid for his family, even though that was against his will. The dad was incredible. He was willing to do anything for his family, even was humiliated by the boss and boss wife. Deep inside, his self-esteem was his last front-tier, and he couldn't stand people judging his "lower-class" smell.
It triggered all of his insecurities, and eventually, he killed the boss.
 
The scenery was magnificent. There is a contrast between their houses. This elevated mansion, extremely spacious space that everyone has its own space, neat and clean with elegant design. In the meantime, a tiny place next to sewage, with drunk people passing by and pissing all the time. When the water came, it almost feel like their meager existence was ever so fragile, and it is one flood away from being wiped out
 
The ending was great, though I felt that is somehow predictable. But I like how it was weaving the son's fantasy and reality. The metaphor appeared that the poor people couldn't have most of the things, but they can always dream of buying that huge mansion one day, and all of their problems are solved.
 
I highly recommend this movie, and I have no intelligent arguments to counter the hypes. For this movie, I am willing to succumb to the hype and being label as a bandwagoner. Yes, I watched this movie after they received the awards. But, I think this movie is well-deserved for its best picture, given its uniqueness, well-versed storytelling, fantastic acting, and directing. So don't wait, watch it, and let me know what you think!

In this dark comedy thriller, the Kims, a resourceful lower-class family swindle their way into employment within the home of the wealthy Park family. Rich with style and social commentary ‘Parasite' presents director Bong Joon-ho in complete control of his craft. 

The cinematography works subtly to convey the rising tension of the film with purposeful slow push-ins on the characters. Even if the audience doesn't at first notice this subtle movement, we subconsciously feel the pressure closing in on the Kim family and a sense of foreboding disaster as their con is at risk of collapse. The film is filled with deliberate long takes, the smooth camera movement shifts the shots creating new compositions and keeps the frame visually interesting without the need to cut. This helps to give more opportunity for characters to share the screen building on the visual representation of their relationships. These long moving shots also function as a method of emphasising the scale of the Parks' house and give the audience the chance to gain a well-constructed sense of the space which is symbolic of the Parks' vast wealth. 

The production design is immaculate and demonstrates a careful attention to detail, both the Park and Kim houses were sets constructed for the film and while they could not be more aesthetically dissimilar, they both feel equally believable. The locations of these two houses are also important, with a not so subtle metaphor the Kim family live down a street in a semi-basement dwelling while the Park house sits atop a hill. This vertical distancing represents both the separation of the families and their respective classes. Through this visualisation we understand that there are physical structures in place enforcing the separation of the classes, while the rich keep moving up, for the poor the uphill battle only gets harder. This idea translates in the story as setbacks for the Kim family negatively compound, forcing them into a downward spiral while the Parks' with their established forward momentum easily transform obstacles into positive opportunity. 

But the movie is more complex than ‘poor people good, rich people bad' each family possesses both good and bad traits showing a common humanity, aiming the critique towards the system rather than the people within it. The lower class can be viewed as infantilized by their idolisation of the rich, while the upper class may be considered child-like in their naivety towards the struggle of the less fortunate. The two sides of society romanticise aspects of the other, what then separates them is the ease with which the wealthy Park family can dip into that fantasy and return to their privilege while the Kim family are punished for their aspirations and attempt to embrace a more lavish lifestyle outside of their designated class. 

In ‘Parasite' Bong Joon-ho has carefully crafted a slick and evocative film that through excellent film technique conveys important social themes of the segregation of classes through the systematic structures of society. The film Resonated with audiences all while being insanely entertaining leading to a much-deserved Best Picture win.

I think this movie is brilliant, but quite tough to digest.

It is a contrast that shines through when the Kim's family, not really living in certain conditions, end up with great acting skills and pretentiousness behave as they are not.
How casually, but with a careful plotting, the two families create a dependency to each other is outlined in a very sophisticated matter.
The great message of the movie is delivered in the conclusive phase (which however lasted a little bit too long): for how much one can plan life is unpredictable and that seems to not be the lessons learned neither to the very bitter end, where roles have exchanged with some character and there is a wish for a life that is not what anyway the Kim's family could handle.
The tension is built up in the storytelling and when the bottom seems to have been reached there is always something coming up to shock and surprise the audience. 
I would have wished for a bit less misery, just to feel less uncomfortable about all the events that have been puzzling up to build the final acts.
Acting was powerful (as it implied acting of the characters as well) but what I loved most was how everything was filmed, with the lights and the shadows to underline the contrasts even more.

I'm giving it 1 1/2 stars for the intriguing and unpredictable plot twists and turns that kept you saying "WTF". In terms of intrigue, I think it got the job done well and quite honestly, very funny at times, then disturbing at times ... as I said, unpredictable, which I like. However, I don't think this was a 4 star or a 5-star film. With ongoing stigmatization and stereotypes of the lower class and the poor, I did not appreciate the way the poor were portrayed in this film; liars, cheaters, dishonest individuals who cannot make an honest living, who are incapable of challenging upper class intellectually and competing and even exceeding those standards. At first, when he started tutoring, I thought "wow, he's a got a chance to prove that he's even better than the wealthy kid" ... but no. It turns into deceitful games, plotting, lying, jeopardizing ... in short, really reaffirms the unfortunate stereotypes of the lower class or the poor, especially those who are the housekeepers full time. If anything, this film probably exacerbated the paranoia of the upper class to be on edge when it comes to hiring people or their current staff. Really distasteful. As someone who rose from the lower class through extreme work ethic, I can tell you, I don't appreciate these types of films one bit. The message of this film was beyond disturbing and tone-deaf; essentially sending a message that there is no hope for you, so the father makes matters worse by committing murder which then reaffirms the stereotype of the poor being dangerous and murderous. This film was all sorts of tone-deaf culturally. I feel that those who come from comfortable lives saw this film as some novel plot, maybe even think they were empathizing with the struggles of the poor by liking this film ... but as I mentioned, personally coming from poverty, the message and stereotyping were beyond f***ed up. If you didn't feel it, then you don't know what it's like to work your a** off to rise up and have to deal with BS stereotypes like in this film.

It seems that in the United States of America, nothing is original anymore. At least, that is what the assumption is. But, if one were to look outside the country, there exists a whole slew of original material just waiting to be watched. And look no further than the country of South Korea. That is where today's film "Parasite" is the definition of originality. Directed by Bong Joon-ho and co-Written by him, the movie is a cautionary modern allegory of the poor taking on the rich. But what makes "Parasite" truly stand out is that the movie is something us Americans need more than ever. It's all thanks to one little country all the way across the Pacific. From it's acting, direction, set and production design, to even the little details that require multiple viewings to get an accurate detail of what is going on. "Parasite" is one of those films that thrives on originality, and make the use of its country to a great maximum.

The story is a little complicated to explain; just keep in mind, that you have to experience the movie for yourself in order to understand it. But I'll try my best not to spoil the movie. The plot of the film involves a poor family living in South Korea trying to make ends meet. A friend of the son comes by and tells him that he works for a very rich family, and that he is going abroad. He asks the son to take over his job, to which the son accepts gratefully. Soon, the son gets his family into working for the rich people. But as this family learns, everything comes with a price...

"Parasite", like I said. Is one of those films that you just have to see for yourself in order to fully understand, but here's what I mean when you need to see this movie.

The setting is perfect for this film; it couldn't happen here in the United States, as it would impose as a difficulty within the context of the story. That and the cinematography are absolutely stunning. From the shifting weather of sunny to rain, the movie really looks good, and it is required to have it played out on the big screen, if possible.

On a technical level, "Parasite" excels in everything. From the lighting to the sound, everything is mixed and edited extremely well, as it is handled in a direction that fits the nature of the film itself. Top that with a minimalist orchestrated score, and you got yourself one amazing film to view.

However, there are two things that work in a grandiose manner for "Parasite".

First, the direction from Bong Joon-ho is absolutely stunning. From the blocking of actors, to the when the intense moments occur, including two very important scenes with the poor family trying to escape the rich family's house, and an intense thunderstorm, his direction is everywhere. It is simply the best. Bong Joon-ho is clearly starting to become one of the best directors of modern cinema, and "Parasite" clearly shows that this man has potential.

The most important aspect for this movie is the story. Cultures clashing, the importance of family, it's all here, and handled extremely well. Contrasting a run time of a little over two hours, the story grips the viewers attention on the edge of their seats, with jaws dropping and eyes wide open, the story is full of twists and turns that you will not see coming.

However, while the story is really good, and providing some inciting social commentary, there are some problems with it. For one thing, there are some plot holes and situations that don't make a whole lot of sense, and it seems like the poor family planned this in advance. But other than that, the movie itself is a damn solid piece of entertainment.

Overall, "Parasite" is a magnificent film that truly proves there is potential for originality to shine through. We just got to look for it.

My immediate reaction was more subdued than after the Oscars and I reflected on it. It definitely stands out.  Acting is brilliant.  Bong once again masterfully crafts a metaphor for his progressive views.  Keeps you guessing and pays it off in the end.  However, the twist in it is... not only unexpected, but almost ridiculously impossible, and it immediately turned a very intelligent, psychological thriller into something akin to allegory.  Furthermore, the extreme violence in the end, while common on Bong's movies, is out of touch with the rest of the movie.  Ultimately, its creative choices confused me.  Excellent movie I'd recommend, but some deep flaws.
A poor family deceiving the rich family they worked for.  Startling story plot with a lot of twists. Didn't expect a foreign film with English subtitles to be that GOOD!

Like Ang Lee, Bong Joon Ho is a director who shows mastery of his art without being show-offy. Parasite is both entertaining and is a relevant tale about class differences, without its message being hamfisted (it is nuanced, in fact, a rare trait in modern media).

This film more than deserved to win best picture. Parasite doesn't sacrifice an ounce of its wildly entertaining story or compelling characters for its in depth analysis of class struggles in our modern capitalist society. I've never seen a film that blends genres so perfectly. One minute you're in tears of laughter, the next your weeping out of fear and anxiety as to what horrific twist the film will take next. A perfect blend of subtly and obviousness allows the films hefty amount of symbolism to serve both the nail biting plot and the more than relevant point the filmmaker aims to make on class struggle and wealth. Bong Joon Ho has proved he is one of greatest filmmakers in the world with plenty of offer in upcoming years. There's no doubt that given the perfection we have seen in his latest, Best Picture Winning film, the world will be watching and anxiously waiting for what he creates next. What's more, the attention this Oscar winner has gardened will mean the west will be looking into the hidden gems of cinema we've missed in Korea and beyond.

The only real obstacles, to me, of this film is likely unfamiliarity of the actors and the subtitles.  Otherwise, this show is near perfect, snowballing the compelling tale of an unusually clever poor(some might say unmotivated)family taking advantage of a WAY too trusting rich family. Some might be bothered also by the moral murkiness this demonstrates(particularly toward the end)but that's it's genius: there really ARE no clear answers to instances of human frailty. There's LOTS of "wrong" here, but clear "right" may be harder to capture than one might(at least initially) think.

"Parasite" starts off as a light hearted, what seems to be comedic piece set in Seoul, Korea about a down-and-out family hooking up with an extremely well off family and then taking it to a level of 'grift' that is breathtaking. And just when you're wondering what will happen, the film just goes off the charts. Funny, suspenseful, endearing and sad, all while offering what is ultimately a biting commentary on the haves and the have-nots, not just in Korea, but in our class stratified world. Definitely a film to see - and an instance where the Oscars got it right.

Parasite
2020
15
Director: Bong Jun Ho
Starring: Kang ho song, Sun Kyun Lee, Yeo Jeong Jo, Woo sik choi, so damn park, Jeong Eun Lee, Hye jin jang, Ji so Jung etc

Overall rating 99/100


Parasite is based on a poor Korean family who thanks to their son tutoring a family's daughter con there way into a rich family's life but not everything is great as it seems. WOW what a movie, one of the best films and some of the best directing I have ever seen, so many good things to talk about here so let's get started here.

First of all, the performances and the Kim family were very interesting. Everyone's performances here was fantastic and I am surprised the actors are not getting more recognition here. Everyone did a very nuanced and excellent job at showing the cleverness of the characters and how far the characters will go not to get found out. I also found the Kim family very interesting. I loved how they were slowly one by one making their way into the house, and the whole family had completely different personalities which I also appreciated.

Next the film-built tension really well and used gore effectively. This film balanced so many tones well, but I think it balanced the tenseness very well. Due to being confined to the house for a large majority it was very claustrophobic for the characters. And some of the camerawork when the family was hiding was truly fantastic and made you feel tense in general but also for the characters involved. They also used gore very effectively as well. It wasn't overused but it didn't need to be, but it was used enough to leave an impact in the perfect way. They happened more out of nowhere which was excellently executed and very startling.

Next the films cinematography and set pieces were fantastic. Wow this film was an absolute feast for the eyes, whether it was the attention to detail through the camerawork or using normal props like peaches or tents in a completely different way this film was just so detailed and masterfully filmed it was insane to watch. The set pieces were also fantastic, I loved the deliberate sharp contrast between the rich and the poor house and both were explored very well, the poor house of the Kim's was extremely cramped and they gave you a good visual representation of what living in the slums would be like, but the contrast of the rich families house was fantastic, it had so many different components to it and each part of the house was explored well it was a great playground for some fantastic and cleverly put together scenes.

My next two positives would be the humour and the fantastic final act. Parasite had a fantastic comedic undertone to it that worked really well the dynamic between the Kim family really worked and they had some great comedic moments together that reminded me of my own family in places, similar to the gore it wasn't overused and I am glad it wasn't as otherwise the film wouldn't of worked as well but it was used enough to get a few good laughs out of me. I also have to commend Bong Jun Ho for a truly fantastic final act that was completely unexpected. I didn't know what was going to happen which was fantastic and left me wanting to know what happens next, and where they ended up going with the film took me by complete surprise but in the best way possible, huge respect for Bong for his masterful directing here.

My final two positives that really made the movie phenomenal was its exceptional script and deep and truthful themes about the class divide in today's society. Wow I think this film had the best script I have ever had the pleasure of hearing. The amount of amazing comments on society and clever ways to develop the characters I was in awe of the films cleverness. The films messages about the class conflict in today's society were so insightful it really made me stop and think which is what a good movie shall do. How the film portrayed the naivety of the upper class and how unaware they are of the struggles of the poor was excellent.  The ending was also showed the harsh brutality of where the poor is places in society and that is sadly underneath the rich which was really impactful for me I gave this film 99 only because it took me a fair amount of time to realise the true message of the film instead of straight away. But there was just so many little messages that were conveyed so well it really made you think.

Overall parasite is one of the best films I have ever seen, with masterful directing, cinematography, screenwriting and performances which leads to an exciting rollercoaster of a film that will leave you shocked and make you think more deeply about the state of the world class system.
It’s in my top 3 films of all time

in conclusion, this movie, Parasite () deserved every bit of recognition it got.

Parasite is a social realistic film that is multifaceted and ranges in use of heavy tone shifts and perfectly composed visual imagery, while simultaneously composed of heavy commentary on class division. Bong has the ability to fluidly create transformations within the characters themselves and their environments, having the calm housekeeper become a madwoman and a happy backyard celebration become a bloodbath.  Countering the opinions made by Rick Kisonak from the Vermont newspaper Seven Days, in which he claims that the movie makes no significant statements, I believe that the insight that this film offers does measure up to the grandeur it is receiving. Some in accordance with Kisonak may argue that referencing a social ill isn't the same as saying something insightful about it. However, I believe that the conversations that are being generated in response to the film surrounding social realism and its role in modern-day society are insightful in themselves. Kisonak is quick to assume that the Bong wants us to side with the poor, and as a result, believes that the commentary of the movie is condescending. Though there is ambiguity created from the fact that both families are set up so that you are not rooting for one over I find it extremely tasteful and it further enforces his theme that there are no bad guys here. It leaves room for the audience to ponder on who the real parasites are. Is it the poor who attach themselves to the rich in efforts to leech off their wealth? Is it the rich thrive who off the backs of the poor, and are unable to complete basic tasks without enlisting working-class servants to refine their lives? Or rather is it the system itself, the same system that thrives off the turbulence created by class division?

Bong Joon-ho delivers a unique, theme-ridden story rich with thought inspiring symbolism. Parasite is at its core, a comedic heist movie that evolves into a tragedy; a brilliant piece of satire that gives an insightful look into class struggle. The film delves deep into the modern human hunger for wealth, the relentless search for it, and how tunnel vision can bring out the worst in even the sanest of humans. What begins as the impoverished Kim family's light-hearted and comical attempt at inserting themselves into the wealthy Park family by providing various "high-end" services, upon revealing to the audience a dark secret unbeknownst to the Parks, then spirals into sadistic cataclysm unraveling the basest of human intents leading to a gory, terrifying conclusion. A stellar cast does a brilliant job of portraying the various personalities of both families, making the characters feel all the more believable. The core message Parasite conveys is obvious, as it is stated by one of the main characters. However, it is what lies beneath that message that Bong Joon-ho wants the audience to decipher, and this is done remarkably through the themes and symbolism alluding to those answers. Parasite is perhaps arguably one of the most important cinematic works of the decade, shedding light on countless societal issues that plague our time. It forces viewers to see class divide through the eyes of the Kim family in their pursuit of wealth and complete disregard for others, leaving a trail of despair that comes back to haunt them. Viewers should expect to walk away from the theatre with philosophical and psychological questions with difficult answers, and should inspire discussions about the human psyche. Expect Parasite to age very well, as it will serve future audiences by conveying relatable subject matter for many years to come, divulging to the viewer that to expect the unexpected is an absolute necessity if one is to survive.
Every cinephile needs to see this. It haunts the viewer for a long time afterwards, and is very important viewing, in our current political climate. Fair warning: It's very dark and disturbing.

The plot is amazing and extremely gripping with every twist and turn. Likewise, the way it tackles the social themes is so intriguing and done so extremely well even if the theme has been done many times before. The entire cast is amazing and honestly not even one of them getting a nomination for best acting is quite the robbery. Huge praise to Song Kang-ho and Park So-dam especially, they gave amazing performances. The cinematography/set design is also impressive and uniquely correlates with the ongoing story. The use of staircase and lines to tackle the ongoing theme, while not subtle, is done extremely well. The soundtrack, while not exactly memorable, manages to elevate the tense atmosphere and keep people on the edge of their seats. Finally, the film is absolutely entertaining with the way it incorporates contrasting genres, black comedy and thriller, into one surprisingly cohesive and exhilarating movie.

I didn't get what's so great about Parasite. It was messy and unrealistic. Kept hoping for something of a clue about what it was all about, but that never came. Instead it was one unrealistic thing after another.
One moment they have no wifi, then they find wifi in a remote spot of the house, and all of a sudden this wifi signal is everywhere in the house.
The family ofcourse needed to be unrealistic gullible for the plot to work. This essential element of the plot is what ultimately makes it a bad movie. None of this has even a remote chance of happening in real life because of it.
Or more towards the end: The family not noticing the mess their staff made, or them hiding under their table. The former housekeeper not dying from braking her neck. Or her allergic reaction to such a small amount of peach skin.
During the finale: The father going to the basement with no regard to his son who is bleeding out on the floor, and the letter he writes in morse code without knowing if someone would read it. The recovered son climbing up a hill for no reason, and the ending that never happened.
I have no idea why this plothole bonanza received multiple Oscars.

Film critics such as Brian Tallerico and Norman Wilner consider Parasite (Gisaengchung) the best film of the year. With a sequence that resembles the beginning of Scola's Ugly, Dirty and Bad (Brutti, sporchi e cattivi, 1976), Bong Joon Ho transport us into a world that unfolds the social tensions between the poor and the wealthy.  A black comedy takes place, touching the viewer's most secret fears about globalization: the upheaval of the poorest, yet capable immigrants, against their privileged, yet overconfident, masters. As in Kafka's novels, the hyperreality of the fable supersedes the metaphor in order to create its own universe.  The absurdity of the plot is compensated with our will to believe on it.  A father, a mother and their children–son and daughter, stage a series of scams in order to become servants of a wealthy family.  Their reward is awkwardly naïve: the possibility of becoming masters of the house when their masters are not at home.

cXoFTolA

Parasite starts in a basement, a clear allusion to Almodóvar's High Heels (Tacones Lejanos, 1991). All the members of the family are unemployed. They appeared to be crooked, but their crookedness doesn't go beyond stealing their neighbor's WIFI signal. All the conventions of reality are broken and we are introduced into a metaphorical universe. The basement is part of a building in no-one's land, or in the poorest slums of most third-world countries, from Haiti to Bangladesh, from Sudan to Vietnam. A family of capable, and yet frustrated professionals, are obliged to accept the first opportunity to "travel" to another community thanks to an unexpected recommendation. Their social status becomes a real problem. After all, they are the outcasts of the earth; so, they are obliged to falsify their son's documents. The social status of a professional without a degree is, indeed, not very different from that of an immigrant without a working visa. But before getting his coveted job, the son should present his documentation to customs. The appointment of Sun-Kyun Lee with Yeo-jeong Jo could have taken place in any customs office of the world. Yeo-jeong dismisses the documents as unimportant, for they appear to be authentic. To insist on the protocols of a world divided by stamps may seem rude for such an aristocratic lady. Woo-sik gets his job and, by pushing one of the most sensitive topics of immigration, tries to seduce the youngest girl of the family.

Still, not happy with the benefits of his new job, Woo-sik conspires to move all the members of his family into his new adoptive home. His sister gets soon a vacant job as a tutor. But they also want to bring their parents, so they plot against the chauffeur and the maiden of the house. They both get fired. Almost immediately the unfortunate locals are replaced by Mr. and Ms. Kim. The story appears to end there. How brief happy endings are. We are fate to witness the furious reaction of the locals.

From immemorial times, natives have resented the presence of immigrants in their communities. It's believed that they rob their jobs and that they seduce their women. Quite often, enraged and, needless to write, intolerant mobs, decide to correct such "abuses", so they attack and kill innocent men, women and children. In Joon-ho's celebrated film all this happens. The second part of the film is a battle between the immigrants and the locals for the privileged of serving the wealthy. But the wealthy are not exempt of guilt.  After all, they have created the social conditions for a struggle that conveys a scant reward. In the final scenes of the film, the revolt of the servants becomes a revolution. A Native-American tent is set up in a children's party as a sinister reminder of the triumph of a group of immigrants over the locals. In Parasite, it's a failed revolution. After all, revolutions today are only allowed in third-world countries. At the end, all immigrants pay for their crimes. They learnt the hard way. They are obliged to accept that ceaseless work and study are the only possible ways to success.

A parable on Immigration, but also a warning on the social conditions of globalization, where a global revolt appears to be just around the corner.

Bucaramanga, September 16, 2019

For a movie to be hyped to death and then still meet expectations is impressive. And yet, Parasite didn't just meet my expectations, it surpassed them. 

Anyone who knows me will tell you that I never read reviews before watching a movie; I'll only read them after. I always preach about the benefits of knowing little about a movie before seeing it. I think Parasite is a case in point: a movie enjoyed most thoroughly when the viewer has little pre-existing knowledge about it. 

What makes Bong Joon-ho's latest feature so exciting is its unpredictability. It has a surprising narrative structure. Think of Parasite, if you will, as a train journey, with Bong the chief architect and the driver. The train doesn't arrive at the expected end destination, and the journey to the final stop is wildly unpredictable. The tonal landscape of the movie shifts as Parasite moves throughout its course. Social realism gives way to surreal horror, by way of jet-black humour and sometimes farce. For our train journey metaphor, think of these tonal changes as the volatile weather outside the window. And despite the unpredictable nature of the journey, the driver always maintains complete control of all. 

Okay, excuse the rough metaphor, but it seems apposite to include one in a review of a film whose director's metier is metaphors. In fact, in what seems like a self-mocking act from Bong, characters in the film often comment several times on how metaphorical things are. The movie is, too, full of symbolism: the rain and different levels being two noteworthy ones. The film is so packed with symbols and metaphors, it makes watching it so fascinating. 

The sociopolitical import of Parasite is clear, highlighting the disparity between South Korea's classes, and taking aim at late capitalism. The politics works because its central message is delivered through humour and horror (in equal measure), instead of prosaically, as with many other films. Metaphors are the tool Bong uses oftentimes to highlight the differential lives of the rich and the poor families. For instance, the rain that comes down towards the end of the movie flooding the entire house of the Kim family fails to penetrate the Park child's tent. At times in the latter half of the movie, Bong perhaps suffers from a lack of subtlety, laying the message on too thick - for example, with the rich family holding their noses when the Kim father is nearby. But Parasite's lack of subtlety is a justifiable and possibly inevitable consequence of a movie that is this bold. 

Hony Kyung-pyo's cinematography expertly captures the starkly different milieus of the two families. The Kim's semi-basement is claustrophobic and restrictive and the Park's mansion is vast and airy. I also think the shooting of the impressive flood scenes at the end of the movie deserves to be hugely commended. It is a film of impressive and important technical ability - something that I didn't expect.

There's one moment on which the movie pivots: a moment that takes the film into a place you don't foresee it going.  As the camera rushes through the black space into the basement, music reaching a crescendo, everything becomes impossibly tense. And then, moments later, the viewer begins to realise gradually what's happening. It is one of the most exciting and astounding things I've ever witnessed in the cinema.

Parasite is absolutely one of the year's best. It's an incredible, shockingly bold piece of film-making that is both a mainstream crowd-pleaser and an art-house wonder.

My highest rated film coming out of 2019, Parasite toes the line between thriller, horror, and suspense while offering social commentary that is just enough in your face to not come off as pedantic. I was going to wait to watch the film, but after realizing how many Academy Awards it was up for, I decided to give it a watch the Saturday night before the Oscars: it was the best cinematic decision I made all year. The Kim family is a sinister bunch who you root for even when you shouldn't. I could list off each character/actor, but I'll save time and just say there wasn't a weak performance among them: each played a role, each nailed the role. Symbolism abounds, as the Kims survive (I choose this word deliberately) in a subterranean lair where they have to contend with neighborhood fumigation, micturating drunkards, and typhoon floodwaters, which eventually turn their lives into a literal world of shit. The Park family, on the other hand, lives in a modern oasis that feels like it was dropped into Seoul from outer space — with plenty of lawn and garage space, I should add. The symbolism is most apparent when the help — old and new — are battling to the death in the mansion's soundproof basement while the Park family lives in ignorant bliss upstairs. The only part of the movie I wanted more clarification on was how Kim Ki-Jeong (Park So-dam) was able to control Park Da-song (Jung Hyeon-jun) from being a tornado of energy. They never really show any techniques or power (abuse) she uses to keep the child in line. You're reading this after the Oscars, so you don't need a reason to root for Bong (go watch his acceptance speeches if you haven't already), but Parasite is a must-watch that could've easily kept me engaged for another hour or two.

An uncategorisable masterpiece

What is one to make of the utterly uncategorisable and impossible-to-define Parasite? Part comedy of manners, part social satire, part heist film, part thriller, part horror, part family drama, part farce, part economic treatise, part social realism, part tragedy, part allegory. What is certain is that it's exceptional in just about every way – screenplay (co-written by director Bong Joon-ho and Han Jin-won), directing, cinematography, mise en scène, editing, production design, sound design, score, acting. There's not a weak link here, in a film that achieves that rarest of things – it lives up to the hype.

The Kim family are down on their luck. Father Ki-taek (Song Kang-ho), mother Chung-sook (Chang Hyae-jin), daughter Ki-jeong (Park So-dam), and son Ki-woo (Choi Woo-shik) reside in a tiny basement apartment eking out a meagre living folding pizza boxes. However, their fortunes change when Ki-Woo bluffs his way into working as an English tutor for the daughter of the wealthy Park family. Father Dong-ik, (Lee Sun-kyun), mother Yeon-gyo (Cho Yeo-jeong), daughter Da-hye (Jung Ji-so), and son Da-song (Jung Hyeon-jun) welcome Ki-woo into their home, and upon discovering just how wealthy the Parks are, the Kims hatch an elaborate scheme to oust the Park's current domestic staff and take their places. However, it doesn't take long before things start to go very, very awry for both families.

As thoroughly entertaining (and funny) as Parasite is, it remains an economic treatise, albeit with a savagely satirical quality. This is far from the first time Bong has dealt with issues of class, but never before has he been this caustic and acerbic, but so too compassionate and witty. One of the most deftly-handled elements of the film is his avoidance of the clichés one so often finds in films dealing with economics – the Kims are by no means a victimised family immediately worthy of sympathy, whilst the Parks are by no means a callous family immediately worthy of scorn. Rather, the Parks are depicted as perfectly friendly and pleasant whilst the Kims are shown to be liars and scoundrels.

Bong is uninterested in trucking in heroes and villains because such rigid diametrics aren't the norm in the real world. For all their scheming and lying, the Kims merely con their way into menial jobs, whilst the Parks' greatest crime is allowing their wealth to insulate them from the world of families such as the Kims. At the same time, the Kims are depicted as a far more loving family than the Parks. Although all four Kims often occupy the same frame, we never see the four Parks together in the same shot. Important here is the title. A simple reading is that the Kims are the parasites and the Parks are the hosts, with the Kims feeding off the Parks' wealth and status. However, Bong depicts the Parks as parasitic as well, feeding off of the labour of their servants. Just as the Kims feed off the Parks, the Parks feed off the Kims, in what is a symbiotic relationship.

Aesthetically, Hong Kyung-pyo's cinematography is magnificent. Hong also shot the superb Beoning (2018), and the camerawork here has a similar smoothness and restlessness, gliding through the Parks' house like it's a fifth member of the Kim family. Lee Ha-jun's production design is also praise-worthy, with the Kims' cluttered and dilapidated apartment contrasted with the Parks' pristine post-modernist semi-open plan house.

It's also in relation to production design wherein one of the film's best metaphors is to be found. As a story at least partly in the tradition of the "upstairs/downstairs" subgenre, Bong literalises the separation between those above and those below by using stairways as a recurring motif. The Kims' apartment has no stairs, indicating their inability to rise socio-economically. On the other hand, the Parks' home has two stairways – one going up to the bedrooms where the four children spend an increasing amount of time, cut off from their parents, and one going down into the cellar. Bong shoots this stairway like he's suddenly directing a horror film, bestowing upon it an ominousness that, at first, makes little sense, but ultimately reveals itself to be a spectacular bit of foreshadowing.

Parasite is a masterpiece, with Bong never putting a foot wrong. It could have been a self-serving and didactic message-movie – a homily to the honour of the poor or a deconstruction of the unhappiness of the rich – but Bong is far too talented for that, avoiding rhetorical cant. Quite unlike anything I've ever seen, it works as allegory just as well as it works as social realism just as well as it works as comedy just as well as it works as tragedy and so on. This is cinema as art, a film which has proven itself very much a game-changer and completely deserving of every bit of praise it's received.

After watching the Oscars and seeing that this film won 4 Oscars including Best Picture, I knew I had to watch this film. Not only did Bong Joon-ho make history, but he also created a MASTERPIECE that will become a cult classic around the world without a doubt. This film is so beautiful but eerie and strange at the same time, I loved every minute of this film, the directing was superb, the cast were all phenomenal, everything about this film is so good. The plot isn't an original plot because there's a lot of films that depict society and depict what the lower class will do to survive but the way it handles those topics is original and it works so well, this film isn't just about society and classes, it's about how some lower classes are different to one another, one lower class family can be greedy and selfish whereas the other lower class family can be grateful and understanding, in some scenes, the inequality of the higher and lower classes are demonstrated very well. There is absolutely nothing wrong with this film and I can't think of a single negative thing because this film is perfect. Overall, this film is one of the best films I've seen in a cinema, it is a must watch and I highly recommend this film to anyone who is 15 or over.

B movie with glaring plot holes.  


A lower class family worms their way into the lives of a rich family, leaving destruction in their wake.  The overall themes of class struggle and injustice may excite some; but this is a dreary, frustrating tale of annoying manipulation of a trusting and loving upper class family.  It completely falls apart by the time it reaches its bloody conclusion.  This movie does boast one great scene - The Flood.  That spectacle alone might justify the time spent watching this movie.


Spoiler Alert: Don't read further if you haven't seen the movie.


The Plot Holes/Give me a Break Moments 

1. There's no way a family that can't fold pizza boxes would have the skills to pull of their deception.  (See 4, below.)
2. What homeowner is unaware of their bomb shelter?  Especially since such shelters are common in South Korea.
3. The son could speak fluent English; why can't he get a real job?
4. If the daughter is clever enough to pose as a skilled art teacher who graduated from the University of Chicago, why can't she figure out how to fold that damn pizza box? 
5. What homeowner doesn't run a basic background check on their prospective household help?
6. The rich couple makes love on the couch while the poor family - the entire clan - hides under the nearby coffee table.  Yeah, right.
7. Wouldn't most moviegoers feel sympathetic towards the rich gaslit family and their original staff, thus feeling disgusted and depressed at the way the movie ends?


Big Spoiler Alert - The killer goes free.  Yuck.

"Parasite" poignantly captures the insurmountable strife between the higher and lower worlds—the moneyed class and the downtrodden. But Bong truly revolutionizes the stairway genre by adding another vertical level to the equation. At the end of Act II, the bottom drops out—narratively and literally—and "Parasite" mutates into something greater. A story about two families, the upstairs and the downstairs, reveals something else lurking beneath.

With Bong as head maestro, "Parasite" is a film as technically accomplished as it is fascinating narratively, a real rarity. Bong has demonstrated he is a master of his craft, as well as the rhythm and tempo in which he chooses to tell his stories. From the camera movement, editing, and music, "Parasite" is akin to riding a frantic wave of story. The result of Bong's meticulous attention to rhythm and finely-tuned tempo is a totally immersive viewing experience. The montage at the end of Act I distills Bong's mastery as a filmmaker and storyteller into an economical sequence of about 60 shots in almost exactly 5 minutes—mesmerically paced with Hitchcockian conciseness.

Bong Joon Ho's "Parasite" is perfectly crafted and eerily topical.

Solid movie. Very relatable characters who made you think about your own situation, whether it be from the struggling underclass or the white collar upper class. The directorial work was good, as they often veered away from obvious plot decisions, while leaving the tension there. I appreciated the use of the water theme and being caught, as well as the lightning of judgement. It was funny that they even called out the ominousness of the lightning, and that the lightning was purposefully not quite perfectly timed, a little more realistic.

There were a few movie gimmes, like the rich family arriving in a few minutes just after a fight. But overall, the movie did its best to maintain realistic plausibility. The violence seemed fairly realistic, with not an excess of gore or blood. The parts about the poor family feeling trapped while having to deal with the rich family's excesses with tacit acceptance was definitely heightened as the movie went on. While the initial benefits of a good job gave them much gratitude, the family's attitude seemed to wane after realizing what they had to deal with to get there. 

Would rewatch this again, just to catch more of the themes.

We watched the recent Oscar-winning film Parasite, and although I am usually unimpressed with the Academys choices, this one is an exception. I could not stop thinking about it all day yesterday, and am still reviewing its implications in my mind. It was thoughtful, insightful, and well written and acted. It was eye-opening in so many ways a true morality tale, not only in the way all of the characters actions were rewarded, but also in the overall tone and story: you are meant to go away and THINK. Although it is set in another country and filmed in a foreign language, the fascinating thing about it was how universal the theme was. I cannot recommend it enough.

Based off the title I thought their would be some crazy epidemic like boon jong hos other movie the host but nope . Just social commentary calling the parasite s poor people which is really clever. This movie is pretty clever in that way and entertaining at times. To get to the good part of the movie it took a good 25 30 minutes. What I mean is the good part is when Kevin is at the house. The acting is amazing. I’ve never seen a foreign movie to make me interested in the acting. Cause reading subtitles is kinda rough, I know first world problems but still. I know people that will agree with me. Anyway it may seem that I’m hating on this movie but it’s very entertaining but would I ever see this movie again, probably not. Maybe if my friend wants to see it for a first time but besides that I’ll just stick to the TV show. Hopefully it’s better.
