The characters were like empty shells. All of them. The only ones I liked were the family dogs. The poor family was a lot more despicable than the rich family. Which made me feel sorry for the rich family. The poor family were wretched to the point I really didn't care what happened to them. I've had to deal with callous selfish people in real life and it meant nothing to see them on the screen. 

The more I think back on this move the more I find it distasteful on so many levels. Even the "funny" parts were unimaginative. Like when the girl sat on the toilet lid as it regurgitated effluence into the house. It wasn't funny. 

Predictable and frustratingly anticlimactic in so many ways.

I liked the movie, it is thriller and when you think that the family would do one thing, something else completely happens. I do not like the ending of the movie, a bit confusing at first but eventually it came together.

It was the most riveting movie I have ever seen.  No one on my row moved a muscle during the last half of the movie.  I am glad I had already eaten my popcorn and drank my diet coke before then, or I couldn't have.  The first half is funny, light-hearted, then it quickly becomes deadly for the fun family.   Don't miss it.
I love Hitchcock type movies and this was a really great one in that sense!
Wonderful glimpse into Korean society.  Gorgeous film.

no spoiler alerts required, I'll steer well clear of the plot. I was apprehensive prior to seeing this movie as 1) I'm not a major fan of foreign films with subtitles (why not not dub?... is my uncultured view) and 2) Having watched the dreadful Roma on the back of its Oscar success last year, I wasn't optimistic. How wrong can you be? Yes, even me. Despite all my preconceptions and having quickly overcome my adversity to subtitles, I really enjoyed Parasite. I had little idea of what to expect, having managed to avoid any spoilers and can confirm, it really is a film to go and see without prior expectations...I'm saying no more, as some people do still talk to me at the moment. Will it be as enjoyable on second viewing? ...I'll have to wait for the DVD release...oh, and I still think dubbing beats subtitles.
Liked the beginning.  The ending left me kinda...  dunno
Obsessed with this, the story, the twist! how it quickly got dark! great film.

Long awaited film for me as Bong never seem to fail. A family, a mom, dad and two grown kids are living in a stinky basement. They do everything to cheat some money out of people and are quite good at it. When they get hold of an opertunity to manifest a mantion with filthy rich people they surely does it. First one family member, then the next and the next one after that. They infest this home - in very clever ways - with different jobs - acting as professionals. Surely this must stay a secret, but that's not an easy task.

This is a very inspiring story and a film that covers most genres. It has a funny undertone, it can be dramatic and even scary at times. Later it shifts into something more dramatic. It looks magnificent and that house that most of the scenes are taken from looks amazing. Good acting, great characters and a very cleverly moving film - directorial wise. 

After the credits faded in it understood how much this film reminded me of a favorite of mine, "Borgman". That is a weirder and a bit more narrow film, but I kind of like that one even better. This is by no means a bad film, though - it's fantastic, actually! Probably on my top three from Bong and once again he lived up to my high expectations.

9 out of 10 pizzaboxes.

Really enjoyed this movie - Throughout the film you find yourself looking for reasons to cheer for or against the characters in the story as they reveal more about themselves. The messages that the writers and directors wanted to drive home are perfectly woven throughout the entire movie.
Great story. I didn't totally comprehend why the poor father did to the rich father toward the end of the movie.
Pretty special really. Does things with a film you would not even have imagined were possible.
Great characters and story line.

The Kim family live a pretty basic existence in an apartment basement until a friend of the teenage son Ki-woo offers him the opportunity to tutor the daughter of the wealthy Park family.  Soon his sister is also working as a tutor, this time for their younger son.  The siblings them manipulate the household so their mother and father also find work with the Park family as housekeeper and driver and so begins the symbiotic relationship between the two families as the Kims provide the Parks with all of the services they need and the Parks pay for the Kims' entire existence. However, there are secrets that are long hidden in the household, secrets if unleashed will bring both family's worlds crashing down around them which will eventually lead to a chaotic and brutal ending for both households. 
Parasite was a really good film and is unlikely to be unlike anything else you have seen (until the inevitable remake turns up!).  It's funny, dark and twisted.  It's one of those films that will leave a lasting impression on you  and I can guarantee you'll be thinking about it for some days after.  Really well cast and acted with a very unique story.  Would certainly watch again.
Started off really good and then everything happened way too fast. I was not ready for that. Seemed very rushed at the end
Wow. What a movie keeps you drawn in the the entire time. This director knows what he is doing. This movie was excellently crafted and is one the most well made films I've seen in a while.
I liked it all.... even the reading. Great movie!
Despite being the best picture winner, it was unusual

This movie is an experience that truly has you thinking about the classes of society. The director truly creates tension is scenes which should bear no emotional weight, yet somehow still managed to have me on the edge of my seat. Overall nearly a perfect movie.
Great plot kept you on your toes
Takes a while to get going, but when it does... wow!
Just so you know its not a movie about insects sucking your blood. Its a twisted tale of humans sucking money out of rich people. I enjoyed the movie but I dont think I would watch it again.

The performances, art direction, set design and cinematography were first rate. That said the first half was interesting and entertaining, the second half totally "jumped the shark" and the ending was a desperate reach to achieve a dramatic climax but fell flat on the obviousness and absurdity rendering the entire work a miss. Whatever it was trying to "say" aside from a routine illustration of abject nihilism escapes me entirely. The fawning is remarkable if not nauseating.

Interesting plot with some weird twists and turns. It’s a different kind of movie than anything I had ever seen before. The comedy is definitely present, but it’s also a good example of the disparity between the upper one percent and those living in poverty.
Comment on class division was clear but situation was a bit too hard to believe.
Just not my kind of movie. Enjoyed the first half of this dark comedy but the rest of the movie was just dark.
Great plot, great characterisation, well shot, an absolute must see!
Great acting, Very good story which was left unresolved so we can consider an ending.
Excellent movie! The plot, the cinematography, everything!
I understand the lack of social mobility, but it is too unrealistic.

A wonderful movie for the thinking man/woman.  The story was thought provoking and the acting superb.  Unlike 'Hollywood' I can actually appreciate the message that this movie conveys.  It offers you a taste of classism as opposed to forcing feminism down your throat.  Maybe foreign films are the future.
Surreal and kind of horrifying.  Not a "best" picture in my opinion.
An inventive, creative story which made you think on several different levels.

I liked this movie, but didnt love it. First, the classes were so extremely different. The people were either living in completely dumpy apartments or in high tech mansions. The cast was good, but I didnt learn to love or hate any of the actors. The movie wasnt predictable. I really enjoyed that and gave it a higher rating.
Meh. Its OK but nothing special. Clearly it was leftist political pick for Oscar.

A two part sardonic movie with the most perfect 60 shot montage in the midst of the film that crescendoes the exhilaration built from the beginning. This montage also give way to the genre changing twist that comes after. A generic masterpiece that mirrors the realities of todays' society.

The first couple of acts were fun even though a predictable rich vs. poor trope.  But I had a bad taste in my mouth seeing that the poor were ultimately being treated as the "troublemakers".  I completely disagree that the this was a agnostic look at the two polarized classes.  The family who fraudulently took an opportunity and blew it in an orgy of self-satisfaction and cynicism was the family who was down and out.  And the so-called "twist" in the third act  soon became completely over-the-top and unbelievable.  Why would they want to call the cops on these people living in the bunker?  And vice-versa.  These motivation made no sense.  Why was there such a struggle?  The former caretaker was completely unaware of how she lost her job -- even after the so-called reveal.  And it went from bad to worse.  One character get's his head bashed in twice (and yet survives without too much health consequences) . Indeed, the last act was a complete muddled mess -- which ended up summarizes this movie well.   You're left scratching your head as to what does this all mean?  It ended on an utterly confusing spin of a moral compass which sorta made the disadvantaged in capitalism look like the deranged immoral bad guys.
This was an interesting movie to watch, but I do feel that it's a bit over-hyped.

Loved this movie!
Highly recommended, It will make you laugh,and  it's got a few parts on the film that will scare you .overall a great movie to watch.

I went in cold and came out shivering! Not out of fear, of course, but in shock. My ticket was too cheap of the production and for the plot of this movie but I am so grateful to watch this without having any prejudice in mind (stop debunking this movie because there are no dubs!!!) As Bong Joon-Ho mentioned, "If you can get overcome the 1-inch barrier of subtitles, there will discover so many more great films."
Lived up to hype. Lots to unpack here.
Brilliantly written acting in some areas fell short. But Park was stellar. Definitely worth watching again.
I can see why it swept the Oscars now

How the rich devalue the poor? By commenting privately to your spouse that a person has an odor? Or not wanting a person you hire to #?%* someone in your car.? News flash, the ‘poor’ in this movie were saying worse things about the rich than the rich ever said about them. And being poor doesn’t mean evil and criminal. I was poor growing up, now I’m rich, but I always had morals. The ‘poor ‘ in this film had almost no morals, they lied and plotted and destroyed ‘poor’ but good people and that is the number one reason that they were poor in the first place.
Was on the edge of my seat throughout most of the movie. Was so good, definitely deserved the Oscar for Best Picture.

I'm really struggling to understand the overwhelmingly positive-rating appeal of this film.  No characters to identify with, a tired "poor versus rich" theme, unrealistic motivation for having included scenes of splatter and gore.  Give me "Trouble in Paradise, "My Man Godfrey, and "Treasure of Sierra Madre." These classic "poor versus rich" films had characters, while "Parasite" had leeches.
It starts off as a comedy, but, it ends as a bloody tragedy. I don't think it should have won the Best Picture Oscar.
You have to see this movie, not once but twice!
Best movie I have seen in a few years.

It was totally entertaining!     Funny, heartwarming, engaging, refreshing, and totally caught me unprepared for the way it ended.   Loved it from start to finish.   That's what a movie is supposed to be.   Will look forward to seeing it again soon.
A masterpiece, perfect from beginning to end.
Best movie I've seen in a long time. Couldn't guess anything - didn't look at watch once. Bravo

I'm not sure what everyone else watched or what they were on when watching it. I however was sober and saw an entertaining movie but in no way did it deserve "Best Picture". I'm assuming the critics loved it so much because they're probably rich and think "this could happen to me and my rich family"? Or "yep poor people are all criminal bottom feeders out to get the rich". Anyways it's worth a one time watch but that's it.
LOVED it! To say anything more would be a disservice to those who haven't seen it, but I strongly recommend watching this film.
Liked the premise- original! But what was an intriguing start eventually became pretty outlandish. It wasnt boring - just didnt live up to the movies beginning. Definitely not Oscar worthy.
The movie is absolutely phenomenal!! Must watch!

Wow.  Just set through it.   Seriously,  this is supposed to be better than the Irishman and 1917.   Somebody is trying way to hard to vote to make a statement.    Very predictable.  Was disappointed.
Funny and tragic, great acting and directing, fantastic cinematography. I enjoyed this more than any movie I can remember seeing in the last several years :-)
Dont understand what the hype is about. Korean version of Shameless
A must see film suspense,humor,and a look into the rich and the poor
Very interesting and keeps you engaged, just gotta read your way through it!
Although at times a little gory, the twists and turns of this movie and the message about how the rich devalue the poor makes for a very thought provoking movie.
Cinematography was good..storyline was good..didnt like the Tarantinoesque ending and length
This movie had everything. A statement on social classes, drama, humor and catch your breath moments.

Wow! Yes subtitles, but what story! From the nearly homeless living in muti-generational hallway rooms below the sewer lines to ultra wealthy in fortresses above. A story of survival, thriving in the city jungle. From those that have success, to those living like the stinkbugs that infiltrate the basement houses. Parasite is ....
A horrifying and awe-inspiring representation of the relationship between the lower and higher classes, this masterpiece is a must-watch for everyone.

This movie was way too violent for me. I feel like I got tricked into seeing violence that I really didn't want to see. This movie was mildly amusing until it became horrifying, and I barely got any message out of it. So overall, it was an unpleasant waste of my time.

As we were leaving the theater, we both said, "Crazy Movie" at the same time as another person in the parking lot. It was a wild and crazy movie for sure. Didn't expect it to end the way it did. It is funny at times and weird and there is a bit of violence. Not for everyone.
Silly history. I don't know why got too many Oscars...
Phenomenal. An incredibly original story. Rich, layered, fascinating, and twisted. Loved it.
Fantastic! Do not miss this movie,you cannot take your eyes of the screen
Everything about this movie was bad,  the script,  the story, terrible.

I went into this movie nearly completely blind with a friend of mine a few days after this came out in Australia, long before the movies hype train began. I had no expectations in the slightest, with the only information I had about the movie being the trailer. I know absolutely nothing about this movie. I left beyond changed. This is the best movie I've seen. It's witty and hilarious, with brilliant cinematography and direction, as well as some of the most underrated acting in cinema. 5/5
Not your usual movie topic. Well done!
Best movie I've seen in a while
One of the best movies Ive ever seen. Its complex, haunting and breathtaking. I cant stop thinking about this movie.
Very creative unpredictable plot centered on social commentary
Good acting, but didn't enjoy the violence ... guess you can't make a film anymore without it, I suppose that's just the world we live in. Left the movie feeling depressed.
Marvelous story telling, insightful social commentary as well as conveying our common humanity                  Was deserved the best picture award
Way overrated. Amateur plot and screen play. The academy awards are phony giving this best picture.

Wow! Brilliant yet with some fragmented story lines. Very funny and then alarmingly dark. Found the violence and over the top change in storyline in the last 1/4 of the film difficult to watch and really disliked it. After, I wish I had not watched this film. Very difficult to rate. I guess I am tired of all the violence. So glad though to see a movie made in South Korea come to the mainstream theater here.
One of the best movies I’ve seen in a very long time. Very clever, when it got dark it got dark quick!
Got so caught up in the story didn’t mind the subtitles. Loved the movie
It is absolutely outstanding! A truly masterpiece.
This movie was interesting but strange.  It was all in subtitles and end was crazy!  I'm just not sure how I feel about this movie.

very original masterpiece. we plan on seeing it again because I'm sure we've missed some things. it's funny that I just read a couple negative reviews from the people that didn't like it because of the subtitles (poor reading skills).
Great Plot. Lots of twists!
Very intriguing. Beautifully shot. Great story line. Definitely messed with your mind a bit. I recommend it!
very creative story, well written.

while the movie was well made, the topic was very dark and I did not find that  the characters had any redeeming value.  I should have just walked out than torture myself to find out the ending. I have no idea how this won the Academy Award for Best Picture.  Winning such an award is the huge joke.  The best picture in 2019 was Green Book and that film was fantastic.  Comparatively,  Parasite was horrible and a complete waste of my time.

Slow to start, unoriginal and saying little, this movie confuses being quirky with being brilliant. The violent ending doesn't fit with the mood of the rest of the film, and simply isn't that clever. After more than two hours of shallow dialog and abuse of the word "metaphorical," a bloody rampage ensues, culminating in one of the lead characters killing his rich boss because the boss called him "smelly." Hailed by many, including the Academy, as the best film of 2019, I am forced to wonder whether standards have fallen dramatically, or 2019 was an abysmal year for films. Thinking back on this film, I suspect both statements are true.
Dark comedy with lots of twists and laughs.
Suspenseful to the end.
It was very interesting!
After not being able to follow story line early I began to understand the movie and felt it was compelling. Gave my wife and I a lot to discuss afterwards.

When I look back at previous winners for Best Picture, 2001-2011 I thoroughly enjoyed all of the winners. Since then, 2012-2020, Ive probably enjoyed 1 out of every 3. Parasite didnt help improve the odds. If the film had been made in English it wouldnt have gotten near the attention. Yes, its a new story and nothing like it existed previously, but it didnt really move the needle enough to throw it into the mix with some of the other nominated films. If youre the moviegoer thats wants to look deep within a movie to find some hidden meaning about society, knock yourself out. For those that are looking to be entertained, save your money. The plot is slow to develop and the climax is ridiculous. Prepare to be disappointed.
an excellent and ferociuos metaphor of our modern society
Funny, wrong and tragic at the same time.

A beautifully filmed movie about family and disparity in modern South Korea. Bong Joon Ho delivers a cinematic masterpiece that will keep you glued to the screen and send you on an emotional rollercoaster with twists and turns you did not see coming.
Has it’s ups and downs but overall pretty enjoyable. Although the story is interesting, most of the shock is delivered in the form of violence rather than story.
Ok not worth a best picture nod

Rating: A+

"All in all, Parasite genuinely surprised me. With so many people hyping it to a ridiculously high level, my expectations were very moderate. Nevertheless, I love it as much or more as everyone else. I know that watching it this late can make some people question my opinion/rating, but I would never love a movie because I "should" or because other people do. It deserves every award it received, especially the ones concerning the screenplay. It's one of the best original stories of the last few years, and it's written in such a brilliant manner, with beautiful visual storytelling instead of the overused exposition. An emotionally resonant message is present throughout the whole runtime, and the various tones are balanced seamlessly. Technically flawless: cinematography, score, editing... everything's absolutely perfect. Nothing is placed without purpose. Not a single line of dialogue is wasted. Bong Joon Ho is a phenomenal filmmaker, one that cares about the art and everything that comes with it. He truly put his heart and soul into this, and it would be a shame if anyone fails to watch this magnificent movie just because it's in a foreign language. Please, don't make such an awful mistake..."
Second time seeing it, just as strong and masterfully done as the first time!
This is by far one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Dark and pointless. How in the world did it win best picture? What a joke.
I didn't like it. The movie was very triggering, violent, and it stressed me out watching it.

I have seen a lot of movies. If it's out, I'll most likely see it at some point. This movie wasn't on my list, even though I knew it was out, and that was a mistake. It took a friend to sit me down and show me the movie, and for all the obvious exaggeration and far-fetched situations, it blew me away. This could be because my expectations were low, but I think it has something to do with the movie allowing me to forget I was reading subtitles. That's the simplest way I can explain my investment to the story and characters. Not for everyone in the end, but a must see nonetheless.
Didnt seem too logical. Are the family grifters or just down on their luck?
Not bad but definitely nothing you have to see
It's the same 'ol, same 'ol weathy and entitled versus poor and underprivileged, this time in Korea.
Wonderful satire - a little bloody at the end.

Fantastic piece of cinema, so fresh yet it masters the basics of the cinema we know and love. Even spread of seriousness, subtle comedy and intrigue, a beautiful combination that works perfectly together in this movie. The film flows amazingly, the pace is just perfect, I don't think I took my eyes off of the screen a single time. It works as both an entertaining film for everyone yet also a masterpiece with a strong message told through Bong Joon-Ho's impressive visual symbolism making it almost difficult not to understand what it is. All aspects of this movie are executed flawlessly, greatest film I have seen in a long, long time.
I don't say this lightly; It's a perfect film. It moves from a smart comedy to something nearly opposite and equally as effective, while creating a layered message that the world needs to see.
In poverty-stricken world, the conditions are rife for deceit, underhanded & scheming even fatal consequences! Truly eye=opening but entertaining to drive this point to the rest of the world.
Creative plotting. Certainly highlights age-old and harsh attitudes/behaviors among the classes. Would not have voted it for best picture, however, considering the field this year.
Cinematography was amazing g and story well told
The class struggle left me with a feeling of hopelessness

Very different could not figure out how was going to end.
Good ending.
Damn. That was cool. And I'm kind of a "bro" I get real bored easily in movies.
My husband and I were glued to the movie screen. This movie is so modern. Had many interesting  twists that you wont believe! Havent seen a movie this good in a long time.

Have totally a different taste of film making, Splendid, And 
there's nothing like it, I admit

A boring and badly acted movie, with a plot that would require the "rich" family to be gullible beyond belief.  They would not have gotten that far in life, being that stupid.  Can't even be bothered to check work references or call schools to verify education?   Come on!!  I cannot understand all the fuss over this low-quality film.  Mass hypnosis?
Perfect... The Greatest Movie
the best movie in 2019.
I have watched this movie at least five times. I think that said something about what I think of it.
Okay but not the best pic of the year

I see the word "comedy" in the description. I suppose for some, graphic depictions of people being bashed in the head with rocks and walls, knifings, slashing, etc. is hilarious. (And we are horrified and confused when these "funny" things happen in real life.) More troubling, it might have been hilarious with a surprising instead of a lazy outcome and without the brutality for brutality's sake. But THAT movie would have required a very talented and twist-delivering director, like Danny Boyle. This lazy "movie" was the worst I've seen, perhaps forever.

It was generally entertaining and had some shock value like a lot of Korean movies. However I struggled to relate to or feel for any of the characters, most of whom had no redeeming qualities. The humour was predictable and hardly subtle. Quite a few reviews here waxing lyrical about this movie - I don't buy it.
Loved it. The dialogue is in short sentences so easy to follow in subtitles. The story is about the wealth gap in Korea and should ring true with Americans as the wealth gap in US is worse.
Definitely Oscar-worthy!
It was a good intense film. You knew they were going to get in trouble eventually. Very predictable. Big secret was the guy living in the basement. It was not my fav fir best picture tho
The whole story line and the concept was absolutely incredible. The language barrier was honestly the reason why it was good.
Absolutely terrific movie!! Captivating!

I really disliked it. Ugly squalid people doing ugly squalid things to each other. I left two-thirds of the way through because I didn't care what happened to any of them. I learnt nothing I wanted to learn about the human condition. Last time I pay attention to the Oscars.

A bittersweet piece of art!
A must see
Such a good movie I’m agree with all Oscar awards that they won

At the beginning I was skeptical because it was English subtitles ( sometimes annoying ) but it got great reviews so I decided , “why not”. The movie definitely keeps you on your feet and the plot and characters are amazing !! Haven’t seen a great movie like this in a LONG time !

Way overrated. Nothing redeeming, humorous or inspiring about this movie.  Every character was detestable.  It was difficult to root for anyone.  The beginning was slightly intriguing only to dissolve into a strange, violent and ridiculous massacre.  So wishing I never saw it.
The first half was slow, but things got interesting and better.

Parasite is a excellent social drama on about the social issues between the rich and poor with great acting from the cast and the cinematography is excellent and written super smart and aware about its self with a unique soundtrack
Amazing story, captured what the difference between social classes can be perfectly. A great movie with excellent writing.
Interesting plots, superb acting, unexpected twists.

Not nearly as good as the hype. Strange, surreal, and not in an entertaining way. I wouldn't say it was bad, just a little too absurd. There are countless movies to chose from that will fill a couple of hours of one's time, as well as, or better than this movie.

keeps you on your toes the entire movie!! Must see!!

Horrific.  

I can't understand this getting awards.

All people at their worst.
Thank you dear lord Jesus that I could save so much money to watch this on amazon for only $3.99.

This movie is darkly funny, with some tongue-in-cheek moments- "it's a metaphor!" then shifts tone seamlessly. It is about a poor family in Seoul that worms their way into A wealthy family to slowly take over a household. It's twists and turns explore class difference in a confronting way. It seems to blend a lot of different types of movies together. Amazing camerawork and set designs to create visual metaphors as well as the script.   An excellent, well crafted film from a precise film maker.
Some films are all style no substance; some films have a lot to say and trip over themselves. Parasite lands at the perfect centre. It's slick, intelligent, tight and a heavy social critique.
It was very complicated. I loved it. 완전 twist.
I can't believe this was voted best picture. entertaining for the first hour with a nice setup, but then? bad writing the last half. It could have used a few more script revisions.
An amazing movie with a riveting plot line.,Keeps you intrigued the whole movie! Great cinemitograpy
VERY intense! Definitely deserved best picture
So good, I forgot I was reading subtitles half way through.

One of the best films I've ever seen. You think it's going one way and then honestly, it takes you a completely different direction. The film kind of a time hits you with a lot of stuff at once but it's purposeful and not just to seem artsy. A lot of small hints that connects two larger plot points in the end. My only complaint, and I'm being picky, Is that the beginning kind of drags But it is such a amazing commentary on social class that goes beyond just South Korea. That's why I feel this movie is resonating. So well. Honestly, there's not a likeable character in the movie and that's kind of a good thing. Haven't seen a movie this well-written since Get Out. Watch this!

And the killing spree was just over the top. Thought that they would have come to a strange but workable arrangement continuing to live as parasites in the end but they instead went for a sensationalist ending.

way to dark for me! I can't believe this movie won for best picture! what was the academy smoking!

Story well-told with great acting and cinematography. Did not like the last 1/4 of the film where the violence just went haywire, as if they couldn't think of a better way to end. The final scene was tremendously clever, sad and hopeful.
Totally amazing. Jessica, only child, Illinois, Chicago...
The story weird.  The violence is awful.  The deception is bad.  How did it win an Oscar?

Straight up excellent filmmaking! You don’t see something of this caliber often. It’s funny, sad, awkward, mysterious, triumphant and horrifying all at once. Even with reading the subtitles I was fully engaged the entire time. It’s a must see.
Great, totally deserving of the Oscar.

Just wow. I’m still in awe. It’s really a comedy thriller but it literally switches from comedy to thriller in few moments. Acting was superb. The movie had a lot to say about class. I can see why it won best picture. It shakes you to the core.
Very enjoyable movie. Great acting and a very unique story line. Well worth it
Really good movie it left me speechless.
This was art. Period.
One of the best movies I’ve ever seen. So happy it swept the Oscars.
Interesting start and creatively done. The ending was bizarre. I made it past the subtitles but couldn’t make it past the sudden and unnecessary gore.

A timeless Masterpiece, a review wouldn't do this film proper justice, just go watch it.
Well deserving of its four oscars in Best Picture, Directing, International Feature Film and Writing (Original Screenplay). Still i am a bit dissapointed that non of the cast was even nominated for acting. All around gripping and mesmerizing preformances & plot.
Deserved every award it received
long movie. best part finally comes toward the end.

Still need to process what I just watched... first half was enjoyable, second half was really  rough! Didn't expect such a change in atmopshere. Surely this movie gives one something to think about e.g. who is the parasite? On the surface, the poor look as if they are the parasites. However, the rich were benefitting from their service, more of a symbiotic relationship. The rich took the work of the poor to the point it felt it was entitled. Come when we want. We pay you extra. Respect. Cross the line. Who crossed the line? At first it seems like the poor family has crossed the line but at the birthday party it has really revealed it.... Despite the [spoiler]the fact that "Jessica" was stabbed and Kims wife was desperately fighting against the maniac, Mr. Park only cares for his unconscious son who would "probably" die in the next 15 min. Sure, bringing his unharmed son to hospital is more important than to rescue an blood stained girl who is at the edge of death [/spoiler]. That's also [spoiler] the reason why Kim has stabbed him: Then when his daughter got stabbed, none of them cared. Like fuck you, lets see what youll do if you got stabbed instead[/spoiler]. At this point it is hard to decide which family to like and to dislike.
Speaking of a different topic: The movie protrayed the discrepance between poor and rich very well e.g. the rain scene. The rich love the rain  because it cleaned the filth and brightened the day. While it destroyed the lives of the poor. Parasites don't often know they harm the host.

I've had films that were favorites of mine actually win Best Picture but it was just that underdog mentality along with so many barriers that made PARASITE winning all the more rich. This wasn't just my favorite film of 2019 but my favorite film of the decade...and honestly, it may be my favorite film since the turn of the new millennium. I can't remember a time I felt so passionate about a film...not even MOONLIGHT recently even though I do adore it. 

I feel like Foreign Films have often been the benchmark for high quality cinema...and yet none have ever won the Oscar. Here, Bong Joon-ho manages to make a movie that is just the right amount of "Art-house quirky" and yet have it be accessible to the average film goer. 

It's a master class in story and structure and acting and directing and design and...frankly I'll take a page out of the late Roger Ebert's handbook when he was receiving THE CRYING GAME: "See this film...and then shut up about it!". It's best to go in "cold" as Bong himself has said but watch the trailer and familiarize yourself with the barest synopsis and then...for the love of god...GO WATCH THE DAMN THING!

It was a mix feeling.  Somewhat boring at first,  then the decisiveness of the Kim's family, then the killing at end...the only thing the movie succeeded at is in representing the reality, the gap between poor and rich families.

In a word this movie is masterful. I can see why this movie is in contention for Best Picture, Best Original Screenplay, and so many more. The score in this movie adds so much to every scene it is in and when absent really allows the acting and natural tension of the situation to shine. I have not seen many foreign films (I can count all of them on one hand) and this movie stands out compared to many movies I have seen in the last decade. Bong Joon-ho does an outstanding job writing and directing this movie that it allows all actors to shine in their own way. There are plenty of sentimental moments that allow us to understand the family's shortcomings and a character's personality; while at the same time building up suspense as their plan begins to unravel right before our eyes. This movie is one I won't soon forget and I look forward to all future works of Bong Joon-ho. Cheers.

While technically proficient and well-acted, in the end the movie is a vile and nihilistic waste of time. It doesn't really have anything to say - its "social commentary" is vapid and one-dimensional. I must admit I enjoyed parts of it but the ending in particular was jarring, disturbing, and devoid of humanity. Not surprised this won "Best Picture" given the perverse, anti-life lack of morality Hollywood embodies. Should have known, given I found "Snowpiercer" an unwatchable mess.

Cannot understand the reaction to this film. It's Internally inconsistent—the improverished protagonists are, at first, incompetent at everything, then suddenly expert con artists. They are also deeply unsympathetic, wrecking the lives of other lower class people, not just the rich. The ending comes out of left-field and was weird, dark and absurd.  The film doesn't know whether it's a comedy or a tragedy, a light romp or a political allegory. The anger, class-resentment and amorality add up to a very incoherent movie.  That it's so popular right now may be a symptom of the current state of political outrage and derangement.  I don't think history will judge the critics, or this film, kindly.

And how does a film get to be greatest of the year, maybe it's a kind of good luck charm rock with power over the outcome of events like some all-knowing entity fixed with singular destiny, or is it related more so to systems like social economics and all the barriers put up, walls constructed to produce architecture, and the inhabitants navigate these worlds like lab experiments in a maze, some luckier than others, the fortunate ones at the higher end equipped with hot irons to smooth out wrinkles natural to anything human, the lower ones literally at a lower level trapped below and in danger when it rains, waters rising up and flooding the inside basement apartment as if it were some sinking ship, Titanic scenes in the cold when sparks ignite electric, toilets shouting, with somewhat the same tools on the other end, just with designs of better quality and a better appearance, plumbing pipes connecting everybody, or Wi-Fi, the stream of youthful romance across classes like Romeo and Juliet, each party fixed on the glowing screen as if it has the answer, working together to figure it out, different communication methods, avenues, even some misdirection, as it would be better to return to the place they'd least expect, which wasn't part of the plan as it just sort of happened that way, determined in a way with all the creatures scurrying around with a subtle inkling that there's choice in the matter, certain determination of putting the mind to some extreme goal, the metaphorical rock acting like gravity, because it all just happens that way, some spontaneous erotica on the expensive couch with the married lovers in luxury sleepwear, very clean at the same time with a fetish a little dirtier morbidly fantasizing being on the lower end when that end is hiding out like cockroaches very nearby but in a good group that looks out for one another and sticks together living in such close quarters having to accept the reality of their limited space, when the rich people have got their own rooms even the tipi in the yard during the memorable rainstorm, and the rain indeed falls on everybody, it's just that some have better shelters and protections than others, different living environments which pretty much determines everything else, somewhat related to appearances and acting the part, and in such a deceptive world it's like anybody can use their cunning and set their world to something they're not, but maybe they are, so what's real anyway, questioning whether you fit in in a different world or if you're destined to remain in the environment in which you were raised, in which you were born into, the idea of moving up in class and identifying the dynamics of driver and rider, the rider telling the driver where to go and what to do, and the driver having the ultimate freedom and choice, even a dizzying amount, but it's that type of madness that could lead to finding yourself in the place of your dreams after all that waiting, that poor sacrifice also of accident pain when it hurts worse trying to make it better, tears, so who are the good people, it gets to be very confusing the more light that's shed, and what fitting theme for the new decade to approach, the realities of inequality, the potential for con artistry, fine moods and cinema revelations, action mixed with contemplative style, a new kind of suspense, transcending, broadcasted outside South Korea?

Parasite, this year's winner of Best Picture, Best Director, Best Original Screenplay and Best International Feature Film, started off quite promising, quirky but witty. Not Best Picture worthy by any stretch but I really enjoyed the first 45 or so minutes. Then the plot gets dragged through molasses before it culminates with the script getting dropped in a methane gas filled sewer and the producers drop in the match. 

Well acted with great characters, but just because you have the ability to craft a WTF ending doesn't mean it works and this didn't. Save yourself 90 minutes of your life, watch the first 45 and then turn it off.

Phenomenal in a mesmerizing and indescribable way. To make a movie that is as complex and convoluted as Parasite is a testament to the genius nature of the plot. While certain aspects of the movie exhibited some holes, the way in which the movie naturally highlights class warfare and division, without casting the burden on either the rich or the poor, makes this even more compelling and realistic. Without a doubt, the movie is dark and tragic (especially the end), but perhaps that is the point: to make a potent statement surrounding the implications of class division. That being said, not recommended for children, but otherwise, one of, if not, THE most complete and well-rounded movie that I have seen in a while. Makes me feel complete too. A genuine masterpiece that is!

Bong Joon Ho doesn't make a specific type of film, or rather he doesn't make a film that can be pigeonholed into a particular genre, instead he makes what can only be described as a Bong Joon Ho film. As with his previous films, Snowpiercer and Okja, social critiques disguised as sci-fi thrillers, Parasite is a giddy blend of conflicting themes and tonal shifts. It begins as a tongue-in-cheek comedy about the class system in South Korea – or really, anywhere in the world, giving it an instant sense of timely significance – and then, like a magic trick, effortless slips into a claustrophobic home-invasion thriller. The cheeky grin that welcomes you into the film becomes something altogether more uncomfortable and difficult to pin down. In the same way that the Park family are duped by the Kims, the audience are tricked into settling in for one film and slapped with an entirely different one half-way through, with all the doors locked and the only way out is to scramble over the bodies. It is a film that only Bong Joon Ho could make.

On the surface, Parasite is a simple film to describe – it's about a lower-class family latching onto a wealthy family and draining their resources, in the same way a parasite infiltrates and infects its host. Dig a little deeper and it's clear that this is not a film about good and bad morality, it's grey and murky, and if you poke it, as Bong Joon-Ho does with a dash of Hitchcock-inspired mayhem, blood spills.

Song Kang Ho, in utterly captivating form, is Ki-taek — head of the Kim family. They live in a damp and messy basement house that's literally half-way below ground, often providing perfect view from their living room of the local drunk who urinates from above. They scurry around for high ground so they can leach off neighbouring Wi-Fi spots, and the film begins in a moment of brief panic when they can no longer find any. Fortunately, if they clamber to the top of their toilet seat, perhaps where the internet belongs, WhatsApp beams back into their existence. These aren't dim people and Bong makes it clear from the start that despite their economic status, these are ambitious, talented, crafty individuals. They are so resourceful that Ki-taek has them leave the window open as pest control spray the street, the gas flooding through into their home, engulfing the family and killing their pest problem in the process.

Opportunity strikes, and sometimes that's all you need, when Ki-woo (Choi Woo-shik) gets a job offer from his university student friend who makes money tutoring rich kids. He's going away and needs somebody to take over. Ki-woo agrees and the Kim family put their audacious plan into place. Fancy paperwork later, artistically designed by his talented sister Ki-jung (Park So-dam), Ki-woo is marching up to the Park family estate that sits high up in the hills, fitted with electronic doors and fortress-like walls. Not long before he convinces simple but well-meaning house wife Yeon-Kyo ( Cho Yeo Jeong) that he's an esteemed tutor, she makes the point that her artistic son is struggling with trauma, and so he recommends Ki-jung for an art-therapist role, pretending they don't know each other. One by one, the Kim family wriggle their way into the Park home, sending the previous employees to the streets, and so the roles and fortunes are beginning to change. But this a Bong-Joon Ho film, and with delighted content comes a crushing reality, and this is slammed home with the film's poignant final shot. None of this can last.

The way it out all plays out is wickedly fun, as the Kim family deceive the Parks in a variety of ingenious ways. To the script's credit, which had it win a Bafta for original screenplay, none of the scenarios seem implausible. And while it's as enjoyable as a caper-comedy, there is a grimness to the way the Park family, blinded by their wealth and self-importance, have been so easily swindled and invaded. Move an inch past the comedy, as Bong-Joon Ho does with razor-sharp ease, and Parasite becomes a deeply uncomfortable film about privacy and social hierarchy. Does that make the Kim family the villains here? It's not clear and obvious. After all, they just want a better life for themselves, and nobody's getting hurt yet. On the other hand, you have the Park family who are rich and openly recoil at those beneath them, even insisting that the Kim family all have a certain smell that defines them – a call back to the stench of the stink bugs eradicated earlier in the film. And yet, the Parks are not bad people, they love their son and daughter – like Ki-taek, Dong-ik (Lee Sun Kyun) simply wants the best for his family, and he gives them that with the money he earns. As the film reaches its wild finale, the grin that started the film shifting into a grimace, the answer to which family is the parasite becomes even harder to reach.

As with the best of Bong, there is magic to the way everything comes together. Parasite is much more than an entertaining genre mash-up with a brilliant script. It's a crisp and clean clockwork machine, made up of ideas all working together and executed seamlessly to create an indefinable but very special whole. The title is metaphorical, something that Ki-woo reiterates throughout, but Parasite could equally apply to the way the spaces of the Park home get inside of you before you even realise the camerawork is doing anything special. The house is a stunning creation with all the intricacies and character of a stage play, of which Parasite was once planned to be, but Bong scrapped that when he began writing the script and could only see the possibilities of an expertly placed camera. He was right and cinematographer Hong Kyung-pyo, fresh from Burning, and in another career highlight, defines every single space in the Park home with the same love and attention that's gone into the script. None of this is explicitly done. It all happens through the introduction of the different characters and their interaction with each layer of the house. Everything has been thought out and how the families occupy the space, from the cosy but cramped Kim home to the wide-open Park house, which has its basement entrance cast in permanent darkness against the bright glow of the kitchen lights, as if anything below this level of the house is a home for something evil. Yeon-Kyo suggests as such by telling Ki-jung that her son's trauma came from there. Again, everything in the film, from its script to its set design, feeds back to its themes of class warfare.

Nobody can stop talking about Parasite, and nobody should. It's the rare film that is both an absolute riot and a complicated dissection of current real-world issues. It's funny, sad, uncomfortable and violent. It's a Bong Joon Ho film, it's his best yet, and nobody is doing cinema quite like this.

https://reelrunner.wordpress.com/2020/02/04/parasite-review-bong-joon-hos-impeccably-designed-social-satire-is-a-riot/

Just like director Bong Joon- Ho's previous film Snowpiecer (2013), Parasite makes is jump directly into the hardships of social spacial segregation and class contrast. And it's a very captivating movie, which just keeps making you watch. It feels like an incredible blend of genres, it starts out like a comedy- family film, but only to continue onto something much more gruesome and thrilling. Although not as scary, it feels a lot like a Korean version of Jordan Peele's 2017 Get Out. And it features very strong performances from the whole cast, but especially by Song Kang-Ho and Lee Sun-Kyun. Overall, this is a pretty entertaining, stunning and strong movie, and it doesn't surprise me that it won the Academy Award for Best Picture. A must-see for film lovers and recommended!!

Parasite is a movie that throws a lot of stuff at you that forces you to consider economic strata and the interaction thereof. A couple of key lines by the wealthy businessman about his driver were "He gets close to the line (of acting improperly for his station in life) but doesn't cross it." and "He smells like the people on the subway... like an old radish. I haven't been on the subway in years." These statements along with the way other household staff were dismissed, showed a total lack of the concept of human dignity, whatever the station in life. And it is the wealthy man's crinkling of his nose in disgust at the odor from a lower-class character that leads to the climactic event near the end of the movie. There is such good story telling and character development that you overlook a lot of the deeper commentary until you are sitting in your quiet car afterward, musing about all the things you have seen. I generally don't like dark comedies, but this was a true masterpiece and I will definitely go view it again to catch some of the subtle nuances that I must have missed the first time around.

The writing, the acting, the directing, the framing, the editing, the plot, the dialogue; there literally isn't a single fault. It's perfectly executed and I love it

Everything it says about society and culture: the way we idolize the wealthy, how apathetic they are to our struggles, how a proximity to wealth can make us turn on our own in pursuit of status, how capitalism works to dehumanize us, how our own advancement comes at the expense of others, how the rich live and the poor merely survive, how the wealthy force us into competition with each other, how expendable we are to the bourgeois class in a capitalist society, how distant our two worlds can seem from each other even if they're only a few subway stops away. I can write an extensive essay on any one of those points. It's smart, it's funny, it's dark, it's deep, it's philosophical, it's tragic; it's all the things.

I was engaged from the first scene to the last. The family was so easy to root for because anyone who's ever lived through hardship can relate to what they're going through. Every poor person has dreamed about being a rich person. To live how the other half lives, even if just for a moment. They get a nice gig, but it ends up being too good to be true. My heart was racing for basically the last hour of the film because something happens that I can't say and the story goes from a light-hearted romp about a family cleverly scheming their way into a better situation to something completely different in an instant.

I honestly can't say too much more without giving anything away, but god do I want to make everyone I know watch it so I can talk about all the great themes. The beautiful, beautiful themes! I can't recommend it highly enough. If subtitles normally deter you, give it a chance anyway. Like Bong Joon Ho, the writer/director of the movie and winner of many Oscars, said, "Once you overcome the 1-inch-tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films". This has actually inspired me to watch more foreign language media going forward, which I've always hesitated to do. Because if my prejudice has kept me from seeing gems like this all these years, then I want to correct that as soon as possible. 

You can rent it on Amazon Prime for $4, so I suggest you do that and see it immediately. Like right now. Skip class. Call out of work. Watch Parasite.

In conclusion: Eat the Rich like Ram Don 🍜

Best movie of 2019 by far. Biting social subtext, brilliantly layered editing, masterful and witty dialogue, a perfectly utilized score, and impeccable directing created one of my favorite films ever. One should go into this film with at least a basic understanding of the current socioeconomic climate of South Korea. The fundamental issue at hand is the immense discrepancy between the resources and fiscal opportunities available to the lower class and the lavish lives of the wealthy. Throughout the film, the Kims (lower class) and the Parks (upper class) are masterfully juxtaposed through both overt and subtle means in order to best emphasize the class strife present in South Korea. One such instance was the monsoon sized rain storm towards the end of the film. The Parks see the rainstorm as beautiful and their son even camps outside in a clearly expensive tent. The Kims, however, return to the sub-levels of their residence to find their beloved basement home irreparably damaged and flooded. In the wake of this disaster, the Parks opt to celebrate and throw a party for their beloved son and ask that the Kims, who are sleeping in a public rec center, (unbeknownst to the Parks) to attend. This stark contrast underscores the animosity and resentment felt by the lower classes as their struggles are completely ignored and tossed aside by the wealthy, a situation not at all dissimilar from the current socioeconomic conditions in the United States. Bong Joon Ho deserved every bit of lauding and praise that he received for this masterpiece. His extensive story-boarding paved the way for a masterclass in editing by Yang Jin-Mo, whose 'frankensteinish' work with some scenes gave the best representation of the actor's gripping performances. Bong Joon Ho's masterful directing is on full display throughout the whole film but is best represented by one sequence. All I ask is that you watch the roughly five-minute long 'peach' sequence and tell me this movie isn't at the apex of cinema today. The editing, directing, score, and acting were... impeccable. The passage of time felt like a breeze despite the immense weight and importance of the sequence to the overall narrative. Callbacks to earlier moments in the SEQUENCE (not even the film itself) were incredible and rewarding. If you didn't notice, play close attention to the hot sauce packets used during the sequence and you'll see what I mean. When I think of a best picture, I think of a movie that I would want to share with others and would also want to watch more than once. This is a movie I will only watch once. It was well made. Lovely cinematography & editing. The story however... ugh. This was a hard movie to watch, but not in a 'Life is Beautiful' kind of way. There was no one to root for. I disliked how everyone behaved. I thought people made irrational and terrible choices. Indeed, I had a hard time finishing it, because I found it utterly depressing. It felt futile, and I didn't feel like I was entertained so much as exposed to the worst bits of human nature without any glint of redemption. Sometimes, a movie can be thought provoking, and make you feel like you've gained access into an alternate POV that is worth considering/examining/learning from. Not this movie. It just made me feel sad for every (contrived) situation & character. It wasn't over the top enough to be on par with a Tarantino movie, and it didn't have enough heart to compete with movies like 'Life is Beautiful.' I don't think it's worthy of Best Picture, but then again I don't think critics are very masterful in their critiques these days. They're too concerned with what they ought to say and not in touch with their actual feelings and perceptions about the storytelling that they're witnessing.

PARASITE- 5 OUT OF 5 STARS ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ ⭐️ 
 
Being a life long lover of foreign films, I saw this movie early in. When I saw it in the theater, there were only 4 other people in the theater with me. And, let me tell you, all 5 of us were equal parts mesmerized, riveted, laughing, horrified, moved and we all gave it a standing ovation at the end. All 5 of us 🤣 It went to surprising and did-not-see-it-coming places few films dare to go in these days of comic book blockbusters and franchise overkill; and it did so with verve, style, heart and vision. This film totally and completely blew me away. THIS MOVIE IS AMAZING. REALLY AN UNBELIEVABLY GREAT MOVIE. And though the expression tends to be thrown around way to loosely these days, it really is A TRUE MODERN MASTERPIECE. It actually reminded me of the very first time I saw Tarantino's Pulp Fiction (who also wrote, directed and produced his own film just like Joon Ho did with Parasite). Where I knew I was watching a special film from someone who's talent, vision and execution was unique, and their art was not able to be duplicated (although imitated it has been). On a level all their own, a masterful level. That their vision is one of a kind. *Parasite* was that powerful to me and I had that strong of a reaction to it. Because it's so well layered, gut punch powerful and masterfully crafted that it cannot be denied; and it's impossible to look away, even when the tides turn in unexpected directions you may not have seen coming. Not only is it the hands down best movie of the year, but one of the greatest films I've seen in the past decade; and one of the best films I've seen in my lifetime. It💯deserved to win for Best Picture. Actually, it's one of the few Best Picture winners of recent memory that's actually an outstanding film. Just didn't think the stuffy, stuck up Academy would actually give it to Bong Joon Ho as he deserved. But they did. And I was ecstatic. For once, the actual best picture actually won Best Picture. Watch it-and fall in love with cinema and the power of masterful storytelling all over again❤️.
This is truely masterpiece of cinema!

Director and master storyteller Bong Joon Ho gives the perspective of the edges of morality the ego causes these complex characters to go through. The audience feels at once sorry for and disgust at the characters in the ebbs and flows of the characters’ arcs. The desparation for the upper class to present a perfect image renders them judgmental and so self-absorbed their lack of awareness widens their blind spots. The poor—so desparate to survive or to be seen as human—sacrifice morality and safety for a glimmer of living it up for just one day.  Be careful what you wish for!  “The best plan is to have no plan.” This quote from the patriarch of the poor family painfully punctuates his total loss of hope and his way of self-preservation. The gesture that sets off the entire ending sequence shows even the “loweliest” among us still has pride. What a trip.

I am a little astonished with the high praise this movie has received. The film starts from a good idea for a story, has good actors and beautiful takes. I found it pleasant and amusing up to approximately two thirds of its duration. In the first part of the movie we are confronted with the ability of the "poor" to scam the "rich" and a comic presentation of the "rich" exposing their naivety and manias. The plot seems to change in nature after the servants  are lead down to the underground bunker by the former housekeeper. In fact that moment is a turning point into chaos -- of the plot, I mean. My limit of disbelief was then reached. Moreover, none of the interpretations of the movie that I've read about in other reviews (e.g. a metaphor of class struggle, a concern with wild capitalism, climate change, and whatever) seems reasonable or applicable, because they are not compatible with the story and  characters' description so far. My interpretation is that, simply, the final sections of the script are uninspired and pointless.

Predictable first half morphed into a not entirely successful shift in genres in the second half. The lower class family that wormed their way into the wealthy family's home actually possessed too many talents to be believable as poverty-stricken. In addition, South Korea has one of the most successful economies on the planet, so the film seems more like a fantasy created by the writer/director. Many of the plot devices are contrivances used by the the director to make his satirical points. I'm avoiding specific examples here, so my review will be free of spoilers, but the "lucky" rock is one example of these contrivances. The punishments meted out in the denouement of the film did not seem justified, as the characters who suffered did not seem greatly evil. The film was beautifully photographed, especially the interiors of the respective domiciles. Mildly entertaining, but certainly not worthy of the best picture Oscar.

It's rare for a foreign film to gain as much popularity with American audiences as the South Korean film Parasite has done. It's even rarer for a foreign film to earn Academy Awards nominations for Best Foreign Language (now called International) film and Best Picture, but Parasite has managed to join this exclusive club. Director Bong Joon-ho has long been turning out top quality, intriguing work (I'm a big fan of his melancholy 2003 film Memories of Murder, about a years long hunt for a serial killer). Bong Joon-ho and Han Jin-won's Oscar nominated original screenplay switches tones and even genres so abruptly and successfully, it makes Parasite a unique movie to say the least. Combined with a stellar cast, excellent cinematography, production design, and pacing, Parasite becomes a thoroughly engrossing, extraordinary experience. Movies like this in any language are rare indeed.

Parasite begins as a dark comedy and sharp satire about economic inequality and class disparity. The Kim family lives in a shabby basement apartment. The street level window provides them a view of ankles and urinating drunks. They work short term odd jobs and hunt around their apartment for a spot with Wi-Fi. A change in luck comes when a friend of their teenage son recommends him as a tutor for the daughter of a wealthy family, the Parks. The son, Ki-woo, reluctantly accepts though he is under qualified. Soon the Kim family schemes to replace each of the Park family servants with themselves though they pose under false identities. The 20-ish Kim daughter, Ki-jeong, provides the family with false credentials. Things take a fateful and irreversible turn when the Kims decide to have a night in luxury while the Parks are away for the weekend.

That plot description seems to make the title describe the Kim family. As you watch them work their way into the home of the Park family, you may find the title applies more to the Parks whose lifestyle requires people like the Kims. The differences between a family that is oblivious of their wealth and a family that schemes to get stable, working-class jobs is apparent. But then, the film reveals layers and depth that make it truly profound. When the film becomes a riveting thriller, it does not eschew its themes and substance. I cannot recall the last time I had no idea where a film was going, not because of incompetence, but because I was watching the work of a master filmmaker.

The entire ensemble is terrific. Each role is well cast and there's a great chemistry between the members of the respective families. The stand outs for me, however are Song Kang-ho as the Kim family patriarch and Park So-dam as his clever daughter. Cho Yeo-jeong as the daffy and gullible Park matriarch is great comic relief.

What sets Parasite a step above other socially conscious films is it does not sacrifice entertainment for the sake its social commentary or vice versa. It never pontificates or pretends to have any didactic solution. It is like a classic Twilight Zone episode, up front about its themes but in such a way that doesn't speak down to audience and feels detached and immediate simultaneously. There is not a single pandering moment in the entire film. Parasite uses the real problems and concerns of modern society to tell a compelling and universal story that causes us to reflect on our world. That can be the definition a great film and great art.
As excellent as everyone says. It’ll never win at the Oscars of course, but that’s okay!

Violence turns me off! The sets, acting, and some themes fascinated me, but then came the violence and I was totally put off. Thats it! I mus also say that I am not squeamish necessarily. If its a crime show or murder mystery so be it! I just didnt get it!
Amazing experience! This movie taps into our social culture and how the rich and the poor differ. From scene one I was completely engaged in the film. A must see for all movie fans!!

Director Bong Joon-ho's global sensation, Parasite, is an allegorical tale of class warfare. Before watching the film, I was familiar with its high praise but knew little of its actual plot. If possible, I'd recommend other viewers similarly go into this one as cold as they can. While Parasite deals with heavy themes (economic mobility, climate change), it does so in ways that are constantly entertaining and surprising. A unique blend of drama, suspense, comedy, and horror, Parasite provides further proof that cinema is a truly universal language.

Parasite is a dark comedy that is smart, relatable and thought provoking. Spoilers ahead! Weeks after watching Parasite in full color, I watched it again in black & white. I prefer the color version and the movie left a lot for the audience to reflect on afterwards. Relatable in the sense that the rich get richer and the poor are left to fend for themselves, it can also reflect on country relationships between S. Korea and other Asian nations alongside the US. South Korea has come a long way in terms of its economic advances but you take the magnifying glass and will realize that many young people there are still not able to get jobs and richer people have access to resources and tutoring programs that make a huge difference in advancement such as tough college entrance exams. Both SK and US have questionable leaders of both countries where it is uncertain if they lead on the interest of its citizens or the interests of their own party/financial interests. In an age where anyone can google, gullible characters fall for a multi-phased manipulative plans initially seeming innocent enough. There's references to "crossing the line" meaning class clashes between character families. The class difference is noted via "smell" which is akin to sub basement dwellings or the subways. There are some reflective moments of happiness in the movie where characters look at the sky from home, relax at a modern home which is not theirs "this is our home right now" or share laughter over family meals in tiny kitchens or taxi driver restaurants. It's almost like the director is teaching us to enjoy the moment and the little things because it is all so fleeting. The struggling daughter pleads with her father to "just worry about us" which could be in reference to international relations or an omen for upcoming provocation. Planning is a key theme throughout the movie where initial plans fall into multiple phases. The struggling father eventually notes that no plan makes for no disappointment or a plan that never fails- which seems to me like just giving up. Hasn't he heard the saying that a poor plan is better than no plan? Water represents a lot in the movie from pouring rain to flooding. Flooding occurs where the struggling daughter climbs up to the highest point in her family apartment which happens to be a toilet spewing sewage. She climbs on top of the toilet seat and holds it down as she smokes a cigarette and sewage seeps through the lid under her legs. There's this landscape rock the struggling family receives as a gift and it represents the possibility of wealth. It's used as a weapon and then finally laid back on a river bed where water washes over the rock. Perhaps this means that to this struggling family, wealth may seem attainable but there  are layers of water between them and the rock. The struggling son also notes that the rock tends to follow him. The high point of the struggling family is when all four are hired to work. It makes you wonder how much the rich family pays for them collectively. But also what does it means at a country level because who really is getting the short end of the stick? Who's the fool? Or are we all fools? Who's the bad guy or are we all bad? Only the youngest child in the movie seems to have any semblance of normalcy where he plays freely (but gets criticized for it) and where he feels and reacts (but then gets labeled as traumatized for it). As we all get older do all our views of the world get tainted and judged? Who's the parasite or host? Or are we all just parasites wanting things of each other?

If you want to see this movie then try to avoid spoilers at all cost, it will make your viewing experience that much better.

Parasite is a tale. A good one. One that is well-rounded, multi-layered and complex. It feels like someone took time to really tell an in-depth modern day fairytale, without the magic. The story follows a poor Korean family who slowly trick a rich family into firing their staff and hiring them as the replacements. However things take a turn halfway in the movie. The film shifts from suspenseful comedy, to thriller to sad family drama. Throughout the journey there are certain insights about class, hope, desire, survival and trauma. Very well-written. Bong Joon Ho, make room for the Oscars you'll be winning. Usually with these types of movies, the audience is part of the movie. You're supposed to connect with the main characters. Build an emotional connection with them. So you can become one with the movie. Especially when it's about a poor family compared to a rich family. Ho does something different. He keeps the Parks, the Kims, and the audience separate from each other. You see the struggles the Kims go through everyday, but you don't really feel sorry for them. Then you have the Parks. They're the victims and they don't deserve what happens to them, but they deserve so much more. For the audience, Ho takes you on a roller coaster. He shows you the peaks you can have when you're on top. Then within seconds show the valleys of poverty. Which creates the struggle inside you. Ho keeps letting you get close to connecting to any character then pulls you back to neutral. That makes for a fantastic watch. You're on the edge of your seat from the start. Then want to see what the next step they'll take. I love that. The only thing I really don't like is, Korean Yelp would've stopped this whole thing. That's not enough for me not to like this movie. It stands out in recent memory actually. Overall it's the best nominated movie I've seen so far this year. Grade Santa. 5 out of 5 beards

A family who doesn't have a lot of money or opportunities in life, starts working for a wealthy family. But will this change the life of the poor family?

DIRECTOR: Bong Joon Ho
SCREENWRITERS: Bong Joon Ho, Han Jin Wan
CAST: Song Kang Ho, Lee Sun Kyun, Cho Yeo Jeong, Choi Woo Shik, Park So Dam, Lee Jung Eun, Chang Hyae Jin
In the movie, we follow the Kim family who doesn't have much money. By chance, the son in the family starts working for the wealthy Park family. He teaches their daughter English. Now the rest of the family sees opportunities to make money, and they have a plan to remove the rest of the staff who work for the wealthy Park family and then take the jobs themselves.

Bong Joon Ho addresses deeper themes, but he always manages to create entertainment and some surprising scenes that bring out the smile. The movie is mostly charming until the Kim family discovers the big secret of the house.

Then the movie starts to get darker, and it explodes into a wonderful finale where we see and understand the message of the movie. The title of the movie turns things on its head. Because what I thought to be quite obvious at the beginning of the movie is turned upside down and I got an aha experience. Parasites are found in all classes of society.

From a technical aspect I think this was a beautifully crafted film from the direction to the cinematography. There are so many beautiful scenes in the movie, and it's pretty well done considering that most of the action takes place inside the big house and the not so big garden.My favorite sequence is when the Kim family has to run home when the rain is pouring down, and you feel like they're on board the Titanic. They must run from the top and down to the engine room. What a wonderful sequence, and it's so beautiful to watch!

The cast was fantastic, and everyone fit the needs of their roles. The characters were well-written with the performances complementing that perfectly. It does a great job of creating a collection of characters that feel like real people, whom despite their eccentricities, maintained a grounded, realistic feel.The musical score complements the scenes nicely and elevates the emotional responses without feeling overbearing.

So, if you like foreign films, thrillers, or movies that can make you think a little check this one out. It's a crisp film from a technical aspect, and with a blend of great writing and acting you can't go wrong. It was a solid film that treats the audience with intelligence. 9/10

I was thinking the other night about how incredibly happy it made me feel to be able to see so many incredible one-of-a-kind films back-to-back in the theater. 1917, Little Women, and now Parasite. If you're looking for something new, fresh, seat-gripping, deep and beautiful, then I urge you to go see Parasite. Bong Joon-ho (Snowpiercer) is a tour-de-force. It was quite the feeling to be in a theater full of strangers by myself and have the shared experience of leaning forward at the same time, clasping our hands to our mouths in shock and sitting in silence during emotionally powerful moments. You can't get that experience at home. The cinematagraphy was sharp, meticulous and metaphorical (inside joke with the movie). The performances and the writing were delicious. There is plenty of honest humor that dances in between the white knuckled dramatic tension. And boy is there suspense! Can't say it enough, GO SEE THIS MOVIE!

The term "masterpiece" can sometimes be so commonly used in a movie review that the word begins to lose its prestige. However, I believe I've seen a film that just might be worthy of the term. So, here's my spoiler free Parasite movie review explaining why it just might be a masterpiece.

Parasite is a film that manages to be funny, creative, unpredictable, heart wrenching, and is extremely thought-provoking. Additionally, it's able to balance multiple tones successfully at the same time with great performances. 

I love how this film pulls common elements used in comedies, dramas, and moments of suspense. Then, mixes them effectively to specific moments to make us feel different emotions throughout the film. It's as if the story is more concerned with being as real, and transparent as humanly possible. It can connect to us on multiple levels instead of focusing on just one emotion or genre. I also love this aspect because as humans we don't operate on one emotion at a time. Sometimes it can be mixed, and sometimes it can vary from moment to moment. So, Parasite balances this perfectly.

After the film was over, I was left sitting there while the credits rolled to let the film completely overtake me. I reflected on all of the themes, story, plot, characters, and etc that really impacted me. Parasite is truly a rare experience that stayed with me for several weeks afterwards even after the credits rolled.

Going into this film I didn't know much about the Director, Bong Joon-ho. However, I want to see more of his filmography as his directing in Parasite is just immaculate.

*Since this review I've seen Snowpiercer, and Okja. Both films are incredible, and Bong Joon-ho is climbing up the chart as one of my personal favorite Directors.

Thematically, I found this film to be one of the most relatable films of 2019. It explores universal themes of poverty, wealth, and family which may seem simple on paper, but the plot of the story is what makes it interesting. Side note, it's also best that I don't say much about the plot because I think it's best to go into this film not knowing much. So, as a result, it made the film unpredictable which is extremely difficult to accomplish. With that being said, the story, and the plot is able to apply the themes creatively without feeling like it's beating you over the head to get the message across.

Parasite has performances that are amazing. Each actor and actress are able to organically go through different emotions as if these characters are real people. The family felt like a real family, and I felt like I knew each member of the family individually due to each being well developed. This is also because we get to spend a good amount of time with each family member.

The music is incorporated perfectly for scenes that were intended to be funny, serious, and suspenseful without being pretentious. The music also doesn't overshadowing the performance.

What do I mean by a perfectly unscripted script? Well, to me. Parasite was so well crafted that I truly didn't know what would happen next. That's a rare feeling that I crave in a film and Parasite is so refreshing in that regard. This also speaks to the originality of the script as well. The first act sets us up for a great payoff. The script has great symbolism and metaphors without overly complicating it with dialogue. The plot services the characters development throughout the story. Then, what I love the most is that it truly feels like a story going from one event to the next without a plan. That is the pinnacle of amazing writing, and the following quote from the film explains the narrative perfectly.

"You know what kind of plan never fails? No plan at all."

I highly enjoyed this film so much I could literally write much more, and I still wouldn't be able to explain how great this film is. So, you'll just have to see it for yourself.
Great plot and story.
