Reflections on Cross-Cultural Issues in the Film 기생충 (Parasite)

Here are a few reflections about the South Korean film by Bong, Joon-ho called 기생충 (Parasite). Some unique Korean cultural differences could get lost to many Western audiences. Reflecting on them is the main goal of this writing. Remember, these are one person's opinions, take them or leave them. Spoiler alerts. If you haven't seen the movie, then go watch it and then read this afterward.

The biggest shock to most Westerners when they see the two poor families at each others' throats is, why not work together in order to fulfill each of their purposes to get wealthy and be comfortable? There is enough wealth for everybody.

It's an excellent question. One of the cultural distinctions of Korea is that there are many ways that people find their identity. It can be in a family, a circle, a class, etc. But if there is neither a history of Jeong  (Shared heart), or Hahn (Shared suffering), then it's hard for strangers to connect empathetically.

Yet one might ask: both families are poor; surely the Kim family should be able to feel "Hahn" for the other family. Maybe so, but consider that the Kims are in a semi-basement (some have described as Purgatory), whereas the old man is living in the basement bunker (Hell), they are in very different places where the Kims are still able to look down on them both socially and geographically.

Another observation is the city of Seoul comes across as being very "post-Christian"~ very much a secular city. Nietzsche wrote that when God is dead; man is dead; the universe is unchained; one is left staring into a dark abyss. The only thing left to exercise is the will to power. We see this in the movie.

There is no morality. One can freely print up a fake university diploma off of the Internet and Photoshop it to one's own liking. One is free to be the impostor and just "fake it until you make it".

Some others have made the observation that the rain water (and the sewage) flows downward; that Global Warming has caused the poor down below to become flooded out of their homes… and the rich way up above are oblivious to it… Just like back during the French Revolution, you can hear Marie Antoinette saying the proverbial …"Let them eat cake!"
Noticing some of the cultural differences can be a challenge. "Parasite" is a wonderful dark comedy that is very unique. It's surprisingly anxiety-provoking and enjoyable. It is also thought-provoking. If you have not seen it yet, I would highly recommend it to you!

I had zero expectations about this film going into it since I hadn't even seen a preview and had only gathered bits of the buzz that it's generated/generating. 

It's not a perfect film. There are inconsistencies in plot and character motivation (for one character in one key moment in particular) and yet despite its imperfections it's almost perfect — and I suspect that may be intentional. 

Experiencing this film felt like someone was sitting in front of a stereo playing a frenetic and erratic score — with the volume turned almost all the way down. Then, slowly and steady, turns up the volume. And keeps turning it up. And up. And up further. Up past the point of discomfort, before quickly turning it back down.

Then grabbing the Balance knob and spinning it left then right and back and forth. Then slowly back to the left and pausing. 

Then spinning it quickly to the right once more.

That's ‘Parasite' — wonderfully scripted and deftly directed and uniquely disorientating and complex. 

And imperfect.

Spoilers within: The title is layered, and the piece has three or four layers. A masterpiece of both heartfelt respect and sadness for life as it is lived, and a biting social critique of how stratification in society can literally lead to explosions that can be lethal. The title:  Who is the parasite? The manipulative poor finding immoral ways to weasel into the lives and onto the payrolls of the rich? Or the inconsiderate rich putting up with the poor whom they hire at low wages to do one form or another of their dirty work? Or yet again, are the family of four who work for the rich family, and the former housekeeper and her hubby who is hiding in the basement illustrating yet another kind of parasite: the poor sucking blood off of the poor? When the rich family went camping, and the four related servants took over the living room and lived if for a short time like the rich, in their house on the hill, the crystal palace with a whole wall of glass looking out onto the green of a well-kept yard, you just knew they would screw this up by drinking, eating, excess and messing up the place. Shouldn't they have been more careful not to jeopardize their dishonestly won jobs in the mansion? Alas, therein lies their fatal flaws. People don't always take care to think of everything, maybe those poorer less than others, due to bigger worries, like how to eat, or attitudes born of the big stresses of living on the edge. Beneath the surface, things are boiling so badly, that when the man in the cellar,  whose wife is abused by the servant family, emerges into the daylight, it is with a knife with murder on his mind, and he does kill the young woman in the servant family. But more surprisingly, her Dad then stabs and kills the rich guy who employs him as a driver. The guy in the cellar of the mansion? A perfect symbol of a stratified society with the rich in the upstairs quarters, a poor man in the downstairs. And when the two-dead birthday party incident plays out in the lush back yard with dozens of guests, the mom and son in the servant family end up on probation for offenses of tricking the rich family into hiring all four in the family, the daughter is dead, and the Dad, now a fugitive from justice for having killed his rich boss, has assumed the position as the cellar dweller in the rich people's house. Upstairs, downstairs again, ship of fools.  At the end, the aspiration of his son is to get rich, buy the house, and let Dad come into the upstairs quarters with him and mom, smash that rich/poor line. It is done as a dream, as in, dream on, that won't ever happen. The class split and the economic roles are too baked in the cake -- in Korea or Pittsburgh. A key line comes from the servant mom who is the housekeeper. Hubby calls the rich woman nice. And she says: "She's nice because she's rich." The rich guy tells his wife that the driver doesn't smell good but that when he talks, he "does not cross the line." The line between rich and poor, boss and help. I was left thinking by the behavior we see that people are pretty much the same everywhere, rich and poor, unconcerned and stressed, and prone to huge mistakes and devastating possibilities. And this had some really funny parts, too.

Admittedly, I don't watch many movies nowadays and feel most box-office films are utter tripe.  Does the world really need Iron Man 8 or X-Men 32?  The answer.... pathetically... seems to be a resounding Yes from today's movie goers.  A very sad state of cinema expectations indeed.

So maybe that explains the high Parasite rating.  Is the general audience grading on a curve?  

Parasite is an entertaining enough film, but that's where it ends.  It isn't deep and it isn't memorable.  Its not ground-breaking, it doesn't have amazing acting, or fantastic visuals, or some crazy good plot line.  It really is just an OK film.  Its a sign that today's audience is in serious need of upping their standards.  Dig the bar out of the ground please.

For me, this movie was all over the place - the plot was overly bizarre, the themes and characters were not fully realized - it was hard to gather meaning from and left me with a bad taste in my mouth. I do however see the appeal - you get through the second act with no idea where the film is going to go, and then there is never a dull moment until the end. It is incredibly fresh and genre-bending. What genre is it? I don't know a little bit of everything it feels like. In the end, I didn't "enjoy" the film as much as I appreciated some of its incredible elements and moments. This is one of the few I disagree with the masses on.

"Parasite" shows us two families in completely different financial situations, however, the poor family's basement or the rich family's magnificent mansion do not support the atmosphere of this film.
"Parasite" is about the world of capital, where the lack of empathy, humanity and scruples rule the society completely flooded in the class struggle.
"Parasite" shows how the sunny and aromatic world of the upper class culturally sucks the energies of those who live and fight among themselves to survive from the crumbs that fall in the dark underworld of poverty.  Who are the parasites really?
Cannes Palme d'Or winner, "Parasite" is, without a doubt, the best picture at the Oscars 2020.

If this incredible, tense, immaculately constructed masterpiece doesn't win best picture this year (which it probably won't) there will be something terribly wrong. This is one of the greatest directors of all times best film and a razor sharp observation on class issues that rings painfully true. Bong's screenplay is fantastic, enticing us through every scene as the mystery and suspense builds to almost unbearable levels in the idyllic yet uneasy setting. The acting is top class and should all really be Oscar nominated as each character is developed and lethally uses in mouth watering situations building to a resonant finale that shocks and excites. Bong's direction is out of this world, almost luring the audience along with him towards the depths of despair and trapping us with genuinely funny humour. It's practically pitch perfect and the tone is immaculate throughout, you'll struggle to find a better film all year and it's only February.

Even though I did have to read subtitles as I do not speak Korean, it did not take me out of the movie.  If anything, it very much added to it.  Twists here and there that I did not expect and I walked out of the theater having a very good time.

Over-hyped and overlong, this film is a muddle that fails to deliver its basically pedestrian "hate the rich" message. The beginning was promising --- two families of four paired off against each other in a battle of wits --- but then the film confusingly introduces two more characters that threw the film out of balance and adds a gory, dark element that didn't fit the satire.  The poor family appears to be borderline special needs at the start of the film, yet turn into genius con artists by the midway point. What gives? This is the sort of movie that gets overpraised because it's foreign and "different" and then gets swollen further with praise by conformist movie critics afraid to say the film is mediocre.

A poor South Korean family grifts their way into the service of a rich family, and then it all falls apart. It's a wild fucking ride. The way the Kims integrate themselves into the lives of the Parks is fun to watch, if disturbing. They're cut-throat in the way they are willing to do anything to get ahead. It's a lens with which to look at class divide. It's really well made and paced. There's a couple of scenes so tense my butthole could have made a diamond. I struggled a bit with the ending, while a character's development was sort of there to justify it, I didn't think it quite earned it. I've got a lot of feelings I don't quite have the words for. I enjoyed it, it affected me quite a bit, but I'm not sure that I liked it as much as I wanted to. It was a little over hyped. I think I also came into it with a mindset that it was going to be more of a thriller like Get Out, and when it wasn't near that level I think I disappointed myself. It's more like a weird heist movie with some thriller elements. I appreciated it and I liked it but didn't love it.

Let me start by saying I'm an American who's been to South Korea many times and I understand the culture and politics quite well. further, my wife is from South Korea directly. This movie is seriously overhyped. I think many film critics and fans who knew nothing about the culture in South Korea just enjoyed the suspense thriller without putting any thought or analysis to why they liked it. No one's expecting a documentary when you're watching a suspense thriller but so many aspects of the plot were beyond contrived. I am going to post some spoilers in the next paragraph to point this out so please avoid the rest of this review if you don't want to know what happens. It is absolutely shocking this awful film is up for best picture of the year ### So we meet the Kim family, destitute & living in a cramped basement apartment. The mother father and their two adult children, none of them have a full-time job despite being educated, at least the children are. This is completely unrealistic in a modern city like Seoul. instead the family works together to fold pizza boxes to make their living? Ridiculous. The Park family has all this opulence and wealth, yet they seem completely incapable of getting any referrals or references for the various positions they need filled in their home? there's no way they would allow a family of grifters to come in and literally manipulate the family and get all the positions. to this end, this contrived plot line that Mrs Park is worried about her son and sees his art as a cry for help based on the fact that supposedly he saw a ghost when he was six in the house was nonsense. This film was popular among those who like to see class warfare. The poor Kim family appears to be not responsible for their crimes and it shows them as scrappy survivors who can outsmart and out manipulate the Park family when it suits them. One of the most ridiculous aspects of this, is that they're not successful or smart enough to fit into modern Korean society yet they have the sophistication and the planning to go into this elaborate lie and manipulation with the Park family? Near the end of the film, there is a huge rainstorm. Supposedly it is so bad, that the poor areas in Seoul are completely flooded out, including raw sewage being sprayed all over the Kim's apartment. This isn't 1960s South Korea and this is literally impossible in modern-day Seoul. It's sad and pathetic that this filmmaker, who's from the city, decides to put this metaphor into the plot as if the poor and downtrodden in the city are crapped upon by the elite. So in the middle of the night there's this horrible rain storm and the Kim family sneaks out in the middle of the night to go back to their own home. They did this without transportation walking or running in the streets assuming it's not such a short distance from the opulent neighborhood the Parks live in. after showing scenes of them in the home and trying to rescue some other things suddenly they're in some sort of city evacuation center with others spending the rest of the night? I don't think there's enough time in a day let alone the middle of the night to move around like this! The Park family wakes up and spontaneously decides to have a birthday party during the day for their son? No planning whatsoever and yet they get on the phone and tons of people show up along with catered food and musical accompaniment? Of course that morning they're also able to get the entire Kim family to come back to help out with the party? Could it get any more ridiculous? The filmmaker continues his thinly veiled hatred towards people of success by having the Park family have a native american-themed children's party for their son. with Mr Kim and the father supposedly dressed in his Indians with tomahawks to attack Kim's daughter as she brings out the cake in front of everyone...🙄 Suddenly, there's a lot of chaos and violence, which I'll leave mostly unexplored in this review, yet Mr Kim is insulted when Mr Park takes offense to the way another poor person smells and he decides to kill Mr Park! There's a whole other aspect to the film with a secret bunker under the home that the Park family is completely unaware of. considering there would be a real estate transaction for this home, there's no way they would be unaware of this major apparatus complete with running water and electricity below their own home that's accessible through a cabinet in their finished basement. This whole film is just an allegory by the director on how much hatred and contempt he has for people of success and wealth. He's crafted a film that has very little meaning, little purpose, inconsistent tone, and very basic acting that's not nearly as nuanced or interesting as others make it sound to be. For this film to be nominated for a best picture award and to win lots of other awards at other film competitions is a testament to how politics seeps into reviewers' minds. This director Bong Joon-ho has truly very little talent, yet the critics loved his film of a few years ago called Okja too. I really challenge anyone to watch that film as well as this one and conclude this filmmaker has anything worthy of sharing with an audience. Right now, Korean music, food, and culture are trendy, and I get it as there are many wonderful aspects to this country's rich and interesting traditions. yet a film like parasite is so polarizing and so preachy with its class warfare messages that the filmmaking seems completely secondary.

This movies is literally one of the best movies I've watched in my whole entire life. The story is something like we've never seen before, yet so  familiar. The perfect montage along with the soundtrack, which causes us a lot of anxiety and magnifies the main characters' wooden face, or a big turnaround in the script, containing once again, a montage, soundtrack and performances collaborating so that the scene is quite harmonious .
I never thought I'd be in any doubt if I hoped someone would do well or badly in the story.
I loved the experience, I loved the film and the social criticism it proposes about class difference, showing in a very discreet way the privileges of some and the lack of privileges of others.

Parasite starts out with a rather familiar gritty arthouse vibe. Some humor is sprinkled in as Ki-woo (Choi Woo-Shik) scans the ceiling and windows for some unprotected (or underprotected) wi-fi to steal as the unemployed family can't afford phone service and they need it to find work. Their partially underground dwelling is susceptible to various indignities from drunken pee and bug killing gasses to flood. When they do get a gig assembling pizza boxes, they can't seem to get it right for some reason. Their luck changes when Ki-woo's friend Min (Seo-joon Park) passes his tutoring job on to him. I little fib and a lot of confidence, and the money starts flowing in to the Kim family. But then he sees an in for his sister Ki-jung (So-dam Park). I suppose simply introducing her as his sister who is legitimately good at art might not have worked, so they go for a much bigger lie and paycheck. Greed is kicking in with head spinning intensity. Before long the family is doing things so atrocious, I started borderline hating the film. Because its protagonists are so unjustifiably vile. To be sure, I loved the parasite allegory. One gets in, starts multiplying, eventually severely damaging or destroying the host. That last part I was dreading the most. Yes, I was also dreading what will happen once the scam is discovered. But I felt really bad for the mother (Yeo-jeong Cho) who inadvertently brought the infestation into her home. She was just trying to do what any mother would - what's best for her kids. Her only fault - she wasn't too bright. Of course, I could have never anticipated the crazy plot twist that unraveled it all. But as the story rolled towards the end in a gut wrenching tangle of victims and perpetrators, the "host" family was treated as if their suffering were at best unimportant, at worst - funny. And they are the ones who did nothing wrong. Except for being rich - I suppose that automatically makes them villains. It was really bothering me. But that wasn't the only problem I had with the film. It didn't make sense to me how the Kims could come up with and perfectly execute an elaborate scheme, when they couldn't even assemble pizza boxes right. And if they are this smart, how is it possible that even the two young ones can't get work? Is Korean economy that bad? Another problem was that interesting things were introduced, but dropped without explanation. Like we never found out why the old housekeeper looked like she had been mugged. Or what Ki-woo was planning to do with the lucky stone. And that wonderful allegory that existed so naturally in the first half of the movie? Not completely gone in the second, but you have to look for it.

The first foreign-language movie to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. This modern classic from South Korean director Bong Joon-ho is a tragic comedy of class conflict that may be the contemporary version of Jean Renoir's masterpiece "The Rules of the Game." Set in Seoul, the impoverished Kim family schemes to infiltrate themselves into the employment of the wealthy Park family household. What begins as an "Upstairs, Downstairs" social satire descends into tragedy as class divisions collide in unexpected ways that erupts into horrifying violence. Like Renoir, Bong Joon-ho shows a masterful command of craft with a superbly fluid, lyrical use of composition. Some of the most indelible images: the Kim children crouched next to a toilet while searching for internet reception on their cell phones; flooded sewage water that leads the Kim family to spend the night with hundreds of displaced people at a gym; the Kim family quietly hiding under a table in the Park family living room, where the husband and wife lie on the sofa nearby complaining of the Kim's odor, then making love. Unanimously selected as the winner of the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival. Won Oscars for Best Picture, Director, Original Screenplay, International Feature Film. Written by Bong Jooh-ho and Han Jin-won. With Song Kang-ho, Lee Sun-kyun, Cho Yeo-jeong, Choi Woo-shik, Park So-dam. In Korean with English subtitles.
An absolute great writing and directing from Bong Jon Hoo, the actors are brilliant on Their interpretations and the final act proves that this film is an surprise knockout (on a good way)

Right now, matched with India, my favorite foreign land for cinema is Korea. When it comes to dark comedic thrillers, Korean cinema in one year releases more originality than Hollywood could hope to churn out in a lustrum. And from that enchanting land, Bong Joon-ho, one of the country's most celebrated directors, has a series of incredible films under his belt, several of which I have had the pleasure of viewing.

First, The Host (2006) was a different take on B-grade 1950s style monster movies, where sludge which is radioactive, toxic and vile, creates a creature feature wreaking havoc on Tokyo…er, Seoul. This is the biggest money-making movie in S. Korean history, and did very well for a short run here in the States. Just a few months after seeing The Host, a pal recommended to me Snowpiercer (2013), which has a ridiculous premise: all of humanity is on a train which travels around the planet, taking 1 year for each circumnavigation. My response: WTF? But my pal was right on, and Snowpiercer is brilliant; full of deep social commentary and a (rather) believable train system isolated and self-perpetuating for humanity's long haul through a frozen world. Oh, and it stars Captain America.

Now Bong Joon-ho's Parasite has crawled into theaters, and instead of creating sci-fi or mild horror, he has fully immersed himself in the dark comedy and dramatic thriller themes with several horrifying moments. Without giving anything away, a stroke of luck for a young man who should have been in college turns out to be, one-by-one, a stroke of luck for his sister, father and then mother. The whole family slyly takes over the important roles — tutors, driver and cook — of a credulous family of very wealthy snobs with their single-family enclave home built by a famous architect. Yet the home has secrets, and we see that the wealthy family's beaming innocence means they pass over crazy enigmas by, for instance, not even investigating what they call faulty wiring. Since it doesn't directly effect the shallow parents, these non-normal problems in the home hide sinister slumberings beneath the modern veneer.

At just the point where I began to ask myself where this film is going, a doorbell rings, and within moments all craziness breaks out, with around 30 minutes of close calls and comedic visualizations bested only by Roman Polanski's Fearless Vampire Killers (1967). Briefly, calm returns to the cast before the corkscrew ending, a bizarre sequence of uptight calumnies, 2 murders, a newsworthy missing person story, and an adventure in the value of being a Cub Scout.

Blending comedy and wound-up suspense is difficult for filmmakers to master, but Joon-ho is obviously a meticulous crafter, and the blending is balanced and feels natural. His well designed photographic sequences make for a blend of vibrancy and subtlety, each where needed. The meticulousness of the film includes the fantastic home in the movie being built from scratch, entirely designed and built just for this flick.

The day it comes to Blu-ray or streaming, I will once again be visiting Korea.  And once again I will have one of its most brilliant filmmakers as my guide.

Bong Joon-ho's South Korean dark comedy Parasite (2019) may be 2019's best film with Bong's creative and innovative direction matching his and Han Jin-won's searing witty script. Bong's stylish direction gives Parasite a brisk pace and makes a 132 minute long film feel like 20 minutes. Parasite features hilarious joke after joke played with a deadpan lethargy like the horrible people acting out awful deeds just bare a nonchalant attitude about it all. I cannot overstate how refreshing Parasite is both as a genius piece of arthouse cinema, but also a very contemporary comedy of errors.

Bong's direction is fun and playful as he successfully subverts what the audience is expecting with outrageous twists and shocking reveals. The house escape sequence is painstakingly crafted and suspenseful like an old Hitchcock classic. Meanwhile, Bong's dry humor befits his sweeping and precise direction for the comedy scenes, like the poverty flood sequence, wherein absurdist nonsense occurs all to convey Bong's overarching metaphor of this South Korean family leeching off of an affluent and apathetic wealthy household like a parasite themselves.

Bong's scathing satire is entertaining in his near surreal sense of humor to his biting social commentary on South Korea's income inequality. He effortlessly juxtaposes a carefree family living in an opulent manor atop a hill within an expensive neighborhood with the poor family's destitute existence barely surviving within their messy semi-basement home at the bottom of the hill. Hong Kyung-pyo's cinematography feels like every shot was thought out beforehand with endless precision and care. Yang Jin-mo's editing is so precise and wicked as he flies the audience all around this luxury home with cunning cuts. I really like Jung Jae-il's score of beautiful harmony and dissonant disruptions.

You will want to kill the rich as your indignation for the upper classic grows with every shallow pointless move made by the lucky few, while the many impoverished characters literally fight for survival with desperate cunning and ruthless ambition only possible by living in abject poverty. Bong makes his rich into people living in light and comfort, while the poor are subservient insects that crawl around like worthless bugs. Parasite is so sublime because it can be watched for pure entertainment value of a sly poor family manipulating gullible elites into paying them for various services, but Parasite also wades in deep waters of sympathy for its poor desperate souls.

I could go on about the masterful craftsmanship of Parasite, but I really want to mention the phenomenal cast of Parasite. They each play very particular roles and deliver precise and riveting performances with a memorable charm and playful deviousness. Song Kang-ho kills it as Kim "Mr. Kim" Ki-taek. His versatile portrayal ranges from casual relaxation, paternal care, to vicious desperation. Song is just too funny to me. His every facial expression is carefully chosen and executed like a comedic pendulum. Lee Sun-kyun is loathsome as the callous and ignorant Park "Mr. Park" Dong-ik. Likewise, Choi Woo-shik is hilarious in his lackadaisical leading performance as Ki-woo a.k.a. "Kevin." You are endeared to him immediately, but it's his acting fascinates you with every moment and word. I must commend Chang Hyae-jin for her tough and fearsome performance as the fearless mother Chung-sook. By the same note, Lee Jung-eun is fun as the spiteful and two-faced Moon-gwang.

Cho Yeo-jeong is hilarious as the gullible and ignorant rich wife Yeon-kyo "Madame". She effortlessly plays the overly worrisome and obnoxious fake with a stunning flabbergasted face. She truly beautiful in Parasite, but it's her genuinely laugh out loud funny performance that had me constantly roaring. I adore Choi Se-yeon's stunning costumes for Cho Yeo-jeong. Similarly, Jung Ji-so is wonderful as the sweet and gentle daughter Da-hye. I must admit I completely fell in love with Ki-jung a.k.a. "Jessica from Chicago" played by the lovely Park So-dam. Her flawless performance in Parasite is my favorite aspect of this delightful indie film. Park is so charming, endearing, and sly as a fox with her quick-thinking, criminal chameleon.

Overall, Parasite is an outstanding South Korean dark comedy that will stand up to the ages as Bong Joon-ho's immaculate direction and scorching script alone with preserve Parasite. Let alone Parasite's god tier ensemble of talented actors and actresses transforming themselves into clever charlatans and the disgustingly affluent.

*NO SPOILER REVIEW BELOW* If you have not seen this movie, go watch it now. Now now now now. Do not read anything about it, do not watch the trailer, do not read a summary, or even this review. Go watch.

*SPOILER FILLED REVIEW BELOW*
This should win the Oscar for the best Picture. Hands down. There is no other movie nominated that says so much, with so much depth to it's message. The cast is so impeccably acted, and The Score is John Williams-esque. It is as close to a perfect movie as I've seen since Mad Max: Fury Road, or Moonlight, or maybe Lady Bird(alright I guess I'm diminishing it, but those movies are fucking good is all I'm saying!). 

This movie is a movie about income inequality plain and simple. It's pretty obvious, it doesn't try to pretend to be pretentious or im14andthisisdeep. You start off with an extremely poor family who live in what seems to be the slums of South Korea. The first act is giving you an idea of this family's dynamics, everyone's role. The cast has such incredible chemistry, not in a million years would you be able to guess  they weren't a real family if they were put in a police lineup and then were to go on about their day as everyone watched. 

You would think nothing would ever break this family apart. and that's kinda the point. This family aspires desperately for a wealthier future, but given the choice between wealth and family, they would always pick the latter. Basically, the Son has a friend he grew up with who is going to study abroad. His family is wealthy enough to go to university and he wanted to give his old tutoring job to the son. 
At first, you think, "What a good friend. He basically gave this easy tutor job to his down on his luck childhood friend since the tutoring is for a young girl whose family is extremely well off". 
The friend then explains he's been tutoring this young girl for 2 years. Meaning she was in 8th grade (Junior High in the US) when he started tutoring her as he was in college. The protagonist asks why would he offer him this opportunity and not a friend from college who has the type of resume they would be looking for? 

In his explanation, you begin to see a beginning to the conflicts within this film. He first seems to be thoughtful because he doesn't want to his rich fratty/douchy friends getting anywhere near this sweet, innocent young girl. He goes on to say, he wants to ask her out when he gets back from abroad, because she will be in college then. He won't have to worry about the protagonist stealing this girl from him.

Showing what he truly thinks of his childhood friend, explaining how the mother is "simple" so you won't have to try very hard to get the job. Now this doesn't seem to be ill-guided, I don't think he meant anything by it at all. This is just the first example the movie shows of the gap between the rich and the poor. 

I'm not gonna explain the whole movie, but the protagonist and his family go on to con the rich family into having all of their caretaker, driver, and tutoring jobs. Unknown to the rich family that they are all related or even know each other. 

Any problem the rich family may encounter from the poor family or any outside conflicts, it's as simple as a phone call, request, or an extra tip to "the help" and their worry is gone. 

Where as the poor family is at a constant battle or struggle to keep the facade up while they have the first well paying jobs in years. Any conflict or problem faced by the poor family is a level of stress that the rich family would never bother to imagine due to the privilege they have lived. 

As the movie goes on, every family member in the rich family, life gets better with the help of the protagonists family. The father learns to be a better husband and father. The mother has a better relationship with her husband and children. 

Without a single inkling of the con the poor family has pulled. 

Every single time the poor family's lives seem to be on the up and up, something drags them back down. Something being the solution to the rich family's problem or annoyances. 

In the end, it doesn't matter how nice the rich family is, how friendly, how much they tip, how much they offer. It's not a solution to problems plaguing the poor or impoverished. It's simply an out, a way to make themselves get satisfaction of being a "good" person. 

It's like seeing a homeless person and you think it's sad or depressing. You assume they are a drunk, an addict, or a criminal, that's how they got there. *I* wasn't the reason he's there. *I* didn't do that to him. *I* gave a nice tip to the taxi driver, or the waiter, or the guy busking by the subway the other day. 

And that's the main idea here. No one wants to take the blame, and at this point, you can't blame people who aren't the richest of the rich. This stuff started A LONG time ago... but does that mean you get to sit around and do nothing about it? I mean *You* didn't put those people there, right? 

Climate Change wasn't *me*, that was the big oil corporations. What am I supposed to do about that? 

Well, maybe if that is the answer you keep getting. I think this film wants us to stop asking that same question. Maybe it's time for us to ask, "why does it have to be this way?". Maybe if we start asking that, then *WE* can start to under what we are supposed to do about it.

This is one of the greatest movies ever made; it's probably in the top ten. The film is virtually flawless. Everything is perfect, and the cinematography is my favorite part. The film has some of the best cinematography I've ever seen, and it must win the Oscar for cinematography. The performances are great, but my favorite is given by Song Kang-Ho. His performance is just so raw, and it feels real. But everybody in the movie was great, I thought everybody did good. The film is incredibly written, and the film shifts well. There is a certain point where the movie goes from a well crafted satire, to a completely suspenseful thriller. The second half is where the movie began to really intrigue me, and that's saying a lot, considering the first half never bored me. Bong Joon Ho directed this movie; it was probably the best directing I have seen all year. This man is a master filmmaker, and has made some truly amazing movie over the past decade. This is his best work, and I think it's going to be very hard for him to surpass. As far as issues go, I had not one. It's an incredible movie, and everything is incredible. It's a movie that has a lot of symbolism, and I cannot wait to watch many times and analyze. It's a masterpiece, and a movie that I think everyone should watch. It's sheer cinematic bliss.

Parasite is a dark comedy thriller film directed by Bong Joon-ho. It depicts the contrasting lives of the Park family who lives a much wealthier life than the Kim family who lives in a basement. Kim Ki-Hoo was asked by his friend to tutor the daughter of the Park family. This became the path for the Kim family to weasel themselves in the Park household. A stormy night and a cancelled camping trip leads to open a few secrets of the Park's house. The sun always shines after the storm but also a good pool of blood.
Excellent commentary on disparity within Korean social classes through an ecosystem lens, using parasitism, mutualism, and competition as analogies for various relationships depicted in the film.
Good comment on the haves/have nots

Utterly ridiculous and extremely engaging, Parasite is a film that makes the audience laugh and question the current social status of modern society today. The story follows a poor family who (due to poverty) infiltrates a rich, upper-class household by conning them into taking them in as their hired help. Bong Joon Ho's surgical execution of shots partnered with the film's rhythm synced perfectly with the poor family's precise planning and execution of deeds to leech off the rich. And when we thought unconventional protagonists have truly won, an unbelievable twist occured, setting the film in a roller coaster like rhythm of events again. 


The satirical portrayal of the rich left me chuckling because of exaggerated but accurate protrayal of rich people who are self-absorbed and couldn't care less about others.

The only thing I'd like for the film to fix was the build up of the driver's rage up to the stabbing part. For me I think it needed work in establishing his hatred more so the ending will be smooth. 

Overall I loved the film and would recommend it to others

Unpredictably composed, Parasite effortlessly shifts between several genres, evenly mixing comedy with tragedy and several stops in between. Of the versatile tools in that particular box, the film's at its best on the frequent occasions that it ratchets up the tension. I constantly caught myself holding in a deep breath, completely immersed in the moment and conflicted about the best possible outcome. Not all of those nail-biters lead to fireworks, and the film is careful not to overplay its hand, so that, when the time is right, those inevitable explosions land like a flurry of unexpected body blows.

The first hour is captivating, as the leeches' shady plot comes together and their long con gains momentum, but the home stretch, with its string of sharp curves and grim consequences, is unrestrained chaos in the best of ways. One helluva ride.

A masterful work of storytelling that is both intricate and all-encompassing, “Parasite” mixes an array of genres as it navigates overlying themes of class and social differences. Director Bong Joon-Ho seamlessly blends humor and suspense into a wild story, complete with twists and turns that you never see coming. Not a moment goes by where you’re not fully engaged in the film, a testament not only to Joon-Ho, but the equally stellar cast who give life to such relatable characters that you feel as if you know them. Fantastic in all aspects, Parasite shows the immense skill of foreign directors, so even if you don’t like to read subtitles….”이 영화 보러가 (Go watch this film.)”

The movie was about moral degenerates with no redeeming qualities. That scamming family really was horrible, they really were parasites. I thought the plot twist would be they would grow to care for and protect the Park family, so it'd be more like mutualism than parasitism. Like those little fish that clean the shark's teeth. The brother was a scumbag. He was entrusted the HS girl by his buddy who gave him the rock gift and introduced the job opportunity to him. Not to mention he intended to murder the other family with the rock. The father's whole philosophy about having no plan being the infallible plan I disagree with, that's just an excuse for being impulsive and lazy, which is what they are- complete losers. In fact all of the philosophy of that movie I disagree with- that poverty is an excuse for moral depravity. Morality is absolute, not situational and not relative. I got the deeper philosophical point of the movie, I just disagree. The crazy basement guy had motive other than being crazy. And the father had even less logical reason to go berserk. Sure maybe he was upset that his daughter was hurt and Mr. Park only cared about his family and his son, but if his main concern was his daughter he would've grabbed the keys and the daughter and driven her off- not tossed the keys and stabbed the guy and made things worse. It just seemed like gratuitous violence for the sake of empty shock value. The ending was somewhat okay- there was a redemption of values when the son said his approach was to work hard earn money and buy the house so the father can be free- and the father in the meantime lives a life in "jail" indefinitely.

As a teenager, I have been infatuated with cinematography and films since I was young. My father, who was practically an amateur critic, would showcase and present me his favorite feature films that he had progressed and expanded in his life of several decades. He rates movies and declares on watching them in a conceited method. Using movie ratings, any movie that seems to have approached over 80% on Rotten Tomatoes, he would give it a watch. Any movie over 90%, he would definitely watch. Any movie under any of those ratings, he believes it as waste of time. With this unhealthy mentality being exposed to me ever since I was a kid, my criticism for films has come to become overwhelmingly harsh. My ratings for films would be far lower than the average viewer that I conversed/interacted/viewed. I would dock points and be disappointed for a film if I had noticed a flaw of any kind, small or big. For almost 18 years, I have watched films. And I have begun to think that I had the special mind of a "critic" where it was far more challenging to impress me in any aspect compared to the average viewer. Sure, this mentality may cause many people to think that I was simply a picky, foolish teenager that was far too cocky with their tastes. I have recognized this. But it was reasonable to a certain extent. I tend to think about films as they progress and surprisingly, 100% of all films I have watched, I would always be left slightly or far disappointed because I was able to predict/expect how the film was to reach its peak or how it was to end. A clear example is the film Knives Out. A mystery film released in late 2019, it has received spectacular reviews. Many say that it was one of the best films they have watched in their life. I had the chance to watch it the past week with high expectations. My experience was a complete contrast to that of the reviews. Unfortunately, I was practically able to depict how the film was going to resolve, who the "perpetrator" was, and so on much before its climax. Maybe if I had watched the film without analyzing every shot, I would have enjoyed the film. But this is who I am. I do this and that is how I watch films. Of course, the film industry has evolved into a market that is pervaded with halfwitted big-budget CGI films for viewers with quite simple mindsets of having an effortless fun experience at the movies with friends or family, which I cannot stress, is perfectly fine. But for viewers such as me, who love to analyze films and watch them like it if it was a form of art, the modern generation of filmography has become far bland, with most being - ahem* excuse me - shit. From big-budget, low effort Chinese funded films to "popular" trendy "superhero" films, the market has evolved into something that was not a delightful experience for me. This directly connects to my initial mentality. I have watched many many classics ranging from a multitude of genres. With a father with a strict process of watching and rating films, I have fetched a similar mentality, possibly far more stern and harsh than one of my father's. But because our generation of films has degraded in quality, in the artistic aspect anyway, it is rare for me to have given a film that is over a 9/10 on my rating scale. In fact, I have practically accepted that a movie that was so perfect to have received a 10/10 on "my" scale would be virtually infeasible. In the hundreds of reviews I have written for films, there was some sort of negative nitpicking that had left me unsatisfied "perfectly". This, as a result, has left me to accept that I could never be fully 100% satisfied with any film in the upcoming future or in the near past.

But today, everything has changed. A few hours ago, I was able to receive the opportunity to watch the film Parasite directed and written by Bong Joon-Ho. I have watched many of Bong's films from the classic The Host - which I can confidently recommend to many people - to Okja, his most recent film, linked and partnered with Netflix. After watching Okja, I was left immensely disappointed and I am quite guilty to say that I had lost all respect for Bong's spectacular storytelling and cinematography. But after watching Parasite today, I could accept that is by the far the best film I have watched in my life and I have gained this newfound respect, far massive than something I had before.

I went inside the theaters with exceedingly high expectations and as it began, I formed many scenarios of how it was to resolve and thinking of how I could match this film to a genre. Not once in my life, even after watching hundreds of classics that so-called "revolutionized" the film industry, have I became so immersed with the film to have been left disappointed that the film had ended. It was almost as if I was able to finally "feel" the great emotion of being amazed by a film, so much that it would leave me with "no words". As the film caught on, I completely forgot about my habit of "analyzing" due to the immense immersion I was in and for the first time, I was able to have the reaction to that of the average viewer. I believe that the Parasite is far superior to any classic film that people believe that revolutionized Hollywood. Many resort to saying that Hitchcock was the ultimate film director, completely revolutionizing cinematography using his new-wide skills of contemporary film shots and robust scenarios. But what Bong did was something much more than that. In a generation where everything has been discovered and finding a new creative method to film something is unrealistic, that is what Bong has done with Parasite. What Bong did was that rather than creating a simple "good" film with fine acting and fine screenplay writing and fine cinematography, he has invented a new genre of films. He has truly revolutionized the modern film industry, something that I believed was simply irrational to even consider. Parasite has defeated me. I could not predict it not once. I could not even consider how it was to go on. The only question I had the entire film was "Okay, what the hell is next? Where is this going? How the fuck can you even end this?". But in fact, he did end it. And it was not a disappointing one. It left me with an open mouth. No words. I would sit through the entire credits without saying or moving. I was just thinking to myself "Holy fucking shit.". On the drive home, I was thinking "Holy fucking shit.". For many hours at home after, I was thinking "Holy fucking shit.".

I did have one disappointing thought about the film. And it was not about the film at all. As a Korean-American, who is very very familiar with Korean culture and being able to fluently speak it as well, I was able to watch it with ease without translations. Parasite is a Korean film. And because it was a Korean film, it was a film derived from Korean culture. As I watched the film, I could only be left disappointed that for some scenarios, the translations strayed away from its original meaning. But I cannot complain, some parts of Korean culture and language are just not possible to translate on paper perfectly for American viewers. That is my disappointment. I am sad that American viewers, who do not understand the Korean language or culture, cannot spectate the film as I have, who fully understood the hints that only one of a Korean viewer could catch. (As a side note for American viewers who were unfamiliar with Korean language or culture and you happen to learn or become familiar with Korean culture or language, I highly recommend that you watch it once more, it just makes the film so much better and polished.)

Regarding the film, I could write pages and pages about my internal thoughts about the film. In fact, I am confident that I could write an entire book regards to my reaction and thoughts about the film. But it is pointless. When you attempt to explain this film to another, you cannot. The only way to know is to have watched it yourself. I cannot review this film. I cannot explain this film simply as a viewer. I cannot talk about how "good" the plot was or how "good" the screenplay was. It was none of those things. It was just….how would I say it…..a film made by Bong and only Bong. My final thought? The only thing I can say is to fucking watch it.

Rating: 10/10









Note: I have noticed that it has been nominated for Oscar's best picture as well. I have watched every nominee film (except for Little Women which I will hopefully be able to watch before the Oscar's). Any other film, in comparison to the Parasite is complete child's play. It is like comparing a film made by a high school freshman to that of a professional. While I am aware that the chances of a foreign film winning an Oscar Best Picture are very slim, I hope it holds out as I believe that the traction it may cause may once again inspire the film market to create new contemporary films so that I can once again, possibly rate another film a 10/10 in the future. Parasite has given me hope that film can evolve once more. I am selfish. And once could perceive me as cocky and a brainless immature teenager. But I could not give one fuck. Just fucking watching the film.

Parasite reminded me of children's book series, Goosebumps, providing a sense of multiple authors, sketches strung together in a pattern of "and-then, and-then, and-then" attempting to maintain interest. Perhaps character-growth is a cultural expectation of literature and film--Parasite began with anticipation of "the first shall be last and the last, first," though the idea went unrecognised. Parasite has a mild overarching story, and no character growth (reportedly a mark of the writer's). Actors rival any community cast, providing good caricature renderings. Writer reportedly decided how to end the film while waiting for a crosswalk signal in Vancouver--a measure of the apparent care applied to rendering the story.

It is always exciting to see what the Frenchies decided was film of the year as it never fails to be a better pic than whatever the Hollywood menagerie showers with a critical accolades come Springtime. Little did I expect Cannes Film Festival to award the prestigious Palme D'or this year to a director who has been one of my least favorite filmmakers...until now. Bong Joon-ho's English film debut, 2013's SNOWPIERCER, struck me as overrated and dumb while 2017's OKJA was cartoonish and ham-fisted. It didn't help that he'd relegated two of my favorite actors, Tilda Swinton and Jake Gyllenhaal, to cringe-inducing career-low sideshow performers. Besides that, I just couldn't vibe with his grotesque and bumbling concoction of family-friendly cuteness, ultra violence, and quirky humor. It reeked of trying too hard and failed to land with me at every turn. With that said, let me be the first and most surprised person to say with no reservations PARASITE is easily one of the best movies I've seen this year.

However, there's the other genetically engineered super pig in the room: PARASITE has an awful lot in common with last year's Palme D'or winner SHOPLIFTERS. Putting aside that the former is a Korean production and the latter was Japanese, both films follow the lives of a poor family as they struggle on the fringes of society, running cons and scams to get by in a callous world. They are held together by their honest love for one another, and their example is set juxtaposed to the neglectfulness of a consumerist society that allows so many to fall through the cracks in the first place.

But the main way that Joon-ho one-up's his award-winning predecessor is with an incisive sense of humor suffused in each character, a humor that is immediately, physically translatable despite the language barrier. It works here so well precisely because it's reigned in and understated throughout the film, making the more manic parts hit harder - such as when Park So-Dam apathetically lights a cigarette on a lidded toilet spewing flooded sewage out the sides. The class conscious themes that have pervaded Joon-ho's science fiction offerings up to this point are given a much greater sense of immediacy and relatability as we watch this struggling family elbow their way into the good graces of a rich, privileged, and naive family. Beside the obvious "haves vs. have-nots" one would expect from this scenario, there's clearly an exploration of the structures that relegate people into servitude and poverty for generations, not just by the wealthy elite but by the pervasive mechanisms of misfortune that are maintained by the working class as we claw at each other's throats for short-term gain.

Believe the hype, PARASITE is well deserving of the praise it has received thus far. It's tense, hilarious, and poignant, and I'm forced to genuinely re-evaluate this director's output knowing that he knocked it out of the park this time.

Many people lack a desire to watch this movie, all because of its subtitles, but director Bong Joon-ho said at his acceptance speech at the Golden Globes for Best Foreign Film, "Once you overcome the 1-inch tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films". Puzzled about the rave response to this film. There is nothing particularly original about the plot or the characterizations. The acting and direction are fine. The settings are interesting to say the least. The film unfolds somewhat like "Shoplifters"--impoverished but clever people who are holding the short end of the stick under our world-wide inequitable economic and social systems. The families in both films scrape by through guile while existing in a semi-underground setting (literally--their living quarters are below street level--and socially, they are disconnected from the fruits of bourgeois society, with no apparent prospects of climbing the ladder). "Parasite" begins well enough but soon drifts into an atmosphere of tension fostered by the creepy machinations of the family members--who seem to have no compunction in betraying the family friend who provides the reference affording them access to the wealthy household. The marks in their con game seem like decent enough folk given their typical (for their class) obliviousness to the inequities in the socioeconomic system that has rewarded them with luxury while forcing the less fortunate to grub out whatever existence they can manage. The film establishes no real basis for the destitute family's turn to enmity, or for that matter to abject stupidity with a beggars banquet farce that sets off the cataclysmic climax. The revelation of the safe room/fall-out shelter with its demented underground occupant may constitute a plausible metaphor for a number of things, including a rage that could rightfully simmer in the consciousness of exploited and repressed humanity. The cowboy and Indian farce no doubt has its own intended symbolic import. But the homicidal melee that concludes the film's action unfortunately reflects a deficit of imagination, at the same time suggesting the filmmakers' possible contempt for an audience that has been drawn in with a plot that early on masquerades as social comedy. The characters devolve into stick-figures in what amounts to little more than a nihilistic allegory.

The poor are most commonly shown rising to a higher socioeconomic class in films through becoming gun toting gangsters or being so nice and optimistic that some rich person takes pit on them. In this offbeat film our out of work, lower class protagonists do commit crimes by fraudulently claiming to have credentials that they do not possess but present themselves as tutors and cooks not drug dealers or pimps. We are inclined to be sympathetic to these people who are terribly disadvantaged and struggle to make a living but they are conniving and cruel to those lower than them when given the slightest taste of power. This forces us to consider whether to take on some rather indefensible moral positions or realize that there are few moral absolutes when it comes to matters of class warfare.

The Kim family live in one tiny house together in a neighborhood full of other unemployed people who are looked down upon by the nearby upper class. Their lives change when their intelligent son Ki-Woo, Choi Woo-Shik, is offered a job by his friend as a tutor for a member of the Park family, the wealthy Da-hye, Jeong Ji-so, who is the daughter of entrepreneur Dong-ik, Lee Sun-kyun. He has his crafty sister Ki-jeong, Park So-dam, create a fake university diploma for him and takes up the job after fooling her gullible mother Yeon-gyo, Cho Yeo-jyong. Soon the family decides that they will have to remove the existing employees of the Parks so that they can obtain jobs. They lie to them and claim that they are not related but when they remove longtime housekeeper Moon-gwang, Lee Jung-eun, she returns to help her husband Geun-sae, Park Myung-hoon, who has been secretly hiding in a bunker under the house for years. This causes conflict between the two families and when a party is held tensions erupt between the three different groups.

The title of the film was deceptive in a way as I expected this film to be a traditional horror in which an animal takes hold of the bodies of several people and tries to take over the world but the film was far from that. Yet the title still fits as without knowing it the Parks and their mansion is slowly infected by this lower class family who may seem benevolent and unassuming but present a real threat when left to their own devices. The somewhat dim Yeon-gyo is a product of her upbringing as we assume she has always been a member of the idle rich and has never been forced to claw her way up the food chain in order to gain wealth or security. Ki-Woo's mother Chung-sook, Chang Hyae-jin, is exactly the opposite as she has been forced to scrounge for whatever money she can get and actively pressures those around her to provide for her. This desperation may not be becoming but if we are honest it is what most poor people who were able to become wealthy by some miracle probably had. One must be ruthless in most situations to come out on top and when we meet Chung-sook and her family they have already experienced so much horror than they are completely cynical.

These qualities make it hard for us to like them as while Yeon-gyo is rich and an airhead she does not appear to take advantage of anybody and her ignorance is perhaps her worst trait. It is when the poor family find themselves with a measure of wealth and power when the Parks vacate their home for a few days that their true colors come out. With the return of Moon-gwang and the discovery of her husband in the bunker Chung-sook is given the option of either helping somebody in need of a break or handing her over to the police so that she and her family can enjoy the luxuries of the house alone. She takes the first option and is cruel to the former housekeeper even when she begs on her knees for some mercy. Then the tables are turned and there is a delicious moment in which the begging Moon-gwang gains the upper hand and her entire demeanor changes. These shifts in power occur throughout the film and allow us to consider what power does to people as they seem to lose their empathy when they gain it.

There are points where the film drags a little bit and I do not know if I would have made the epilogue quite so lengthy but the film is fascinating to dissect and deserves to be one of the most discussed of the year.

Rich people, in that sense, are indeed a bit more "naive" because they do not know how it feels to not even have the basic needs met; but it's also this deeply engrained difference, that made this minor overheard comment of the smell lead to the death of Mr Park (because that implies, that the Kim family never has a chance of really being part of the upper class). Like a long drive on a sunny day and happening upon a thundercloud, that got dark quick. Parasite is a Korean film with a tightly directed story and a social message. Social stratification is made manifest in dozens of ways as our basement dwelling Kim family grifts their way into the upscale hilltop home of the Park family. It becomes particularly interesting as the movie reveals literally another level that sees no daylight at all. The movie has many layers, including one of being a basic thriller.  Yep, that's blood. Kang-ho Song is particularly effective as the Kim family patriarch.  All this said, I am not sure how much I emotionally resonated with the Kim family or Mr. Kim in particular. Is the rain of crap from the rich to the poor a karmic comeuppance (poor cheaters bad) or the director commentary on how the storms do not affect the well-heeled as a kind of criticism of the system they live in (wealthy clueless bad)? Bits of brilliance but a little heavy. Never before has a coffee table been so significant in cinema.

this is a very touching movie about human psychology. when people are in desperation, their brains will trigger drastic adaption. This can be for both good and bad things. In the beginning of the movie.... (spoiler alert -- you have been warned) the poor family was in great desperation for survival. Anyone in this survival mode usually become very creative in problem-solving, focused, calm, disciplined, and motivational. The poor family with this adaptive mindset taught themselves everything they need in order to survive. They successfully did this. However, they went a little to the extreme, which is not realistic in real life. Again, this is a movie, so we need to see an extreme example. Otherwise, this movie won't be worth watching. The poor family took an extreme approach and achieved a great success. However, in life, easy comes easy goes, and this literally happened. What happened next is literally a moral conflict between two poor families trying to survive. In stead of co-operation, which, in reality, most people do. These poor people chose a path to win-lose situation. Again, this is a movie, in real life, most people would come up with win-win solution, but this wouldn't make a great movie. As a result, the two families clashed into a win-lose... I mean... lose-lose situation. Devastation for not only the two poor families but the hosts also. The biggest takeaway is that people in desperation are very creative and will do whatever it takes because they are in survival mode.

I realize that I am not reviewing a film. I am reviewing a seamless, masterful medley of different genres of film all rolled into one. Parasite has elements of sidesplitting comedy, seat-clenching thriller, riveting drama and more. And they all have their time in the sun thanks to the spectacular juggling act by Bong Joon Ho. The filmmaker is so present in every scene- nay, in every shot. All of the film's technical elements meshed together in one of the most well-oiled machines I have ever seen on screen. I'll break down some of these in detail, but it bears repeating that Bong displays master craftsmanship in this textbook definition of a passion project.

The foundation of every film is its screenplay, and this one by Bong and Han Jin Won is exceptional. Aside from the aforementioned genre blending, this script tackles ever present themes of class warfare, social mobility, greed, manipulation, and power, to name a few. The icing on this cake is the highly witty and clever dialogue, which expertly delivers humor and theme at the same time. 

The ensemble cast deserves far more recognition and praise than it is currently receiving. There was truly not one weak link. Every actor had shining moments where they displayed a layered, highly developed character. The standout is clearly Song Kang-ho, playing the father of the Kim family (arguably the protagonist). He displays the most vivid and defined character arc throughout the cast. A personal favorite of mine has to be Park So-dam, who played Ki-jung (Jessica) also of the Kim family. Her scenes earned well deserved laughter from the audience in my theater; the way she repeatedly bowls over Mrs Park is hilarious and memorable.

Of all the masterful technical elements, the one that is most deserving of praise is the production design by Lee Ha-jun. The sets were so crucial to the storytelling and themes, and the detail that went into them provided so much. It bears mentioning that both the dirty alleyway of the Kim's home and the gorgeous home of the Parks were both built *entirely* from scratch. These two locations provided great insight into the circumstances of the two families, and the contrast between the two was thematically brilliant. The Park home in particular was superb; the cinematography (Hong Gyeong-pyo) completely immersed the audience in an intimate way. Alongside the design is the excellence of the editing. Mark my words- the montage where the Kims are plotting against the Parks' maid will be in film school masterclasses for decades to come. Finally, the music by Jung Jae-il greatly assisted in the film's constant shifting between moods and tones. 

The one qualm I have with this film is that the rewatchability is somewhat low. But this is acceptable, given that the first time watch value is so incredibly high. Parasite is a technical marvel as well as a downright entertaining roller coaster. If you see only one film this awards season, make it Parasite.

Bong Joon Ho's latest, "Parasite", is a very well done film. I've seen most of his work and this is definitely an enjoyable witty and dark ride.

A black comedy of immense social relevance, not to mention heart-pounding tension, Parasite has been hailed as one of the best films of 2019, and I'm not about to argue with that. A tale of finding work to support your family soon becomes something entirely more bleak and sinister than the premise would suggest, and the longer the films goes on the more disturbing things become. Bong Joon Ho is a director with an eye for the unique and usual, and he holds nothing back here. I love how different it is, I love how well its acted, how deceptively clever the seemingly simple script is, and I love how it constantly feels like its building to something. Many of the moments take you by complete surprise, and some scene had me on the edge of my seat with my breath firmly caught in my throat. It fits into a lot of genres, such as family drama, satire, horror, slasher, but what it is above all else is a social critique. Is a commentary on the mixing of social classes, on the governments abuse of the proletariats, on the shifting dynamics of a family in poverty? It could be all of them, or it could be none of them. The film is very much open to interpretation, but I definitely see is as an allegory for the divide between the affluent and the poor, and how rarely the opposing ends of the social spectrum can be united. Whatever message you glean from it, there's no doubting that the film is yet another remarkable movie that the Writer/Director can add to his already stellar resume. Remember the name, Bong Joon Ho.

After big films such as Okja and Snowpiercer, South Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-ho comes back with another great original story that borrows from black comedy, horror and drama that acts as a social commentary on the division of classes. In it, unemployed members of a family take interest in the wealthy and glamorous Park family until things take a very unexpected turn. A gripping story that makes the strong distinction of social classes an exaggerated conflict and that never allows the viewer to guess what is going to happen next. It keeps you at the edge of your seat wondering what will become of these eccentric and complicated characters when meddling with the thin line that divides rich and poor. Good luck at the awards season, but it will not need it! 🇰🇷

I went into this without as much knowledge about the film as I should have. I vaguely knew that it was a dark comedy/thriller, and truthfully, not much else. I can say that this is the first time in a long time I have been so blown away by a film. Not only was the dark and absurd humor mesmerizing, but once again Bong Joon-Ho (who I didn't realize was the director until I got home and looked up the film) presents us with an all too familiar look at the brutal reality of class division. While it appears satirical, those of us with experience as part of the working class know all to well the things we would do to support our families. The acting was phenomenal, the cinematography brilliant, the script sensational. And props for great food porn as well.

I'm a huge fan of films; I watch many over each year. This film is undoubtedly the best movie I've watched in 2019.

It's a genre-defying film—it makes you laugh hysterically in one scene to crying with a whirlpool of emotion in another. It's a rollercoaster ride with incredible screenplay and directing. Additionally, the score makes the film even more exhilarating and you're intensely gripped with what is happening from one scene to the next that you cannot turn away. Perhaps it is for this reason I have watched this film four times, and each time I find myself laughing, tensed up, shocked, sobbing in the same scenes. The magic of this film never dies away. If anything, rewatching it showcases smart details that Director Bong has included that may have gone unnoticed before. 

From the cast to the score to the director, the film is incredible. Song Kang Ho showcases such genuine emotion that you forget that this is a fictional script. All actors and actresses fervently commit to their roles and you see them as genuinely human. There are no villains here, which is why it makes the film so captivating. You don't know who you are rooting for or who you should be rooting for. The set of the movie is also noteworthy—they created the poor neighborhood and the rich house from scratch!

While this movie is in Korean, the movie explores a theme centered around class-struggle that is universal. The movie is centered around a rich family and a poor family, and how their lives eventually intertwine. You get to understand their family dynamics, economy, and their hopes (and also hopelessness). Even if you're not Korean, you will connect to this film. It's a film about people and socioeconomic classes, among other things.

You'll do yourself a disservice if you don't watch this movie! It's an incredible experience, and I can not recommend it enough. There is a reason why this movie is gaining worldwide success and award recognition. And it deserves all the attention it is getting. Director Bong has produced many of the best cinematic experiences in Korea. This one is an extraordinary one.

A positive aspect (but not enough to explain Parasite success) is that the film takes a dramatic and surprising turn, but that turn takes place through the most childish slapstick action, developing into one that is unnecessarily heartbreaking, with characters with whom the audience have initially sympathised that turn to be heinous with no reason except to try and make the movie more thrilling and dramatic, but the result is totally unconvincing. Well acted, well crafted, Parasite success is still a mystery.

Superb comedy drama that keeps you on the edge of your seat while making some nice social commentary.  The cast is superb across the board, making you feel for each character, even when they are doing some very bad things.  The real star, though, is writer/director Boon Joon Ho, who delivers a hilarious social satire about upper and lower class life, especially in not taking a black and white stance.  All the characters have personal motivations and flaws that make you root for and against them, often at once.  Plus, Ho manages to deliver some of the funniest moments in cinema in recent years, especially in the way the family cons their way into upper class life.  Easy to see why this is considered one of the best films of 2019.

Mind-boggling experience that left me with a pit in my stomach. The story of Parasite is one so unique, all of my expectations were immediately negated. From the twist to the action to the ending, everything had me at the edge of my seat. The camerawork, cinematography, set, and blocking all added their own components to the underlying themes of the movie. The use of vertical movement, from the camera to the stairways, became such a simple, but effective tool to use for symbolism. Going in blind was amazing, but it took 3 or 4 views to catch everything. This movie is hilarious, thrilling, suspenseful, terrifying, tragic, and hopeful all at the same time, without even feeling the least bit jarring. This is the movie of 2019 without a doubt.

Parasite 
(Spoiler Free)

Last night was one of the most thrilling experiences I have had watching a film.. 

	I attended a small arthouse theatre close to 15 minutes from my house. I finally saw a movie I had been yearning for some time. I am a little late to the party, in regards to my timing of this film. But I am ecstatic I got to view it in a theatre. I wanted to go in with no expectations, because typically I am let down. I have a tendency nitpick as a viewer, which can make some movies difficult to enjoy. I was aware that it had won best foreign film at the Golden Globes, and had received much critical acclaim. I cannot recall seeing another Bong Joon Ho film, except possibly The Host (in which case, it was so long ago- I do not remember). Either way, I was excited to see a movie that looked like a family drama, with perhaps some suspenseful elements.  

	As I sat in this small cleanly theatre, I noticed the majority of people were of Asian descent, and unless my eyes betrayed me, mostly Korean. I attend movies frequently and it was nice to see a very diverse crowd. As the lights dimmed and people munched on their popcorn, and drank their coke's; I sat there, by myself- as the only one in my row. Ready to have a fun experience, with what's been regarded as one of the best of the year.

	The first portion of the movie, centers around an engaging Korean family who live in a lower-class part of the city looking for jobs. They live in a home that is underground, but can still see the street through one of the windows. The family consists of a young adolescent brother and sister as well as their middle-aged parents. The movie begins with raucous laughs and instantly makes you engaged with these characters. The first 30 mins is truly a full-blown comedy and my theatre could not stop laughing. In its own right it is a very effective comedy, that had hints of possible dread ahead. The hints at suspense begin when another family is brought into the story. We see how both of these families become entangled in each other's lives, and how the threads are tied together. The pace was slower in the early stages, but still immensely entertaining. Then there is a tonal flip. A character re-enters the story and you instantly feel tight. At this point you could not really tell where the story was headed, so I stayed in peak curiosity. Then comes a moment when dread absolutely swept over me and I felt as if the story was about to turn into a full-blown horror movie. I sat there in near dread, caught in my own amazement of what I was watching. The tension then softened a bit, but there was still an underlay of tightness. The whole tone of the movie had changed by this point, and you can feel the stress the characters are going through. As well as the fact that the viewer knows more than some of the characters on screen, so there are moments when you want to shout at the screen- DON'T LOOK THERE! Within a few minutes though, you are immersed in the new direction the story has gone in and what's happening. It was fun to follow the story's new direction, with a good level of suspense at this point. You can feel everything is on the brink of destruction, but its still being held together by a thread. Then the story levels off a little bit, heading an even different direction. In this sequence the story is setting up a finale, that will leave devastation. Once we get started in the third act, my jaw just about hit the floor and I was stunned. The final 20 minutes of this people was honestly breathtaking. The music, visuals, acting and the tone of the story hits you like a ton of bricks. By the time the final credits rolled, I sat there in utter amazement. It was the first time I left a theatre feeling utter euphoria. I was absolutely ecstatic with what I had just seen. 

Parasite is a film that brings together a plethora of genres that all coalesce effectively. There is an underlying theme of classism and how the social construct of class impacts the psyche of the characters. But this is truly a story that has many layers, and the shifting tones create an atmosphere that is both eerily terrifying as well as holistically captivating.

Grade- A+

I’ve been feeling very underwhelmed by films in general theses last few years. Remakes, sequels, sagas, universes, spin-offs year, after year, after year. And then 2019 came in with an abundance of original films from some of the greatest and creative minds in the industry, Baumbach, Tarantino, Scorsese to name a few. But Parasite stood out from the bunch. Bong Joon Ho has made a modern masterpiece. Without getting into spoiler the movie made me laugh, cringe, it made me uncomfortable at some points, I felt tense from start to finish. But the best thing about this movie is that it’s unpredictable and when you watch the whole film to the end you feel a weight has been lifted. By far one of the best films of the decade, definitely one or the best film of the year. I will recommend this film to anyone who is in need of powerful, original storytelling, with master class directing. Thank you Mr. Joon Ho, you gave me inspiration and hope in cinema.
