I was completely blown away by Parasite, a movie which combines excellent acting performances with brilliant direction. Bong Joon Ho subverts expectations and changes tones with incredible skill as the movie switches from surprisingly funny moments to powerful emotional drama. I found the themes of the movie to be deeply interesting and spent a long time thinking about it after it was over. The portrayal of the families in Parasite felt remarkably authentic and there were reasons to sympathize with both sides. The acting in the movie was great all around but I was particularly impressed by Kang-Ho Song and Park So-dam who gave the performances of their careers. It is difficult to discuss the movie too much without spoilers as the movie takes many unexpected turns but I would recommend this movie to anyone, it is surely one of the best films of 2019.

I have heard people refer to this film as a case-study on class warfare, and that could not be farther from the intent of the film. The classes are not at war. They do not particularly like or dislike each other. They do not fight with each other either in the open or behind closed doors. The key is to understand that this film is about deception, and not about class warfare. Individuals are continually deceiving each other through out the film, and this precipitates the main conflict/tension instead of any sort of fight or disagreement between classes.

Equally appalling is the gushing of critics over it - "urgent social commentary." Perhaps there's a parallel to the emperor's new clothes - the tailor says that only a fool can't see them, so nobody wants to admit the obvious - the king is naked. An instant classic of the cinema, South Korean auteur Bong Joon-ho's "Parasite," from his script with Han Jin-won, is a gutsy thriller rife with pitch-black comedy that introduces us to the audacious fraud perpetrated by a resourceful family. Son Kim Ki-woo (Choi Woo-shik) stumbles into work as a tutor for dense debutante Park Da-hye (Jeong Ji-so), whose dad is smarmy IT magnate Park Dong-ik (Lee Sun-kyun) and whose mother is fluttery, scatter-brained Park Yeon-gyo (Cho Yeo-jeong). Though he has faked his way into the job, a crush helps seal the deal, and paves the way for his sister to come aboard as an even less qualified art tutor for the family's brat savant son, Park Da-song (Jung Hyeon-jun). Things snowball when mom Kim Chung-sook (Chang Hyae-jin) heartlessly takes the place of the family's devoted cook and housekeeper (Lee Jung-eun), and dad Kim Ki-taek (Song Kang-ho, in an Oscar-worthy performance) slides into place as their chauffeur. But when things appear to be as easy as stealing candy from a baby, the family that uses together loses together, with one incredible development after another threatening their arrangement. Look, this is already one of the best-reviewed films of all time, and is among the Top 10 best-reviewed of the past decade — if you haven't seen it, see it. The title makes it sound like an '80s creature feature, but it's much more like '40s Hitchcock, and it just may be the foreign film that does what "Roma" (2018) couldn't quite do — win top honors at the Oscars over the Americans.

It takes unexpected twists and turns that are just annoying and you sit there thinking, "really? did I really sit through this movie for this to happen?" I beg you dont waste your time, the only reason why people like it is because it played to their emotions of how sad it is to be poor while others are ultra wealthy. To be honest, I think the movie is overall stupid.

The importance of the film is that it comes to us at a time when the divide between the rich and the poor is wider than ever. The rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. The middle class is on the verge of getting wiped out. I applaud the film for showing this divide. Not many films show it, and not many films should. The direction, acting and cinematography is all well-done. But the story is lacking. I wouldn't have nitpicked on this if it was just another average film, but since it is considered as a masterpiece by many, I guess I'm allowed to nitpick. A well-shot film does not necessarily mean a well-made film. The things that happen in this film would not happen in real life. No way. Not ever. At least not this quick. The rich here are just depicted as stupid people which they seldom are in real life. Also there is little to none character development for the rich and the poor as well. Don't get me wrong, I still think it's a good film and I like it. It's just not a 'masterpiece' and 'best film of the year' that I hoped it would be.

Movie ratings rarely are reasons to get outraged. This is an exception.
The South Korean-made "Parasite" won the Cannes Palme d'Or award and has received five-star ratings from several critics.
It does, in fact, have a cleverly-crafted screenplay – several interesting twists and turns not easily foreseen.
But it also cynically exploits several mean-spirited, prejudicial and demeaning stereotypes.
It portrays the non-wealthy/poor as:
• Lazy.
• Unwilling to take pride in their work.
• Obsessively scheming and calculating.
• Predatory.
• Uncaring.
• Cruel, even more so toward other non-wealthy persons.
• Brutal.
• Deceptive.
• Unhygienic.
• Unambitious.
• Untrustworthy, even toward extended family members.
• Politically insensitive (they make great fun of North Korea's steps to de-nuclearize).
Conversely, it illogically portrays them as:
• I.T. geniuses.
• Brilliant improvisers.
• Well-educated and fluent in multiple languages.
• Possessing sharply-honed acting skills.
Meanwhile, it portrays the wealthy as:
• Kind.
• Gullible.
• Thoughtful.
• Sensitive.
• Unsuspecting.
• Naïve.
• Respectful and loving spouses/parents.
• Incurious (the wealthy family prominently featured in the film isn't even aware of all the features of their own home)
• Not revengeful.
The film's main message to the viewers is three-fold:
• Unless you want to incur a boatload of bad karma, avoid being unkind and exploitative to the wealthy.
• If, as a wealthy person, you allow the non-wealthy to become too deeply involved in your life as service providers, they will become the equivalent of sentient, malicious and deadly cockroaches in your home.
• To protect your own family from great misfortune and the temptation to commit brutal crimes, aspire to become wealthy yourself.
What those elite Cannes reviewers were thinking when they voted "Parasite" as the year's top movie is beyond me. Maybe Steve Bannon (Drumpf's white supremacist former adviser who was behind the machinations leading to Great Britain's Brexit referendum) stacked the voting deck, so to speak – who knows?

5 Star Review: (No Spoilers here) WOW. This film will simply leave you wanting to talk about it for hours afterwards. Masterfully crafted by Korean film director, Bong Joon Ho, Parasite is a mystery thriller that sucks the audience right in from the very beginning and doesn't let up until well after the film's final seconds. Arguably the best film I have seen in 2019, Bong Joon Ho fills this masterpiece with metaphors throughout and utilizes mise-en-scène to add depth and symbolism to the film's theme, story and ultimately to help guide the audience to the message he wants to convey.
The film's expertly written script has the right type of story beats to add layers to the world we see on screen and to introduce the inciting plot element at the right moment. The script builds off of that point in the film and smartly keeps the audience guessing and processing the events as they unfold on the screen. It all comes full circle in the film's final act that paints a rather harsh but truthful reality that many of us sometimes have to come to grips with in life.
Thought provoking and pulse pounding, Parasite is a film that deserves to be seen by all on the big screen. This is what cinema is all about.

if you haven't seen Parasite, go see it. It's a stunning achievement and one of the tightest, most sophisticated, clever, and intimate films of the 2010s, if not further. It's clear that director Bong Joon Ho had a vision, one that he expertly and concisely executed: One part struggle between the haves and have-nots (less economic anxiety and more class mobility), and one part darkly intrinsic look at family, society, and belonging. Without spoiling much that isn't in the trailers…

The film follows the impoverished Kims, living in the underbelly of Seoul—father Ki-Taek (Kang-Ho Song), mother Chung Sook (Hye-Jin Jang), son Ki-Woo (Woo-sik Choi), and daughter Ki-Jung (So-Dam Park)—taking whatever odd jobs they can (the film opens on one—folding pizza boxes). But a chance opportunity for Ki-Woo to tutor a wealthy family's daughter sets the stage for the film. It's not spoiling to say that the entire Kim family soon weasels their way into service for the wealthy family, the Parks, and more specifically the mother, Yeon-Kyo (Yeo-Jeong Jo).

Watching the Kims infiltrate the Park household during the first half of the film is a sight to behold: Darkly comedic, whip smart, and incredibly incisive in its observation of both family's worldview. "They are rich, but still nice," quips Ki-Taek. "They are nice because they are rich," retorts his wife. A lesser movie would devolve into a clumsily depiction of a class war (eat the rich!), but the nuance and shades of grey Director Bong uses to create his characters and their world is as thought-provoking as it is entertaining.

Rather, Parasite becomes something else entirely… something darker. From the turning point—you'll know it when you see it—Director Bong really begins to twist audience expectation. In a relatively quick timeframe (in-movie time), the Kims, the Parks, and others find themselves in a series of incidents that are equal parts thrilling, vicious, and deeply saddening. The thrill ride the Parasite takes you on in the second half is indescribable without spoiling, but know that it's edge of your seat gripping, while still managing to keep its darkly humorous tone. By film's end, Parasite leaves you utterly floored and slightly hopeful, but only just so.

Throughout the 131 minute runtime, but most vividly in the second half, Director Bong is working at the height of his powers. Without any fat or indulgence, Parasite is laser-focused on its satire of socioeconomic disparity. It doesn't beat the audience over the head with a hammer (like other notable 2019 films… cough, Joker), rather it surgically penetrates your psyche. It isn't black and white, there are no good or bad. There are only people. People in two distinctly different worlds. And ultimately, the choices these characters make to create their version of existence.

Highlights: The camerawork, storytelling, and set design are astounding: No wasted space, no self-indulgent sets, and no extraneous storytelling. This entire film is a master at work. Parasite bursts with so much that it's impossible to highlight without spoiling.

MVP: Park So-Dam turns in an aloof, yet charismatic performance as Kim Ki-Jung. And Yeo-Jeong Jo as Park Yeon-Ko dazzles as the bored, eager-to-please, worrying mother.

Should you see it: You shouldn't be reading this, you should be buying a ticket right now. 10/10.

Like nothing you'll ever see. While I was very anxious to see this film based on reviews I had read, I found it to be a  rather bizarre film for most American film-goers, probably due to major cultural differences. If this film were made by an American director/producer, it would have most likely been done as a comedy, to get across the biting criticism and condemnation of class differences. The film veered off the reality charts once all Hell broke loose in the plot and with the chaos created in the end. I would have difficulty recommending this film to most of my friends and colleagues.

OMG, this is the most remarkable film of the year, IMHO. It makes a commentary on class distinction from an Asian point of view. I might stretch it to compare it to Downton Abbey, but with more violence at the end. I was so surprised and often shocked at the many twists and turns in this film, I can't even begin to describe them. 

I had heard a lot of buzz about it from friends who had seen it at festivals, but nothing they said about it prepared me for the huge impact it had on me. It provokes a veritable roller coaster of emotions from hilarity to horror, heartbreak to awareness. 

The acting is superb, every member of the cast makes a dramatic impact and each character is so distinct yet plays off the others so well. 

But, the most impactful part of this film is the socio-political message it makes and the class clash. The economic inequality between people from different social classes is played out so enticingly well. The thoughts and behaviors that connect people and promote closeness among their personal interactions within their class is examined and shown so clearly. The ending is so perplexing. Even today, two weeks after I initially saw this film, I was discussing it with a colleague and we differed in how we perceived the ending. I may have to go see it again. It truly is a brilliant piece of filmmaking. 

This is not a kid or family-friendly film, which we usually review. However, that being said, as a person who greatly respects the art of filmmaking, I felt compelled to review this one, which is outside the KIDS FIRST! norm. Do go to kidsfirst dot org for more reviews of family – friendly films.

Bong, baby ...You did it again. This fascinating, master-crafted examination of class oozes intrigue in every frame and it's chaotic crescendo is one sure to latch onto your cinematic memory bank -like a parasite. Refusing relegation to the ranks of forgettable features, Parasite is defiantly, deliciously original storytelling helmed by a mad genius and woven around a delicately balanced cast.

This movie is amazing- beautiful storytelling. Deeply sad but it feels like a comedy through much of it. More a parable than a drama or thriller but the suspense pulls you along through its most uncomfortable passages. A real masterpiece.

While I rank among the most novice of viewers in regards to Korean filmmaking (having only seen Oldboy and a couple of Korean films regarded as 'classic' by those who suggested them to me.) I cannot help but sit in awe at Parasite. The film has a solid pace which allows the characters to be observed both in their natural habitat, and that which they invade. Outstanding acting and beautiful blocking allow Parasite to fill above and beyond the usual film, but what really shines is the script. A story difficult to place in terms of genre, it manages to lead the viewer towards each designed motion. A dramatical satire whose social commentary goes beyond riches, as it aims directly towards the nature of people and it is not afraid to go all the way in. In my opinion, a must-see in 2019, and also easily regarded as one of the best films of the decade.
By far the best film I've seen all year.

Bong Joon-Ho's slow burning, indubitably Oscar-worthy film explores the subject of social classes in a meticulously calibrated (and metaphorical) manner and it's one of the most original, daring and astonishing thing I've seen in the cinema in years. Heavily infused with social commentary and satire, yet subtle enough to avoid any preachiness, this is the story of two families: the unemployed Kims are the lower class who lives in a tiny, literally sub-street level, apartment while the wealthy, upper class Parks luxuriate in a huge modern designer house. When an opportunity arises for Kim's son to tutor the Park's daughter, the Kims begin an elaborate plan to infiltrate the Park family. Just as you think you are settling in for an invasion thriller, the film pivots into an unexpectedly revelatory and gripping middle section that plays out like a tense hide-and-seek heist and culminates in an exquisite finale so jaw-droppingly outrageous that it can only happen in a Korean film. Using every cinematic language available dextrously to deliver something complex and thought-provoking, its cinematography is awe-inspiring (and pops even more on the big screen) and every screen composition and production design is brimming with meaning and specific significance. Minor contrivances in the plotting aside, the cleverly constructed script not only juxtaposes well the manner the Kims connive to better themselves with the Parks' obliviousness and inability to appreciate what they have, but refuses to give in to simple characterisations or resolutions. The Kims may be devious and ruthless but they are also aspirational and hard workers and good people at heart. Wickedly funny, tragically poignant, yet remaining positively hopeful, this entertaining and immensely (re)watchable film will overwhelm you with a myriad of emotions and thoughts and stays with you long after you left the cinema.

"Parasite" is an intriguing feature film that talks about the differences between social classes, opening up a wide range of discussions without neglecting the artistic part that a film needs to have.

The script tells the story of a Korean family on the brink of misery that begins to infiltrate and steal jobs within a rich, manipulated, sabotaging, and lying family until all members are employed within the family core of the rich family.

Several interesting themes and subversions of roles occur, such as the rich family being harmed and manipulated by the poor family, showing that money does not always define character or villains and good guys, or even deify the rich family's charisma because they have no problem with money. , several clichés are broken, and the two family nuclei suffer during the work that discusses social inequality, honesty and trust, in a work that values ​​more its plot and direction than open these discussions, which in a way is It's good, because it creates an engaging, straightforward movie and makes the viewer reflect on such issues as simply having forced partner issues.

Bong Joon-ho conducts his film with a clear technique, with a bluish photograph and a classic soundtrack, the director uses many open planes and always uses the composition of scenes to give amplitude and depth to his scenes, it is also worth mentioning his beautiful frames, it is a beautiful direction, direct, and sometimes even risks leaving the comfort zone, using slow motion and sequential shots.

The human material in the film is good, everyone plays his characters well, especially Kang-Ho Song, the most expressive and unpredictable character and sun-kyun lee, who has a great screen presence.

The feature film, which is a favorite with Oscar for best foreign film of the year 2019, is not perfect, the development of some characters is lacking and some continuity errors occur, but the work has many hits and is one of the highlights of the year. NOTE: 8/10

Parasite is a fascinating film because, while it consistently maintains focus on the same topic, it is constantly changing the style and genre of the film. At times it’s a comedy, then it’s a thriller, then it’s a con-artist/hustler movie, then it’s a horror film, etc. There are surprises around every corner in this movie, and that made it riveting to watch. I never once felt that I knew what was going to happen next, and that is such a freeing experience. I also have to commend Parasite for threading the needle and making a movie with protagonists who are unlikable, but getting me to care about them. It’s weird, but the way the film sets up their plan, it has just enough comedy that I kind of enjoy watching the devious plot unfold. There’s a twisted pleasure in seeing people that are clever enough to be a few steps ahead of everyone, even if their intentions are selfish. The cast of the film was wonderful, and many of them had to take on complex roles where they basically require 2 distinct personalities. However, Parasite wasn’t pure joy for me. I got annoyed later in the film that these people who seem so savvy start to behave like morons. The one thing that I could clearly predict in the film was something that they didn’t even seem to consider as a possibility. It isn’t a huge fault in the story, but it seems inconsistent with the characters that we see carefully planning so many details. I also thought at times Bong Joon-Ho went a little overboard with messaging in the movie. While it’s fairly obvious that the entire film is focusing on the differences in classes within Korean culture, it’s not like I need multiple scenes of people peeing in the streets to show the lousy living conditions of some people. There’s even a massive flood that doesn’t play into the plot in any way but to show the night-and-day difference between these two families. Despite any minor complaints, Parasite is a truly unique film, and one I can’t wait to watch again in order to pick up on all the details I missed the first time. If you know nothing about the film, then read no more, watch no trailers, and go see it...you won’t regret it.

It was provocative, but it mirrored what is currently going on in our own government.  The fact that they kept going back and forth between the comedy of the characters to the tragedy of the bizarre split between the economic classes was tragic and at times sickening.  It took advantage of the audiences innocence and ignorance of the situation in a foreign country and used shock value to make its point.  It also was done with a keen excellence in film making, but the audience was actually the victim. South Korean dark comedy Parasite is a film that requires as little information known about the story before seeing it as possible. It was a struggle for me to keep myself as far away as I possibly could from reviews and articles about the film, but I am glad I did so, because I truly believe the best way to see it is to know nothing about it beforehand. 
Parasite revolves around two families, one living in poverty, barely having enough money to eat every night, and the other, spoilt for riches, struggling to decide what to eat each night. The first half of the film shows the families interacting through an elaborate scheme that sees the entirety of the poverty-stricken family working under the same roof as the wealthy family.
 It is hard to reveal any more about the story without taking the experience away from the viewer, but what I can say is, the complete shift of tone halfway through turns this film from a dark comedy into a thrilling drama. It is a true testament to director Bong Joon-Ho that the film can change tone so frequently without creating unrest. Every tonal shift brings the audience along with it; you will be laughing one minute and in complete shock the next. Every scene is important to the direction the film takes, even the numerous, lengthy tracking shots have significant meaning behind them. There is one scene in particular, where the gradual build-up of tension explodes into one of the captivating twists that you will see this year.
The cinematography, production design and directing piece together the two halves of the world perfectly. The juxtaposition of the two houses that the characters reside in, are almost characters in themselves. The characters personalities change depending on which house they are positioned in, and the natural events occurring in the world can have significant repercussions on one house, but would leave the other unscathed. 
There really isn't much you can say wrong about this film. It is one of the best films I have seen this year and perhaps even this decade.
Bong Joon-Ho gives such a unique take on poverty and the class differential that occurs worldwide. As the film gains traction coming up to the awards season, it will not only gain relevance, but create a discussion. Parasite is a true masterpiece from one of the best foreign film makers around today.

This film reminds me of a Quentin Tarantino movie and let's just say, I am not a fan. Beautifully filmed and good acting across the board (although the bunker housekeeper character goes from demure to psychotic a little too quickly), the film clips along and keeps you guessing where it will go next. But with a storyline that involves amoral con artists scheming to take advantage of an amoral and clueless wealthy family, there is no one in this film who you will empathize with. There is an impending sense of doom from the start that offsets any attempted humor in the beginning of the film although it garners plenty of laughs in the theater. Midway through, the film takes an unnecessary and ridiculous plot turn and the violence builds to a frenzied crescendo that leaves you feeling that any point that was to be made of the rich feeding off of the poor and the poor being justified in feeding off the rich is lost in the mayhem. I often find writer+director-as-one films lack a tempered hand to rein in a tendency towards overindulgence: this is definitely true for Bong Joon Ho's "Parasite."

Breezing by with the fiendish joys of a clever heist, that's only the first chunk of 'Parasite.' Song Kahng-ho, Jang Hye-jin, Choi Woo-shik, and especially Park So-dam are impeccable as the Kim family, who in all their relatable desperation looking for work, bring a sly fondness as they start scheming against their newfound employers. Joon-ho and Han Jin-won's screenplay (in addition the former's understated directing job) is excellent with perfect pacing that beautifully flows from scene to scene, and once he's done laying all his cards on the table, Joon-ho springs a set of vicious narrative traps that escalate into a thrilling, almost totally new film whose every minute is better than the last.

Whether it's a casual passing remark, joke, or calculatingly placed visual, every single detail gradually coalesces into an immaculately tight piece about the relational tension between society's haves and have-nots. It's flooring not just how much, but how synergistically and open to interpretation Joon-ho crafts his film, particularly in his impressive ongoing visual motif contrasting the power disparity between high and low height levels. As well as being an effortlessly humorous, sinisterly horrifying thrill ride, there are heaps of love and care put into Parasite, and it shows on every bit of inch of screen as it plays.

Bong Joon-ho's class-warfare thriller is yet another cinematic masterclass without ever feeling like it's delivering a lecture—or like it has a fully realized political stance, either. No doubt the film has something to say about social inequity, class structure, and the titularly parasitic nature of capitalism, but the mere suggestion and its depiction does not mean something finally gets said: Are the word's "capitalism" or "class" ever even spoken? A poor family rich in cunning and craftiness set against (which is to say: capitalizing upon) a rich family poor in their credulous capacity to take care of themselves, the film wants to say something by showing such inequality in the extreme, though in the end I can't quite say the movie takes a side beyond viewing the symbolic symbiotic relationship as unsustainable.

Taste of Korea.  Now I would personally recommend going into this knowing nothing, but if you insist on having a small inkling, this is about a family of four, all of which are unemployed.  They get gifted with a rock that is said to bring its owner fortune, and they find themselves gradually becoming gainfully employed by a wealthy family under false pretenses.  How long will they be able to keep the ruse up?  Like I said before, I went into this knowing as little as possible about this on purpose.  What little I had seen recommended that I approach it in such a fashion, and Joon-Ho Bong is such a talented director that I heeded the warning.  I watched a trailer and that was about it, and I was careful to avert my eyes if anything popped up on social media.  I wasn't even sure what genre this would fall under, and that is the best way to take this movie in if at all possible.  Now what I most appreciated about Parasite is how many layers it has to it.  Sure, you can view this as a microcosm for a capitalistic society, and that all works, but even if you don't do that extra legwork, you can still get behind this twisty story as it is presented to you.  It is so rare that a movie can actually pull a surprise in this day and age, and even when you are sensing something big is about to happen, Parasite is excellent at constantly catching you off guard in a way that you don't see coming.  Even very early on with this, something is off and the story won't allow you to quite put your finger on it.  It pulls you in with this heist-like setup, and then it flips the script entirely.  Much like this family, it has got you hook, line and sinker, and you have an inherent need to see how this story is going to play out.  I never knew really at any point where this movie was going to end up, and for somebody who watches as many movies as I do, it made for a completely engrossing experience.  I just saw this three days ago and I can't stop thinking about it.  Joon-ho Bong blends genres seamlessly, and this covers comedy, thriller, mystery, and horror in the best way possible.  The dynamics of the story are always changing which is sure to make it an absorbing watch.  This was one of the few movies of 2019 that I went into with high expectations and they were all met.  The cinematography is terrific as is the acting, and as long as you don't mind reading subtitles, you should get ready for one of the best movies of the year.

This movie made us think.  Who's the good guy?  Who's the bad?  Everyone is both.  It reminded me of the Sopranos in that way.  The main character, Ki-taek. is like Tony Soprano.  He is a family man, indeed a leader of his family.  He is a visceral man.  He will fight for his family.  He plans.  Like Tony, he cannot bear certain kinds of slights.  For so many seasons, I understood Tony Soprano, but then it became too much.  For most of the movie, I understood Ki-taek, but then I couldn't.  

This movie is a social commentary about the haves and have-nots.  The haves are condescendingly kind.  The have-nots are left to bear that condescension in order to be half haves in their own right.  Then they too become ruthless but in a literal kiss up, kick down kind of way.  

It's a biblical like story with all the seven deadly sins woven in and out of the plot.  Like with the Bible, you have to suspend your sense of reason, especially when Ki-taek is left in the basement at the end of the story.  Of course, he could get out himself, or his son could just break in and get him out, but it is his penance to stay, just as Cain was left to wander.  Can the son succeed where the father couldn't?  Do we want him to when his dream is not to better humankind in some way, but to live in the dream house and be a have?  

No one learns their lesson and the human condition goes on.  Will any of these characters emerge to be Jesus?  There is no hint of that.  So the story leaves us without any hope.  No one even dreams of a Messiah.  No one yearns for a simple life with some love and kindness.  It's grim, like the Old Testament.

The best film of the year.  Fantastic performances.  Absolutely not the movie I thought it would be.  Funny, thrilling, shocking, poignant. I can't remember the last time I enjoyed a movie this much,
Unexpected. Plot twists. Cultural commentary. Excellent.
Creative plot and great acting, but I found it difficult to enjoy a movie about such self-centered and deceitful characters.

By far the best movie you will see this year. No scene in this film is a waste of time and every line of dialogue and piece of symbolism carries weight throughout the film. Just when you think you have it all figured out, it hits you with a twist so dark and morbid you are left in shock for the rest of the film. It's a comedy horror drama that is at once surreal yet strangely relatable. I would compare it with Sorry to Bother You as a must-see "late stage capitalism drama".

One of the best movies I have seen to date. The twist and turns leave the viewer always wanting more and surprise them at nearly every scene. A wonderfully constructed narrative that fills in any plot holes. All of the actings was superb with each actor and actress performing their role to perfection. Me and a family member make a bet after 15 minutes into a movie to figure out the ending, whoever gets closer wins and the other person pays for lunch, we both got almost everything incorrect. This is in my humble opinion the best movie of the year.

Even blew endgame off the number one spot for best movie of the year for me. It's everything you want in a movie as a cinephile once you get past reading the subtitles. It's funny, thrilling, tragic, sweet, and downright memorable. Deserving of more than just an international film Oscar nomination.
So Fresh: Absolute Must See! This movie is like no other

Bong Joon-ho’s new film is something truly special. I don’t want to spoil the slightest detail, I’ll just say the film offers so much to appreciate and is one I’ll be rewatching regularly in life moving forward.
WOW! Is all I have to say. See it!
No word can describe the true drama and horror of the modern capitalist society and how it divides us. This movie is perfect, the message os its story is the most necessary in this state of things.
Deliciously dark...brilliant, hilarious performances... twists & turns

This is unique and gripping in a way 90% of modern films are not. A simple story with a clever twist played to maximum tension. I was intrigued from the opening frames all the way through the masterful ending.
This movie was interesting and captivating.  Lots of twists and turns.  A little long but loved it!
Don’t try to figure out where its going. Just relax and watch.

Flawless cinematic perfection. Parasite is like a Korean Tarantino film. The screenplay is so original and the dialogue is impeccable. It has humor, suspense and sorrow. One of the best foreign films that I have ever seen.

One of the best films I've seen recently. It is a universal story about class differences, avarice, and pride. The film reminds me of some of the best work by the Coen brothers, especially Fargo, with similar dark humor, and exquisite attention to detail in all aspects of film-making.
Liked the story, not the subtitles
worth to watch it in the theater ,

Overhyped and overrated. The story unfolds in a sort of pseudo-intellectual plot that seems too neat and implausible for how it is presented. The guts of the movie is formulaic and predictable making an otherwise interesting look into a foreign culture pretty dull.
This movie has everything: drama, humor, & thrills. The tension is palpable and the irony is delicious.
Excellent and original.
Acting was very good. Other then that, to me the movie was a bore.
Some problems with the script, but overall very good.
I generally struggle with slower shows lately but this movie kept me on the edge throughout!! Love it!

this is, without a doubt, my favourite film of the year. Bong Joon-ho is one of our time's finest directors, he could never make a single dull film if he tires, his films are full of brilliant twists that aren't shoved down one's throat but carefully contemplated and this film portrays that the best. I would say that this film is the director's magnum opus and would like him to prove me wrong.

We saw Paradite today at the Century 20 in Clackamas Town Center and loved it!  
I highly recommend it.
Best movie of the year.

The first half was funny and engaging. The second half was disjointed. The turn of events left me anxious, a feeling that stayed with me well after the movie was over. I guess that could be a sign of good moviemaking but it just caused a disconnection making the movie as a whole very disappointing.

The kind of movie that is unexpected.  There are many layers of character and story...each suggests a view of the levels of class within society...and, ultimately how those levels exist intertwined...it's funny and quirky...by that I mean there is a lot commentary about the hollowness of social structure that is represented openly in the actions of both poor and rich...their stories are dependent upon one another and no one may really be the winner in the struggle for survival in life. As often with this director the movie doesn't go in expected directions and that is it delight.
THIS MOVIE WAS AMAZING. HIT ME IN MY SOUL. GO WATCH IT NOW!!!
Great narrative on social classes. Terrific thriller. Highly recommend!
masterful masterwork masterpiece. Easily the best film of 2019
great flick. would have been better if I wasn't forced to read the subtitles and rather, focusing all attention on the actors.
This one stays with you.

Spine tingling, charming, yet terrifyingly brilliant. Parasite hits a number of notes that you never new could be hit in a movie. A story that's been told before but never like this'd Parasite takes place over the course of a couple of months and focuses on two families, The Kim's and The Parks. The acting in this film is absolutely perfect, each character has their own motives and fleshed out plans. Each step the characters take leave you on the edge of your seat. I have not seen a movie this gripping in years. If you expect it to be a live action of the anime well you'll be disappointed cause it's not. The situations and score make this movie absolutely nerve wracking and satisfying all at the same time. The narrative of two families one wealthy and one poor, is told to perfection and it feels very realistic. The movie kept me on the edge of my seat waiting and waiting for the next thing to happen. It builds up and winds down in the perfect way possible. The score is absolutely perfect and added to the overall story and tensions to the film. The characters are interesting and the story is gripping and phenomenal. An absolute must see, and a game changing film.

Final Grade: 10/10

I have no idea why this movie got such a high rating. As you watch it, you realize that you hate the movie because you know that certain things are going to happen. And it gets even worse than you expect. The movie is not about class differences. It is about moral differences. The people in this movie have no morals. I found it hard to watch and didn't like it.

What a great movie.  Bong Joon Ho is one of our greatest filmmakers and he has made a compelling and completely captivating film that is sadly all too relevant to the times we live in.   Nothing about this film misses.  See it.
Watched it twice in two days! So goooooood!
Absolutely incredible.

This is one of those films that sticks with you and lives in your brain. PARASITE is the ultimate Upstairs/Downstairs in wealth and status division. My wish is everyone watches this and appreciates every scene. I would write more but I don't want to spoil anything. Holy hell it's so good.

A very difficult film to review. It had some very creative and novel storytelling elements but it was riddled with small mistakes. The prevailing opinion will probably disagree, but I thought that potentially powerful, emotional moments were squandered. We spent too long watching some scenes with no payoff and far too little time with scenes that could've carried the story and greatly affected the audience. I was definitely entertained, but the greater class struggle themes were mostly wasted due to a muddled message. It would've also been easier to watch this film if we could've actually liked the main characters but they just seemed like underdeveloped, desperate con-artists instead of fully-formed characters.
Not what you expect.
Deep. Thrilling. Kept me on the edge of my seat the entire runtime.

The way in which the film is directed is a fresh and wonderful idea, the director presents us, a family within another family, and then within another one; in the process, it fills us with positive, negative reflections; it moves us, it shocks us, it confuses us, but then at the end it hugs us, at the same time in both soft and brutal ways.
Incredible movie story telling! A wonderful film!

Layers on layers. The characters are excellently acted out, showing complex feelings all over the place. I felt every shot was symbolizing something deeper, commenting on inequality or family or love or etc. This beautifully shot black humor thriller is a must see.
Great movie with top notch actors. Interesting.
Troubling and terrifying -- movie is a lot of fun and leaves you stunned at the end.

Beautifully crafted, “Parasite” defies genre. It smoothly transitions the viewer from one surprise to the next, taking multiple unexpected turns, that have you on the edge of your seat! Brilliant characters, writing, cinematography, acting, Bong Joon-ho has crafted a masterpiece.

A once in a lifetime experience. Do not make the mistake of not going to a theater to see this, this film is mesmerizing. The directing, the score, the acting, and the writing are all superb and the closest Ive seen to perfection in a film. The performances from all actors and actresses in this film are phenomenal. A film that has a strong message but isnt ham fisted, its handled with humor and powerful moments/shots. Dont do yourself the disservice of sitting this one out.
Keeps you on the edge of your seat, as you try to figure out how things are going to unravel, come together and ultimately come to a conclusion.
This movie did a great job of making the audience feel uncomfortable (in a good thriller way) and definitely kept me on the edge of my seat!
This was a horror film spiked with just enough humor and real story to make it work.......Very creative........very thought provoking!
Well written, well acted, and kept my attention all the way through.
Very good film. I was thoroughly entertained. It got a little wacky on the end there, but overall a good film.

I was expecting some sort of horror-thriller vibe but what was presented was a vague depiction of some sort of class commentary with a too-long-to-arrive climax that doesn't explain any of the undertones leading up to it. The story is of a scamming family that makes there way into a naive rich family's house in a multitude of positions, but the overall experience is unsatisfactory. Nothing interesting or important is said and shame on the Rotten Tomatoes sheep for tricking me into watching this.
A great movie! The suspense was uncomfortable. The acting was great. The plot was interesting. There were a couple minor issues but overall a great movie.
Parasite was excellent in every way: a great balance of humor, social commentary, and surprise. Amazing writing, editing, and directing. Loved it.
Great photography and editing, acting was superb and believable. Chaotic end was a bit much and too satirical for my taste. I guess it could have been finished a lot better than how it ended.
Parasite is wonderfully crafted film with the help of the cleverness and smarts of the talented writer and director.
Bong Joon Ho just continues to master the craft of filmmaking...and this modern parable might be his best.
One of the best movies of 2019, the climax was amazing and left me shook 😆
This is why people make movies. Every aspect of the film was interesting, visually stunning and profound.
Started well then just became silly and weird
Bit of a disconnect from the start being humorous to abruptly turning gruesome.

This is one of my all time favorite movies and the best movie of 2019! It’s almost flawless with amazing story telling, script, cinematography, and acting. I can’t recommend it enough. It is a must see!

This is one of my all time favorite movies and by far the best movie of 2019! From a movie making standpoint the film is almost flawless. Beautiful story telling, cinematography, acting, and script. This is what more movies should be like. I can't go on enough about how good this movie is and a must see!
Great cinematography. Well-paced. Good acting. Not predictable. Thrilling.

Great con story about greed and class. 
Must see

Another Bong Joon-Ho film that I will be rewatching for years and years to come. With the usual perfect casting and suspense of his prior films, it's blended with comedy and a pace that can't be matched. Every turn in the movie, regardless if it's a twist or predictable, seems to fit perfectly into every scene. Guaranteed to keep you invested for the duration of the entire film, without checking your watch once.
Just because it’s foreign doesn’t make it a quality film. People on here tend to praise film when it doesn’t deserve it. Parasite is mediocre at best.
This is a great movie. Funny, sad and a poignant commentary on our parasitic society. Full of brilliant scenes done by a great cast. Clearly destined to become a classic.
Very inventive and includes several unexpected twists. Great acting all around. One of the best movies of the year.
Holy Mackerel, that was awful!
What a unique plot!!  It was funny, sad and very well done!!  Loved it!!
It is well written and well directed, acted and produced.  The sets are fabulous, the script is unique and wonderful.  It is completely unpredictable and entertaining.
Great!!! 100% entertainment
The film was infectious!
Such interesting Plot twists, excellent acting, and multi-faceted characters.  Loved the movit

This movie is extremely RACIST!!!! The repeated cultural appropriation was gut wrenching. I was sickened to see a child running around with Arrows and a Tomahawk  mimicking Racist sounds of Native Americans. Calling the child "an Indian fanatic" then comparing it to being a boyscout.Really? And it doesn't stop there when the adults decide to adorn their heads with Sacred War Bonnets which is extremely disrespectful!! My culture is not your costume!! I'm in shock that here we are in 2019 and this racism is still here! Not to mention from a foreign film! Wow! This is the worst movie! BOYCOTTING THIS RACIST FILM!

You can’t watch it at a surface level - it’s deep and dark and very meaningful, no matter the culture - this isn’t just Korean culture, it’s all about perception of life. Clues: the title and references to the cockroach, the ending and the way the father lives... we are all born into a situation but perception and action makes a huge difference to outcomes. Loved it.
Parasite marries gut wrenching tension with a joyous sense of fun and humor. I simultaneously felt heartbreak, happiness, horror, and a sense of home. Not a single moment wasted.

Bong Joon-ho presents a masterpiece of suspense, humor and subtle social justice commentary in his aptly named Parasite. I agree with others that the less you know about this film prior to seeing it, the more youll enjoy it. This is the kind of film Id like to see again because of the richness of the characters and the intelligent plot. After youve seen it, youll probably appreciate why the audience at Cannes gave Bong a five-minute standing ovation. He won top movie there this year. A sure Oscar contender. Go see it.

I'll say this was a tough one to gauge. At first it starts off as a funny family film, takes a turn to a psychological thriller and somehow turns the darkness up which doesn't feel possible an yet it happens. Definitely a film for the year that tells a unique and interesting tale.
Such a great movie. A typical good Korean movie could be a good universal movie.
Excellent story, acting, cinematography, and twists!!
I made an account to recommend this movie to everyone. Incredibly well layered yet seamless. Get ready to be discomforted
Wow! What a great movie. I understand why it earned the Palm d'or.
Fantastic, great action, and acting . Subtitles u get used to. Great story .

This is by far one of the WORST movies I've ever seen. If you enjoy watching a low life family of bad con artists destroy another family's life, while full of impending doom foreshadowing the movie until it starts getting bloody and violent, then you'll love it. The movie was disturbing, pointless and creepy with no redeeming qualities. All the great reviews leave me completely amazed that anyone would think this movie was worth seeing. Waste of money and 2 1/2 hours of my life. Don't waste your time like I did.
Great writing, directing, and acting. I had no clue where the story was going. Totally unique.
Intelligent, brilliant, unique, and entrancing. I loved this movie from start to finish. It's so very tense and intense. Definite must-see!

well made

Absolutely one of the best movies of the year.  Highly recommend this one.

The film moves constantly and is not especially long so once seated, buckle in because you won't want to miss a scene. It's a lot. The ending and it's build up will surprise you. 

Worth seeing if you like suspense and trying to figure out where a film is going.... or if class struggle is more your realm.

It is a movie worth seeing. Direction is somehow perfect where you'd think perfection cannot be achieved. You think you know what's coming ahead but the twists and turns hit you in the face and you realize the director has full control of his craft. Shots are amazing, sound track is cleverly used. I must watch this movie several times to really take in what it has offer in full. I watched this movie yesterday and I am still thinking about it today.
What the hell just happened!!! Started out funny and sweet and ended sad and gory!! Sorry...but this is a horror flick!!
AFTER SEEING THIS MOVIE, I DON'T BELIEVE REVIEW SCORES IT RECEIVED...
Fantastic comedy/drama (didn't know this was even a thing) that is so unpredictable, it legitimately had me on the edge of my seat multiple times.

I enjoyed every twisted twist, never knowing what to expect.  The social commentary on class separation is perfectly clear throughout the entire movie. I enjoyed every minute and would see this movie again happily.

I'm going to have to go against the grain on this review. The movie kept my attention, but I just didnt like the story. This movie couldn't figure out what it wanted to be...a con artist comedy to start, some social class inequality issues throughout, finishing up with a tragic, violent ending which didnt fit the flow of the movie up to that point.
Movie was great loved everything about it I recommend seeing this
Clever, dry humor, thought provoking story. interesting plot. Enjoyed it, but gruesome towards end.
Captivating, immersive, from beginning to end, keeps you on the edge of the seat during the entire movie, the director plays with your expectations and overcomes them.

Loved it!! Completely engaging from start to finish, unlike anything I've seen, acting was fantastic, loved the scenery. So nice to see something completely different for a change, and that kept my attention. Gripping. Well Done!!! A must see.

4.25*
Bong Joon-Ho creates another great film.  This is more of a comedy than anything else so don't go in expecting Memories of Murder.  The hilarity of the situations the characters are put through, and their subsequent reactions, are amazing.  He takes the movie to places you could never possibly guess.  The acting, as usual with Korean movies, is top notch.  As absurd as the story is the characters all feel authentic/real and their actions somehow come across as rational.  It's a dark comedy and if that's your thing then this will surely appeal to you.
Superb film, impeccable acting and direction.
This film completely surpassed my expectations. Every aspect of this movie was absolutely phenomenal! Bong Joon-Ho is the best!
I'm the odd man out on this movie. Despite some funny lines and revealing moments, I wished for a Fast Forward button. The movie was entertaining, but just.
subtitles are a negative
Unbelievably beautiful and chilling. Takes you on one ride just to toss you into another.
Creative movie! Unpredictable
The most incredible movie I’ve ever seen

The cinematography was beautiful and the character development inspired. It is very humorous and clever at the same time. The suspense was well developed, even if somewhat predictable towards the end. The foreshadowing of the use of the “scholar’s stone” as a weapon and the underground shelter as the father’s hiding place. Overall, it was an amazing film and a lot of fun.
A very unique movie that is like no other. Creepy yet funny, terrifying yet interesting. This movie has it all. It's a masterpiece and one of the best of 2019.
Best movie I've seen in a loooong time. Definitely worth the watch.
Nothing you would expect. Really nice movie.
One of the years best.
Not what you expect but a must see

Writer-director Bong Joon-ho crafts a masterpiece for the ages, establishing his blend of dark comedy and timely drama as his signature and proving to be one of the most accomplished filmmakers of his generation.
So much packed in! I felt like the perspective was that of an alien or aliens studying humans.
This film tricks you into one thing then turns it upside down. One of the best films of the year.

might rate this one higher after a second watch, but not sure when that will happen so reviewing now. didn't read up on it before going, wanted to be surprised. did know it had something to do with economic class struggle. this is a movie for grownups and it's easy to recommend. just one (or two) "um, really?" plot line moments that i didn't get fully on-board with. positives FAR outweigh any negatives.

I have never written a movie review before. Today, I was inspired to write my first one. I have not walked out of the movie in many years. Today, I was motivated to do so. The story began interestingly enough as the "Parasite" family befriended the wealthy family. The story was woven nicely on how each family member began to work for the wealthy family. However, the movie soon took a very dark turn. I told myself repeatedly while watching Parasite: "the professional reviewers had given it a 99% rating and it would soon improve". I was wrong. Finally, in frustration towards the end of the movie, (I checked my watch and realized it had been two hours already), I stood up and walked out. It was the only satisfaction I had in watching I checked my watch and realized it had been two hours trying to watch this movie. this movie is not recommended by me. (As a small aside, I've seen many Asian movies produced in China, Korea, Japan, etc. and this was the first one I ever felt so inclined to walk out of.)
What a great film, funny, suspenseful, shocking and all around such a great film!!!
Very meticulous, yet warm, then stunning development. I feel like I will have to check the basement of my house - again.

I never knew a movie could be suspenseful, sad, hilarious, and damning at the same time. You'll stay gripped to your seat the entire time. The movie really gives a new take on things never really being what they seem. This is the best movie I have ever seen.
This was a great movie. A comedy that makes an unexpected turn to a thriller.
Movie started out with an interesting plot but took a morbid, bloody turn the last 25% of the movie

Grade: A+

Sometimes it's difficult to rave about a film especially if it is getting so much praise, but here, the HYPE IS REAL! It is so rare that I can say this with film. You can see how much effort was put into every shot of this film, and the film does it with such ease. The acting is terrific which makes the film even more tense and dramatic. Parasite is one of the best, if not the best, foreign films I've ever seen. It is able to use visual storytelling a lot to convey the deeper meanings to the audience. Not only does its story keep you engaged and entertained throughout the 2-hour runtime, it also is so brilliantly written with no lingering questions to ask. This is a film that you don't see anymore. I wish there were more movies like this.
Totally unexpected, but totally entertaining at the same time. the first chapter was Grand, climax was superb. The resolution was a bit long for my tastes.
Really enjoyed it, but a bit nuts at times

Visually stunning social commentary applicable to many communities in Asia, Latin America and the West. So much to unpack. They will be teaching classes about this masterpiece in college ... have been haunted by its themes for days now. Bravo Bong Joon-ho!
Parasite is a thought-provoking film, essentially about class warfare.
I didn’t have any expectations for this movie but it was exceptional! It was funny yet moving and I expecting! Fantastic watch!
Excellent. Never quite sure where it's going.
An incredible film full of twists and turns. Incredible!
One of the best movies Ive seen in a long time.  Beautiful and horrific all at once.
This film maker is insanely great at his craft. this is a masterpiece that comes with all the trimmings. I was very satisfied with the results and hope it wins best picture
Beautiful photography. In the end just a weird plot
One of the most thought provoking, original, and entertaining movies I've seen in a long time.
Definitely go see this and the less you know the more you will enjoy! Few films or even filmmakers have reached this level of mastery.
Great acting but terrible story
Amazing. This movie turns into something you never expected.

This is by far the best thriller you will ever see. The other reviews talk about how they wanted to leave the first 10 minutes buts that’s only because they didn’t get to see the whole movie. The first half is just a family and everything is normal but as time goes on the second half starts it starts to get out of place and more insane. By far my favorite movie for sure and it is so intriguing and thrilling.

I'd advise to see this movie prior to reading reviews or watching any clips. Parasite delivers multiple shocks and turns, creatively so, that leaves the audience questioning every character and their decision.
A cinematographic and editing masterpiece, enabling the bulk of the class conflict/nihilist themes to blossom outside the understated narrative.

Overrated 
Disappointing
Fantastically orchestrated, beautifully filmed and a finely crafted picture that's genuinely gripping. Bringing as a dark comedy, segueing into tragedy. It's truly a story of two halves.
One of the few achievements of 2019, a thrilling success! Movie goes between comedy, drama and thriller in a shocking way that ultimately creates a different and special tone to itself.

A masterclass in direction, screenwriting, acting, and cinematography.  The director skillfully blends the disparate genres of comedy, horror, and thriller, along with a healthy dose of social commentary, to make this a truly unique cinematic experience.

This movie is so well done. A great piece of entertainment it had it all. Good characters, good acting, good sets, good story and great directing. If you dont like subtitles no matter youll be so wrapped up in this film youll barely notice. A MUST SEE!
the hype is real for once

Watching this movie without knowing anything, not reading the synopsis, no watching the trailer, no expectation at all besides all the good and positive review from a bunch of people. Nor that I know before that Parasite took home Palme d' Or at this year's Cannes Film Festival.

And... damn just damn!! This movie turns out to be a really good movie!! So good that after the twist in the middle of the movie, I can't even blink my eyes even just for a second. Even the ending makes me to hold my breath for quite time. Now I know why Parasite took home that most prestigious award.

To describe Parasite is like when you bought a K*nd*rj*y, you like the toy when you open it (to describe the twist in the middle), and surprisingly found liquor after you bite the chocolate (like the best dessert you ever tasted). And yes, it is just that damn good! Bong Joon Ho succesfully gave a light story and more comedy at the beginning, getting a little serious with a genre change in the middle, and gave us the perfect twist with that ending.

There's nothing more that I will spill about this movie, just go and see it for yourself since this movie will definitely blow your mind. And if you like Japanese movie The Shoplifters who also took out Palme d' Or last year and being nominated as Best Foreign Film at the Oscars and Golden Globes last year (if it's not because of Rome, Shoplifters would bag those awards for sure), you definitely would love this movie too.
Its A Must Watch Movie
Fascinating film, interesting characters, dealing with the haves and the have-nots. Many striking visuals that will linger long after you leave the theater. Excellent acting. Thought provoking.

Bong Joon-ho's typically heavy-handed approach to class commentary works charmingly as a black comedy. Parasite is as cruel as it is witty, and is as charming as it is obscene. Despite dragging on for a touch longer than it may have needed to, the ending is more than worth it.
Tense, brilliantly crafted, and surprisingly timely, Parasite finds director Bong Joon-ho masterfully blending a suspenseful mystery and relevant social themes with ease!

It's very tense, even during the comedic sense because you wonder constantly if the characters will hit any form of conflict. The director gets us invested in the main characters so fast because of their living state which kind of makes you feel bad and slightly supportive for them. Even as protagonists, they are slightly shaped as villains but at least you understand why they are taking every bit of chance from this opportunity. 
It's very clear in terms of structure and it is a very ambitious story that has finally gotten me out of my comfort zone when it comes to watching different genres of film.
5 star. great movie. one of the best movies i have seen in recent times
Entertaining, shocking tale of the worthlessness of lower class ambitions and the resulting havoc to the one-percenters that ignor their plight.
It was more of a plain dark movie, than a dark comedy.  Original and very good, but not the best ever.
Silly. If the message is you reap what you sow I get it. A little less would have been more.

It's rare for a film to come along and blow me away as much as "Parasite" did.  It does it in a way that blindsided me. I wasn't expecting what crashed into me and derailed my senses.  Directed by master Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-Ho the film pulls you into the desperate world of a family living in poverty.  Getting work is tough, so when the sons friend offers an opportunity to tutor a rich teen in her family home, it becomes a chance to lift the whole family.
From there the film evolves several times into an unpredictable roller coaster ride that will shock, amaze and left me speechless.
This  is a not-to-missed thrilling experience. I wonder if a better film will come out all year.
GREAT film!!! Not many good films out there but this is one of them!!

_Really_? 99%??

Dragged the wife to this very highly reviewed, yet strange and horrible movie. Save yourself and don't do the same. 

The first clue should have been the Fandango description as a "Comedy, Drama, Suspense/Thiller" (?!). The first third of the movie showed promise, in setting up a Home Alone/Bird Cage sort of potentially-comedic-tension situation. But if this part had a Tim-Burton off-beat crazy momentum, the movie then screechingly suddenly gives way to Charles-Manson-like random progressive cruelty. 

Ah, but the cinematography! And the symbolism! (So much water-flooding water! and basements, and hidden sub-basements! And The Stone!) Ooh! 

Blech. All in service of a scattered, almost-pointless storyline, with...um...a healthy helping of unexpectedly gruesome graphic violence, along with a sprinkle of oddly clumsy couch-sex that will probably horrify anyone over 17. 

I dunno - maybe you like awful (subtitled) movies you have to go out of your way to see. Sometimes even I do. 

But not this time. Don't say I didn't warn you.

This movie was incredible by far one of my favorites. It was so visually captivating and I picked up one some fantastic visual nods to the story. Generally, I can get easily distracted during subbed movies and shows, but I very quickly felt like I wasn’t even watching a movie in a different langue than my own. I was on the edge of my seat the whole time, not sure what would happen next and it has been quite some time since a film has kept me on my toes.

After 10 minutes I was ready to leave "Parasite" but I can count on one hand how many movies I have walked out on so I decided to stay and find out why word of mouth was being so positive about the film.

Basically it is the story of how a very poor family of 4, parents, son and daughter scams their way into the home of a very wealthy family of 4 consisting of the parents, daughter and son. Really can't talk about the movie itself without giving spoilers, though none of them jolted and/or surprised me.

The movie is 2 hours and 13 minutes of which 13 minutes could have been cut very easily or spent in explaining some relationships that are sort of glossed over.

"Parasite" takes place in Korea and the differences between the classes are made immediately. The film has subtitles that took me a few minutes to get used to but to which I adapted fairly quickly.

I left the theatre glad I didn't walk out but at the same time I really can't see recommending it while, on the other hand, Allen thought it was a classic whodunit.

Bong Joon-ho's "Parasite" is a smart, wickedly funny and utterly unpredictable film that delivers a timely message about class discrimination in Korea. With his latest feature, Joon-ho has crafted a fascinating portrait of a poverty-stricken family living in Korea. Using gorgeous cinematography, the Korean auteur draws viewers into the world of a poor family that dreams of becoming rich. From stunning establishing shots to intense close-ups, the cinematography elevates the movie to another level. Aside from excelling behind the camera, Bong Joon-ho draws excellent performances from his ensemble cast. In the year's most award-worthy Asian ensemble, every actor gets the chance to shine and leave a lasting impression. Kang Ho-Song is the most notable standout as the desperate father of the Kim family. With riveting expressions, he captures the plight of a father struggling to be accepted by his rich owners. Although "Parasite" is undeniably exhilarating, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. At nearly two and a half hours, it is slightly long and suffers from a lengthy running-time. Moreover, its blood-soaked finale is a little drawn out and tests the viewer's patience. Nevertheless, "Parasite" is a must-see and one of the best films of the year. At a time when the Hollywood studio system seems to be running out of ideas, it is joyous to be reminded that foreign films like "Parasite" are still getting made.
A "Heathers" dark humor on a very relative timely topic. Being poor is becoming a crime in many countries.

Clever, heartwarming and heartbreaking.

Just when I’d relax and settle into a genre comfort zone, this Korean film would change gears until by the final shift into overdrive I was convinced I’d exit the theater with whiplash. Caught in the wildly unpredictable intersection of two South Korean families, we flow, over 132 roller coaster minutes, from slice of life satire to laugh out loud comedy to murder mystery to thriller to horror. We first meet the Kim family: former Olympian medalist, no-nonsense mom, philosophic dad and their twenty-something children, a clever, jaded daughter and a cagey, articulate son. Together they live in a cramped subbasement with a single window opening to an alley frequented by urinating drunks. Cobbling together pay-as-you-go jobs, the destitute family of four assemble pizza boxes and post advertisement fliers but still can’t stretch their collective earnings to prevent cellphone shutdown. I was instantly empathetic as they doggedly scramble about their tiny, cluttered basement quarters looking for an unprotected neighborhood wireless signal to hijack. Who amongst us can’t identify with the duress and agitation of no internet? I remember wandering around my backyard one blustery night during a power outage holding up my open laptop searching for a signal and happily tucking myself in the corner woodpile to draft off a neighbor’s service. We are won over by these Kims, a likable and resourceful pack, resigned to underclass status, not from lack of will or skill, but as victims of ravaging unemployment. Marked by a distinct working class odor from subway travel and basement travails, let’s call them “down but not out.” Next up, their polar economic opposites, the Park family: fashionable, fretting mom, high tech dad, preening adolescent daughter and hyperkinetic young son. This family of four live in 1% luxury, their home a gated modern mansion of renown architectural pedigree, tended by a chirpy Brady Bunch Alice-type maid and chauffeured in a top of the line classic black Mercedes-Benz. We common folk cruise along voyeur-like momentarily drinking in the fascinating lifestyle of fame and fortune. As most of us are interlopers to the decadence spawned by riches, the Park family are never in danger of generating empathy, but neither do they stir antipathy. A family of nouveau wealth, deemed “of course” entitled to servants, they deflect lurking presumptions of elitism by pointing out that they pay their staff more than the market rate. Call them “nice.” From the introductory phase of meet the Kims, greet the Parks, the plot flirts with a quasi Prince and Pauper remix, here a twist, there a turn, here a sting, there a caper. Out with the old (the Park support staff), in with the new (the Kim conniving crew). We enjoy the antics of the two families bizarrely blended by means and needs, schemes and scams. It’s a fun frolic! Then ominous storm clouds roll in, thunder booming as the Park’s original merry maid stages a dramatic return, throwing a lighting bolt of double dealing deception causing the walls of hoax and trickery to come a-tumbling down. It’s not fun anymore. It’s frightening and vicious. The once comedic clash between social classes turns into a literal flood of ugly, cruel, vindictive and murderous rage. Suddenly, I’m watching a cinematic detonation, the black comedy explodes into thriller, then slasher, splaying the complex social, cultural and economic layers wide open, leveling the playing field of the haves and the have nots in an astonishing, jaw-dropping finalé. Don’t let anyone persuade you that Parasite represents a societal showdown between good and evil. This film noses around in all the nuanced gray areas, exploring and ultimately unleashing the pent up human dynamics of hope and despair, greed and want, power and pain. This creative, complicated, masterfully orchestrated film will be a hands down Oscar contender—and, if Academy voters can look past subtitles, Parasite will rack up recognition well beyond the Foreign Language category. It may not stick around very long so best see it soon. It’s (wink, wink) a peach

“Parasite” Review (10/10) Snowpiercer director Bong Joon-ho has made a South Korean social satire that's also a genre-bending Palme d'Or-winning thriller of class struggle. It’s best to go into “Parasite,” the Cannes Film Festival grand-prize winner by Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-ho, not knowing too much about what you’re about to see; the better to let its sly power sneak up on you. A dark satire of the class divide in contemporary South Korea, it’s the story of two families of four. You’ll watch knowing you’re in the hands of a master filmmaker; only wondering when it’s over how certain effects were achieved (a sequence near the end is a wonder), and losing yourself in these characters: particularly the gentle, wide-eyed anxiety of Mrs. Park and the way that Ki-woo’s father, a man who cheerfully recites his string of failed businesses, remains determined to somehow find a way to make his family prosperous again. The title metaphor becomes abundantly clear, is filled with vivid conversations that remind us how the Parks can’t imagine (or don’t care to imagine) how the other half lives. In one scene, they coolly discuss how poor people smell; like an old radish, says Mr. Park, or a rag that’s been boiled. Ki-woo’s family, however, seems to understand the rich all too well. What keeps you rapt in Parasite is the visual wit, every shot distills the movie’s themes, and the richness of the characters and performances: Song’s stricken expression as Kim Sr. is driven to murder by class resentment, Lee Jeong-eun’s swift transformation from a calmly efficient housekeeper to a keening madwoman, and Choi’s eloquent helplessness as his teenage protagonist watches this new world order gorily combust. At the heart of Parasite is the most gnawing evolutionary fear of all, the inability to protect one’s family. Parents work to save their children but lose them, as children lose their parents and wives their husbands. The bonds are firm but can withstand only so much pressure before they fracture. Who are the real parasites? The poor who attach themselves to the rich or the rich who suck the marrow of the poor? The movie dissects the universal gap between the haves and the have-nots with shocking wit, stinging topicality and gut-wrenching violence. It’s explosive filmmaking on every level.

Okay Juicers, I am going to make a confession. I am not a huge foreign movie guy, but I am absolutely trying. I saw The Farewell earlier this year, I saw Pain & Glory (review coming soon) and I saw Parasite. Parasite is the newest movie from acclaimed Director Bong Joon-ho. I was excited to learn about this guy and I will be diving into his filmography soon because I LOVED this movie.

Parasite is a story about a family who slowly embeds themself with a wealthy across the town. The do this by slowly taking over all the positions in the household. They maneuver the son to become the tutor, they maneuver the daughter as another tutor, they bring in their dad as the driver and the mom as the maid. Now they have to do some bad (but sometimes funny) things in order to achieve this, but the movie does a great job of making it seem natural.

The true greatness in this movie though lies in the tone. The way Joon-ho maneuvers your emotions from laughing to freaking out between scenes is unlike you see in very many movies. The way it is paced only only helps that tone because they never linger on anything which makes bouncing from the suspense to the comedy so easy. The tone also helps balance the class commentary throughout the movie. Clearly the director wants people to understand natural life in Korea and commenting on the classes was the best way to do that.

Stock Watch

Stock Up – Bong Joon-ho made waves with Okja and he is continuing the hot streak as I said above. This guy just seems like a Kubrick type where his movies really try to put a spin on genres, from what I have read. This was a masterclass in filmmaking and I will watch anything he does from now on. I mean look at him he clearly has cool friends…

*A couple other tidbits

When you first see the maid hanging from the wall pushing the bookcase you are like WTF. Easily second best WTF moment this year behind Midsommar.

The romance between the son and daughter of the two families was a little weird.

Parasite is easily the biggest surprise of the year for me, and I honestly wish people could make more movies like this. Yeah its not 100% perfect but its original and was gripping from start to finish. This is me telling you Parasite is a good movie…

Juice Rating:
92/100

Parasite is the kind of movie that lingers with you for days, months, if not years. It would call it Bong Joon-ho's masterpiece for the whole world to see. Starring Song Kang-ho as Kim Ki-taek, Jang Hye-jin as Park Chung-sook, Choi Woo-shik as Kim Ki-woo and Park So-dam as Kim Ki-jeong, this dark thriller has some bizarre comedic elements, and dredges through the South Korean societal classes with the depth and uncertainty as who is hero and villain. The multiple layers of struggle placed upon each character only adds to the brilliance of the story and culminates with an even greater crescendo when their whole lives start falling apart. Part horrific disaster, part  frightening emotional congruence and part a wonderful expose of the lengths a whole family would go to cover for each other and make sure that each of them gets the proper slice of the proverbial pie of life that they can muster. Simply outstanding!

Parasite was a true tour-de-force twisted and ingenious thriller. I went into the film with very minimal knowledge on the events of it. I had only watched a small segment of the initial trailer, and I read a small blurb about it. All I knew was it was about two families, one rich and one poor, who become intertwined. I suggest you do the same. In a short time, he brings his parents and sister to work for them…then things take a very dark turn. Director Bong Joon Ho (best known for Snowpiercer) continues to showcase his skills at creating unique and disturbing storytelling. The combo of humor, suspense and violence lends this film an intelligent, yet visceral quality that's sure to stimulate and surprise. (Korean with subtitles)
